text: Klares schwarzbraun mit durchschnittlicher beiger Schaumkrone. RÃ¶stmalzig, dunkle Schokolade, Espresso, wÃ¼rzig, leicht trocken, etwas bitter.

Rami Rami is drinking an Obsidian Stout by Deschutes Brewery at Muzeum Azji i Pacyfiku

Jest palonosc, owoce, sporo zboza, kawy, chyba ciut jablka, rzeskie, lekkie, konsystentne mocno jak na %. Mile, codzienne takie

Zwart met fijne bruine kraag. Aroma van geroosterde en gebrande mout, donkere chocolade, mocca, koffie, cacao poeder. Smaken van geroosterde en gebrande mout, donkere chocolade, cacao, mocca, droog mondgevoel, matig geroosterd bitter, matig zoet, koffie, mocca, redelijke body, zachte co2, ok
Black with creamy foam. Apparent malty flavors of dried fruit and brown sugar. Aftertaste is long.

(Deschutes Obsidian Stout) Bottle 335ml at home, served into a shaker, ABV 6.4%
Dark brown to black colour on the body, small and thin beige head on top. 
Aroma of toasted malts, coffee, chocolate, mocha. 
Taste of coffee, dark bitter chocolate, mocha, roasted malts, coal. 
Mediumthin body. 
Pretty good.
On nitro. Pours oil black with steadfast beige head. Nose is coffee and chocolate with a similar taste. Mouthfeel is smooth nitro. Solid stout.
Pours very dark brown, with a tan creamy head. Chocolate milk aroma, chocolate taste and lots of rich roasted flavors, sweet overall, but with a low underlying bitterness. Low carbonation. Very good.

Bottle, 355 ml, courtesy of Max. Shared with him and JFK10000. Pours dark brown with light brownish head. Malty, cohocolate, roasted, coffee, sweet with somewhat harsh bitterness in finish. Medium bodied.
Klasyczny Stout z fajnym, kremowym ciaÅ‚em. DoÅ›Ä‡ wytrawne, mocno palone, trochÄ™ popioÅ‚u i lukrecji. Smaczne.
12oz bottle from Reid Market. Aromas of dark chocolate, coffee, toasted nuts, light molasses, light raisin. Black with a lasting tan head. Dry, roasty, burnt chocolate, light char. Full bodied.

This is quite a sound beer, big aroma, big mouthfeel, and a lot of somewhat unexpected bitterness. Lovely mouthfeel though and a nice bitter hop like finish make this a rather interesting and extricating beer.

12 ounce bottle. Pours opaque black with a large rocky tan head. Amazing roasted malt nose hints at espresso and licorice. First sip is dark roast malt at its finest. Rich and complex with notes of bittersweet chocolate and dark coffee. Hops come through in middle, balancing this stout nicely. A wonderful balance of sweet and dry make this a delicious stout of epic proportions. The finish has lingering malt roastiness that seems to last forever. Simply delicious and worth seeking out.
Bottle at home. Pours black, nose is chocolate, cream, light liquorice, taste is sweet, creamy, dark chocolate, light bitterness.
C-. Pours a black color with khaki head. Lighter body than expected. Also a bitter aftertaste

0,355l bottle at home bought from Beergium, courtesy of Saeglopur, big thanks. BB 04/24/2017. black color, medium coffee-colored head. smells milky, spices, peppery, bit joghurty, light roast, earthy. decent smell. full body, soft carbonation, slick mouthfeel. tastes of ash, spices, bit milky, peppery, some cardboard notes, chlorophyl, some vanilla. finishes bit roast and dry with notes of vanilla, cardboard and chlorophyl. do not like this, drinks rather unpleasant. the bottle from beergium arrived just a couple days ago, so I am rather surprised by the short BB date. not a fan.

Bottle from Beergium. Aroma is roasted malt, powdery cocoa, chocolate, caramel, touch of charcoal, coffee, hint of dark fruits. Flavour is moderate to medium sweet and above moderate roasty bitter. Body is medium. Lacks some depth, but tasty roasty coffee Stout.

35,5 cl bottle, BBE 24/4/17. Black beer with a light brown cappucino-like head. Wonderful aroma of coffee, chocolate, muscovado, the usual really, but it works every time. Fairly light body, I suppose due to the ABV in part. The coffee comes through pleasantly enough in the taste despite that, but thereÂ’s also some ashen character in the initial taste, a bit like a too bitter French press. ThereÂ’s a nice fruitiness in the taste, but overall this just needs more body. Still a solid coffee-infused stout, these just tend to shine more at about 3-4 % higher.

Bottle, BB 24.04.2017 (from beergium). Pours black with brownish head. Aroma is sweet, roast, oats, ashtray, lactose. Flavor is sweet and bitter, roast, coffee, ash, bit acidic, some licorice. Finish is roasty-ashy bitter with some sweetness. Body is on the thin side. Overall: ok. Technically even good, but lacks something I canÂ’t but my finger on. Definitley would like more malt backbone, but thatÂ’s not the only problem.

12 oz bottle. Dark black pour with a thick and creamy tan head. Malty chocolate goodness in the nose. Starts a touch sweet, then coffee, bitter chocolate and just a touch of hop bitterness in the finish. Excellent.

Bottle. Pitch Black in colour. Very Malty; roasted/burnt malts, espresso coffee, liquorice, caramel, hint of dark chocolate. Fruity: berries. Full bodied. Underlying sweetness with sour burnt edge. Tasty. Enjoyed this a lot. Very Nice Stout! 
(2008)
Black color with a light tan head of creamy foam. Light espresso and bakers chocolate notes. Medium to full bodied, rich mouthfeel. Dry coffee bean roast finish.
On nitro. Pours pitch black with light brown foamy head. A faint roasted malt and grain aroma. A creamy body with a taste of roasted malt, coffee, and chocolate. A lingering roasted malt aftertaste.

Pour from a 12oz bottle. Inky black brew with small tan head, good head retention and lacing. Aroma of roasted malt, burnt toast and coffee. As it warms in the glass ethanol aroma becomes noticeable. Taste is moderate sweet malt up front, coffee and dark roasted grains. Coffee and some chocolate emerge mid swallow with a sour / bitter hops emerging at the end. The hops in the finish is a little pronounced for a stout but compliments the roasted grain nicely and gives a dry finish. Palate is fairly thin but bolstered by moderate carbonation that keeps things lively. Overall a really enjoyable stout, though not the most complex.

UPDATED: JAN 27, 2017 Bottle poured into an English pint. Pours pitch black with a thick brown head that leaves light lacing. Aroma is pretty big and roasty with lots of coffee. Initial taste is espresso, earthy, coffee, bitter roast. That bitter roast aftertaste hangs around for a while. Body is full with surprisingly high carbonation. Good, for sure. Not my favorite out of their line up, though.

$2.10 bottle, Wine Warehouse. Pours somewhat thick and black, small tan head. Aroma is coffee, floral hops, citrus, and chocolate. Flavor is chocolate, roasted coffee, light floral notes, light ash. Not a huge, strong, in your face flavor, but quite solid and drinkable.

Pours thick and black, with a tan crema and light aromas of cocoa, custard and a hint of tart plum. Initially creamy with roasted malt and lightly chocolate notes, thinning on the palate as red fruit and drier cocoa come through, along with a little ash and roast coffee. Good yet somehow unusual.

This is a fine, classic take on the American style stout. It pours dark brown to black with copper highlights and little foam. The aroma is coffee and a bit of citrus and charcoal. The flavor is all about the roasted malt. Not a bit sweet, not off balance, just a dark, rich, roasted malt character that is delicious to the last drop. A fine stout.
Pours black with small brown head. Aromas of dark chocolate and malt. Has a bitter hoppy finish. Thin mouth feel. Slight smokiness at the end.
Just a bit too thin for my taste. good balance between sweet and bitterness, overall very tasty. just not quite there.

Nice aroma of bitter chocolate, some charcoal, and a hint of vanilla. Ebony color with a huge tan head that you can float a bottle cap on. Sweet roasted malt up front. Bitter chocolate, coffee, and cacao, all swirling on the tongue. Bitterness is dark chocolate like and slightly dry. Finish had more sweet than bitter but balances somewhat at the end. Light to medium mouthfeel. Solid.

Bottle. Pours black with dark tan head. Nose of bread crust, chocolate, and coffee. Chocolate upfront with bready malt notes and some coffee following. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Dark dark pour with solid tan head. Nice strong aroma of coffee and chocolate. A little thin in the mouth for a stout. Nothing bad to say about the taste, but for some reason it just doesnÂ’t stand out. Too bad, I was hoping to like thins one better.
Bottles bought in Napa, CA. not creamy or heavy. Nice light coffee flavor. Not a lot of depth but good.
Bottle from Liquor Barn into a snifter. Pours black. Aroma of bittersweet chocolate and espresso.
12oz bottle pours black with tan head almost a rootbeer aroma with coffee flavor smooth drinking.

pours black with a medium dark tan head. Aroma of roasted malt and dark chocolate. Rich malty taste with some black coffee bitter notes. Thick creamy mouth feel. Some mild bitter linger. Not overly heavy, very drinkable. An enjoyable stout.

A 355ml bottle with a best before date of 30th January 2017, poured into a Spiegelau Stout glass. It poured black in colour with a big frothy three fingered mocha brown head with pretty good retention and great lacing. Aromas are light roasty, milk chocolate, coffee and a hint of raspberries. Tastes sweet-ish milk chocolate, a touch of dark fruit with a bitter roast coffee bean and espresso finish. Creamy, medium to light bodied with mild carbonation. Overall, an easy to drink Stout with nice chocolate and coffee notes.

Bottled. Pours black with an average tan head. Aroma of roasted, coffee, chocolate and dark fruits notes. Sweet flavor that ends up being more dry and slightly bitter. Medium bodied, oily texture and soft carbonation. A very nice Stout. ðŸŒŸðŸŒŸðŸŒŸðŸŒŸ
On nitro at Deschutes Public House. This could be the best stout IÂ’ve ever tasted, smoother than a milkshake, amazing.
Its my favorite, and while there may very well be a better one out there somewhere, I havenÂ’t found one I like more, so I gave it my top rating

Backlog, Bottle in 2010 or 2011 with Joe. Pours ultra viscous black with smaller head. Smell and taste of dark chocolate, burnt coffee, toast, barley and roasted malts were the main tasting notes we got out of it. Nice but possible too much char?
Stark contrast to Black Butte, nose on this is chocolate right up front. N2 tap pours nice and smooth. Flavor is mostly roasted malt, with a nice breadiness.
Had on tap at brew pub in Bend. Completely black, no light getting through. Noticeable brown top. Strong chocolate smell. Super thin. Could drink in winter.

Bottle. Aroma roasted malts with coffee grounds finish. Pours black with tan creamy head (thickness depends on how steady your hand is). The flavours may be robustly malty with a sweetness that may edge it to the stout/porter border. But it draws appeal from both. Splendid.

Pours as black as obsidian with an appealing crema head. Aromas of espresso and deep roasty malts. The flavors of a French Pressed coffee permeate the tastebuds. The boozy heat lingers on the finish. This is a beer thatÂ’s meant to be sipped and enjoyed.

Black with a regular brown head, good lacing. Nose of roasted malts, coffee and chocolate. About the expected in the palate: roasted malts, coffee and chocolate, with good dry hops to balance. It doesnÂ’t add anything to the stout universe, but itÂ’s a damn good stereotypical stout!

Cask at GBBF 2016, Olympia, London. A dark brown/black coloured pour with a small beige head on top. Roasty, malty, chocolate, coffee aroma. Tastes quite similar, roasty, malty, chocolate, espresso coffee, slight bitterness. Decent stout from Deschutes.
Black liquid with tan head. Aroma of coffee, chocolate, vanilla. Tastes same, medium sweet, medium bitter, light+ sour. Medium body, soft carb, long fin.
Cask @ GBBF 2016. Very dark brown with a small brown head. Malty and fruity tones. Malt, coffee, fruit and hops. Medium body with a nice bitter / fruity finish.

Draught at Toronado. Black color, beige head. Bitter taste with roasted malts, chocolate, hops, vanilla, nuts and a bit coffee. Bitter finish with roasted malts, hops, coffee, chocolate, nuts and a bit of licorice. Very nice stout.

Bottle. Pours dark brown with small brown reddish head. Aroma: roasted, sourish, coffe, chocolate, hay. Taste: medium bitter, dark chocolate, coffee. Medium body. Just a good stout, nothing special you just can drink it one after one. Good.

Aroma: roasty, smoke, chocolate, 
Appearance: black, clear, minimal head,tan foam, 
Taste:light sweetness, light bitterness, lightly sour, 
Palate: light body, thin feel, average carbonation, bitter, long finish,
Nitro draft. Pours black. Aroma and taste are chocolate, coffee, and some roasted malts.
Very dark, tan head. Bitter chocolate, roasted malt, dark malt, a little coffee. Thinner tongue than the full flavor would imply. Quite good. Rich.
Black and tan pour. Bitter dark chocolate and espresso flavours. Thin palate. Some balance in the mid length finish.  ---Rated via Beer Buddy for Android

12 oz. bottle, poured into a pint glass. Black pour, khaki brown head, nice lacing, which dissipates quickly. The flavor shows licorice and roasted malt, dark chocolate, coffee and dark fruit. Would definitely recommend really nice drinking stout.

Nitro to taster at source pour opaque black with large tan head. Nose lots of chocolate and roasted malt. Taste roasted malt, red fruit, dusty bakers chocolate. Light bitterness from the roast. Nice mouth feel on nitro.

Pours dark coffee black with medium tan head. Smells like coffee and chocolate and caramel in the nose. Taste is nutty with notes of chocolate and coffee. Finishes off with a bitter clean finish. Good stout will drink it again.

355ml bottle - thanks Allyson
Lovely rich tarry roast aroma. Black as your hat, lovely tight tan head. Fullish, but surprisingly light palate, pleasant carbonation. Very deep rich burnt roast, but staying just shy of ashiness. Nicely earthy bitterness. Very solid stout, packed full of character, but highly drinkable. Finish has a pleasant bitter tingle. As it warms it gets more character, gets really quite spicy. Like it - thanks again, Allyson!

Very roasty coffee aroma. Pours black with a rich tan head. Pretty big bubbled. Thinner body than expected / to balance the richness of the flavor. Sweet. Chocolate. Coffee flavors. Bitter flavors at the end do not interfere with the chocolate sweetness.

Really dark brown color with brown head. Aroma has dark malt, brown sugar and a good dose of hops. Taste starts with dark sugar, roasted malt and bakers chocolate. Body is quite thin for a stout, carbonation is medium. Overall itÂ’s a good stout but nothing to remember.

From 330ml bottle. Poured with huge tan head; was amazed how gassy it was and had to wait 2 mins to finish the pour. Appears browny black. Subtle aroma hinting at complexity and booze
Drinks with roasty flavour, tiny hint of coffee, hint of booze, complex and balanced a delicious stout. really excellent

Pours jet black with huge frothy rocky tan head that sticks all over. Aroma of chocolate, espresso coffee, and cocoa. Taste is very smooth and creamy with a malt sweetness up-front that is cut quickly by the bittering acidic burn of the roasted barley which lingers. Some sugar flavour make their way to the taste buds. The hop bitterness is at par with the roasted barley. Espresso, roast coffee flavours appear midway and fade a little with the other roasted flavors. This a great stout, one of the best IÂ’ve tasted.

12oz bottle from Total Wine. No room to safely pack it, so IÂ’m rating it in my room. Pours dark brown with a beige head. Aroma is dark chocolate, dark fruits and roast. Flavor is chocolate, dark fruits, a hint of molasses, roast to balance. A pretty good stout.

355ml brown bottle. Black pour, dark brown head, thick glass coating lacing. The aroma shows licorice and roasted malt., dark chocolate and coffee. Taste has bitter roasted malts, coffee, toasty, nutty. Dry and bitter finish. Big flavours, very drinkable.
On tap at Hopcat. Smokey notes. Pours dark on nitro. Smooth mouthfeel but thin. Not a huge fan of the smokey.

Pours black with quickly dissipating head. Aroma of burnt toffee, black coffee and dark chocolate. Flavour is smooth with a rich mouthfeel and lightly bitter aftertaste

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Beer looks great and smells very good but tastes terrible. Even worse is the after taste. It just lingers and hits you in the back of the tongue. Stay away from this beer

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
12 oz. bottle. Poured black with thick dark tan head. Aroma was coffee, espresso and molasses. Taste was roasted coffee and mild bitterness.
A very very good stout! Beautiful head and lacing. Quality beer very evident. Hoppiness is a pleasant surprise. Won worldÂ’s best stout for a reason!
12 oz bottle pours black with a tan head. Aroma of chocolate, malts and toffee. Taste is coffee and chocolate.
@ Deschutes 16-3-10: trevlig rostat smak med en hel del kaffe, arrak och vanilj. Torr eftersmak.
On tap at the Brewpub in Portland. Black with a small tan head. Rather creamy with roasted malt, chocolate and coffee. Also some hints of dark fruit and caramel. A pleasant one.

UPDATED: SEP 22, 2016 From 12 ounce bottle poured to wine glass, drank before 08/21/2016
Appearance: Pours black- even the edge of the wine glass is black no to minimal head some lacing 
Smell: Hint of toasted grain 
Taste: Toasted grains, bitter, but well balance with nice follow through
Feel: creamy, very good
Overall: Excellent beer, something to drink again
Drank: March 10, 2016

Bottle. Deep brown black almost opaque with a nice creamy tan head. Coffee, roasted beans, espresso, cocoa, dark chocolate aroma. Moderately sweet with flavors of coffee, caramel, chocolate licorice, burnt malt, bitter finish. Medium bodied, smooth with moderate carbonation. Great Stout.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours deep black with a tan head. Nose is dark toffee and molasses. Taste is creamy dark chocolate, coffee with a hint of caramel. Creamy mouth feel with moderate carbonation. Top stout

Appearance of almost black with a creamy tan head leaving nice lace. Smell of rich chocolaty coffee notes and sweet dark malts. Taste has the same notes as the aroma with a nice hop balance to round off the flavor. Mouthfeel is viscous with good carbonation. overall a very nice bold stout that would go very well with some rich chocolaty desserts.

Milky, chocolatey, just a hint of Kona coffee. Almost black as midnight with a supreme creamy texture. Has a slightly bitter aftertaste that lasts until the next quaff. Almost a smidgen of brown sugar sweetness as well. Very delicious. My local distributor said he can get me a 1/6 brl of this, and I think I may just do that. Very good out of a bottle, cannot imagine how good this would be from a nitro tap.
Bottle into pint glass. Pours a jet black with light brown head. Aroma is roasted malt and coffee. Taste is chocolate and a little coffee with a pleasing bitterness.

Pours a jet black with a foamy tan head. Aroma is roast, chocolate, and earthy notes. Flavor is chocolate and roast, with some earthiness. Has a nice body. Almost sweet, well-balanced. This is one amazing stout.

On tap. Rich black mahogony hue and dark walnut on the edges. Medium pillowy tan head that sticks pretty good through the pint. Nice chocolate notes that are smooth and not too bitter. Subtle coffee and burnt toffee notes come in hints. Very smooth and drinkable beer.
Black. Anise aroma some chocolate and esters. Malty. With cocoa and sweet caramel. Anise licorice a bit strong. Piney? Bitter.

A thick, wet black pour from the bottle into a pint glass with a full black color topped by a large creamy-foamy tan head with excellent retention, and average cling and lacing. Its aroma featured a blend of malty tones, including chocolate, caramel, and coffee along with some earthy and grainy notes. The taste was mildly bitter with a rich chocolate and coffee blend, which also had a touch of sweetness and an earthy finish. The beer had a very thick, full mouthfeel with a heavy body and average carbonation for a smooth finish. Excellent stout!
Cloying sweet. Strong coffee on nose that reminds me of my morning coffee, which is nice. There was something funky on the palate....very molasses.

Shared 12 oz. bottle. Pours black with a tan head; moderate amounts of lacing left on the glass. Aroma and flavors of roasted malt, coffee, some chocolate notes. Light to medium-bodied. A nice bittersweet finish. I like.

Aroma: chocolatey and rich; yummy; Appearance: pitch black with piilowy tan head that lingers; nice lacing; Taste: also rich and chocolatey but not too sweet; Palate: heavy body, smooth; long, sweet finish with a little hops; Overall: lovely stout; would definitely buy again.

A very dark black with small head and curtains of lace. Aroma of dark chocolate, espresso, deep roast malts. A little sweet in the aroma that is not apparent in the taste. Taste is roasted barley, dark chocolate and black strong coffee. Bitters as the finish gets longer. Slick in the mouth not as think as expected. Does not present well but is an excellent brew
Bottled. Pours black, big tan head. Aroma is roasted malts, chocolate, caramel, coffee. Flavor is chocolate, malts, coffee bitterness and hop bitterness. Full bodied. Really solid hoppy Stout.

Dark with lots of tan head and lacing. Aroma of dark roasted coffee, some sweetness, and espresso. Roasty throughout slight dark fruit but mainly dark chocolate and coffee. Just enough hops to cut the sweetness and keep it fairly dry. Roast lingers for a very long finish
Bottle in Portland, OR. Black oily body with thin tan head. Nose is malts, chocolate, caramel, roasty. Taste is caramel, malts, plums, barley. Oily texture. Sweet, punchy finish.

12 oz bottle. DonÂ’t even recognize these bottles anymore, and then wonder how the hell i never rated it in the first place. I gotta start going back through all the beers i had in my freshman year of beer drinking. This was definitely one of them. Nice toasty flavor here. Roasted malt heavy. One of the most interesting stouts these guys have. Ill have another.

Bottle from a trade. Poured into glass. Nose is a very inviting dark cocoa powder and baking chocolate. LARGE light brown head with large bubbles. Taste is very dark roast coffee and bitter like coffee grinds. Overall very good, but a tad too focused on the dark coffee bitterness without the body to back it up

Bottle sample at a tasting at Beer and Beyond, Tel Aviv. Deep black with big brownish head. Aroma of licorice, milk chocolate, lots of wood and some coffee. Flavor of roasted malt, licorice and coffee, bitter finish, dry. Medium to full-bodied. Very nice.

Poured into English pint a dark black with decent mocha head and curtains of lace. Aroma of dark chocolate, espresso, deep roast malts. A little sweet in the aroma that is not apparent in the taste. Taste is roasted barley, dark chocolate and black strong coffee. Bitters as the finish gets longer. Slick in the mouth not as think as expected. This is one to take slowly.
12 oz bottle. Pours black with full tan head. Aromas of black coffee and roasted malts with some plastic notes. Flavors of same. An easy going stout that is easy to drink.

Bottle to Styrofoam cup. Road beer to Baltimore. Look: dark black, thick, really big foamy tan head. Aroma: lots of roasted malt and oatmeal, touche of coffee. Taste is barley oatmeal, very grainy. Some chocolate, coffee, vegetable. Mouthfeel is thin, but creamy. A lingering siltyness like some Irish stouts. Overall, Reminds me of Samuel Smith Oatmeal Stout.

Bottle 12 fl.oz from La Cave du Haut Jura - St-Laurent-en-Grandvaux (F). Poured black and fat with a brownish crown of 1 cm. Torrefied and intense aroma. The taste is supple, ever very torrefied, espresso, bitter chocolate, a little earthy and ashes. Bitterness of roasted coated by hops with a note of smoked. Masculine Stout, without feminine side, burned and bitter.

Purchased at Albertson in Vegas. Pours a deep brown colour with light ruby highlights. The head is creamy-foamy, beige, long lasting and gives out chunky lace. Sweet dark fruit aromas with the roasted malts and coffee notes. The taste is similar to the nose with some added hops, but mild, that creates a nice light dryness. Kind of the coffee replaced with some grass notes. A pretty good stout overall.
Was hoping for more with this one. Lots of flavors but i was expecting a little sweeter. New to this style but have had better

Bottle in LA. Pour rich black with tan head. Chocolate, roast and some hops on the aroma. Flavour is chocolate, roastiness, a little hop, finishes with roasted malt astringency and lingering hop bitterness. I prefer a little less astringency but itÂ’s still a great stout.

Great dark color, cream head that thickly climbs to side of glass stickily. Deep, rich malt smell. Strong oatmeal flavor upfront that passes and mellows, slowly into chocolate notes. Fantastic specimen.
Bottle from Favourite Beer, Cheltenham. Advent beer day 1. Black colour with a thick creamy tan head. Aroma us roasted and toasty malt. Taste chocolate and roasted bitterness, with a sweet finish.

UPDATED: DEC 11, 2015 Pours a deep brownish black from the bottle with thin tan brown head that leaves moderate lace. Aroma and taste of earthy hop, roasted malt, and fruity yeast esters. Really nice, easy drinking stout. Even better on nitro tap.

Pours black with tan head; nice sticky lacing. Aromas of coffee, cocoa, and molasses. Flavor is very similar; dark chocolate, espresso, licorice, and molasses. Would definitely recommend.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Pours deep brown to black. Robust, slow-receding beige head. Noticeable alcohol aroma with bright fruit and caramel. Roasted malt and dark chocolate flavor. Warming finish, slightly dry and bitter. Straightforward and clean. A touch high on alcohol for a stout, but not quite overpowering.

Pours opaque cola-brown-to-black with a 1-finger caramel-colored head. Aroma of dark-roasted coffee with a touch of chocolate. Body is medium-to-full. A touch oily, with a dry finish. Flavor of coffee, with a bit of char at the back.

Rich flavor but not as much coco or coffee as I would like. I'll for sure buy again though.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Black pour with a tight beige head that holds up well. Coffee, roast, liquorice aromas. Taste is sweetish, molasses, coffee, cocoa, a little creamy mouthfeel, finishes like iced coffee
Heavily roasted malts, toasted grains and dry coffee. Notes of toffee, brown sugar and light cream. Moderate/strong bitterness.

Pours a black colour with a medium tan-coloured head. The aroma is of coffee and roasted malt. The taste is slightly of roasted malt and ethanol, but mostly of hops with a moderate bitterness that is long lasting on the palate. Overall, a reasonably good quality beer.

It is a pleasant stout but not special in any way. My tongue gets a bitter sting at the front which differs from others stouts IÂ’ve had especially so since the bitter doesnÂ’t linger. Bit thin for a stout in my opinion.. overall a fine stout, ij just expected more.
Bottle to porter glass. Pours dark black and opaque. Great malt nose and flavors of chocolate and coffee. Delicious

12 ounce bottle into tulip glass, best before 2/29/2016. Pours pitch black color with a 1-2 finger dense and rocky tan head with great retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lingers. Nice dense soapy lacing clings around the glass. Aromas of big dark chocolate, cocoa, coffee, molasses, raisin, plum, licorice, toast, dark bread, light smoke/char, pine, and herbal/roasted earthiness. Fantastic aromas with great complexity and balance of dark/roast/bready malt and moderate earthy hop notes; with great strength. Taste of big dark chocolate, cocoa, coffee, molasses, raisin, plum, licorice, toast, dark bread, light smoke/char, pine, and herbal/roasted earthiness. Good amount of herbal/pine/roasted bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of dark chocolate, cocoa, coffee, molasses, toast, dark bread, light smoke/char, pine, and herbal/roasted earthiness on the finish for a while. Fantastic complexity, robustness, and balance of dark/roast/bready malt and moderate earthy hop flavors; with a nice roasted bitterness/sweetness balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Fair amount of dryness from roasted bitterness as well. Medium carbonation and body; with a very smooth, moderately creamy/bready, and sticky/chalky mouthfeel that is great. Alcohol is very well hidden with minimal warming present after the finish. Overall this is a fantastic American stout style. All around awesome complexity, robustness, and balance of dark/roast/bready malt and moderate earthy hop flavors; and very smooth and easy to drink. A highly enjoyable offering.

Bottle at home. Black pour. Chocolate, spice, wood, sweet iced coffee, layers of roasted malt flavor intermingled with sugar and spice and ashy smoke. Perfectly balanced finish. Up there with the better of them.
Rich roasted malt flavors of dark coffee/ espresso, chocolate, black licorice. Balanced with a moderate hop backbone and just enough depth to feel warming, while still sessionable.

Bottle in the Junkyard, Nottingham. Pours black with a nice beige head. Mild cocoa aroma. The tatse is full of roast coffee and dark chocolate. Some light spice too. Rich and delicious. The body is perhaps a touch thin, but otherwise superb.

Pour out of 12 oz bottle, dark black pour with tan head, aroma brought notes of big dark chocolate, coffee, hints of dark fruit, some brownie. Taste was a mix of brownie, chocolate, coffee, roast, hints of spice, vanilla, nice earth, finishing fairly sweet, slightly roasted.

Midnight blackness with two fingers of toffee on top. Nose is espresso. Bittersweet. Middle is dark patent and chocolate malt, coffee, and coco. Finish is bittersweet and full bodied. Tour de force brew.

Bottle. 

A: Pitch black with a large mocha head. 

N: Roast, espresso, bakerÂ’s chocolate, some black cherry, black peppercorn, earth, some leather, some vanilla, more char. 

T: Bitter and sweet in rich proportions. 

M: Medium body, no alcohol presence, crisp carbonation.

O: A stout that thinks itÂ’s a double and acts like an imperial. Really get the sense of Abyss in this and it is really, really good.

Aroma is robust, chocolate, roasted malt, very nice. Appearance is black, light brown head, poured thin. Taste is robust roasted malt, chocolate, lingering bitterness. Mouthfeel is thick, soft carbonation, oily, very nice. Overall, this is very well done.

Draft: (nitro)
Black with a creamy tan head.
Coffee, roasty chocolate aroma.
Slightly smoky....coffee, chocolate malt....mild ashy bitter flavour.
Very good...rich....

Roasted malt and chocolate dominate the nose. This thing is BA. Black as night pour with a khaki colored head. Taste is wonderful, coffee, chocolate, smoke and slight bitter hops. Palate is medium bodied and creamy. This is so good, glad I got a six pack, canÂ’t wait to get another one. Must try.
Leans sweet...with heavy coffee and chocolate flavor. Dark black color with thick creamy head
Tap @ the chance... aroma is espresso, malts, and chocolate, taste is soy, espresso, coffee, and some hops. A real hop finish on this, very nice

Bottle shared at LeightonÂ’s place. 25/08/2015. Bottle from GBBF. Aroma is toasted coconut, earthy ashy roast, charcoal, oyster. Pitch black coloured pour with a lasting frothy mid tan head. Flavour is composed of ashy charcoal. cocoa, toasted coocnut, dry roast coffee, ashy. Bitter roast in the finsh. Palate is medium full, moderate carbonation. Ok some earthy mushroom.

Nitro tap at the Holy Grale. Pours black with a creamy beige head that leaves plenty of lacing. Aroma and taste of rich dark chocolate, cocoa, roasted malts, espresso, black licorice, caramel and toffee. Full bodied, creamy and thick palate, moderate carbonation. An absolutely excellent stout!

Bottle share at LeightonÂ’s, thanks to Fergus. Pitch black, big foamy brown head, light lacing. Aroma is ashy, tangy hoppy blackcurrant jam, coffee bean. Body is light, tingly carbonation, slightly foamy. Taste is strongly ashy, biscuity malts, bourbon biscuit, medium bitterness. Has a pleasant ashiness. My kind of stout.

Bottle thanks to Fergus. It pours near black with a decent beige head. The nose is rich, toasty, liquorice, charred aspect, plum, prune, coffee and chocolate cake. The taste is smooth, toasty, chocolate, rich roast, robust, burnt fruit cake, ashy, cocoa and light pepper with a smooth, toasty finish. Medium body and moderate carbonation. Good body and drinkability. Nice one.

Bottle shared in London - many thanks to Fergus. Pours deep black-brown with a frothy khaki head. Dry roasty malts in the nose, cocoa, ash. Medium sweet flavor with burnt wood, earth, chocolate, dried dark fruits. Medium bodied with fine carbonation and velvety texture. Fairly sweet on the finish, more ashy roast, burnt earth, sugary chocolate, raisins. Not bad overall.
On tap, kop f&h. Deep dark brew with strong silky tan head coating the glass all the easy down. Strong coffee and bakery bites and rich malted earthy tastes. Smooth on the palate. Dessert in a glass

Poured from bottle into a pint glass
 Appearance Â– The beer pours a very dark brown, nearly black, color with a small tan colored head of one finger height. The head has a decent level of retention fading over a moderate amount of time to leave a good deal of foamy lace on the sides of the glass.
 Smell Â– The aroma of the beer is massive of a coffee smell mixed with a nice showing of a roasty smell and a little bit of cream like aroma. Along with these smells comes a light caramel sweetness and a little bit of a burnt toast smell, giving a very nice deep and dark strong expresso like smell overall.
 Taste Â– The taste begins as the nose would suggest with a whole lot of roasted malt and a strong showing of coffee. Upfront there is a bit of a caramel sweetness which seems to fade as the taste advances. While the caramel fades, other sweeter flavors of a light vanilla and sweet crÃ¨me flavor come to the tongue. These remain lighter overall keeping the taste on the drier side. More and more roast and coffee come to the tongue at the end of the taste, where with a little bit of an earthy and char taste, end up leaving one with a nice dark and roasty coffee flavor to linger on the tongue.

 Mouthfeel Â– The body of the beer is average to slightly lower for a stout of 6.4 % abv., with a carbonation level that is rather average. A thicker body and lower carbonation level may have accentuated the nice coffee and roasted flavors slightly better, but overall, the feel was OK.

 Overall Â– This is a very nice coffee heavy flavored stout with tons of roasty and dark flavors. The taste and aroma are nearly spot on, with the only thing holding it back a bit being its moderate mouthfeel. Even with that said, I must say this is a nice, more moderate in abv. stout overall .
They really did a nice job with this one...nose is roasted malt....flavor is delicious nothing over the top...very enjoyable...yummy!

12 oz pour from chilled bottle into tulip glass. Black, opaque, moderate light brown head with nice lacing. Roasty nose, sweet, caramel, coffee. Body is fairly thin for a stout, a little crisp and sharp on the end. IÂ’d prefer it thicker. Taste is good though. Roasty, a little woody, coffee, maybe burnt toast. Aftertaste is bitter with some woodchip notes. Not bad, but I prefer stronger stouts with more body.

BOTTLE. Cola black with solid tan head (coke spider).. Dark malts on the nose with a hint of warm booze.. Good dark roasted malts throughout the beer, good rich creamy finish with a burnt malt/dark chocolate back end.. Sourced RW

UPDATED: AUG 8, 2015 Smells like burnt coffee. Dark obviously. Nice off white foam. Taste cigarettes, coffee, mild sweetness, mild bitterness. Relatively savory stout, not sugary like many others. Mouthfeel medium to thick. Great

Midnight black in the glass. Tan head...just not much of one. Heavy mouthfeel. Rich, dark coffee and chocolate. Some molasses in the background. Lotsa malt. Hops come in just enough to balance everything out. Well made. Worth the coin.

Bottle from Schnucks. Aroma is of roasted, smoky malts. Appearance is opaque black with 1 finger-width beige head and trace lacing. Taste is roasted malt with dominant smoky flavor with moderate bitterness. Palate is surprisingly light-to-medium bodied with thin texture, minimal carbonation and long bitter finish. Overall, a good beer but a little thin and a little more bitter than IÂ’d prefer for the style beyond just the smokiness. Still good, but there are better ones out there.

Nitro-tap. Served a dark brown color with a thick tan head and good lacing Aroma of roasted malt, some coffee, bit of chocolate and nut. Taste of roasted nut, nice touch of coffee and chocolate. Nice bitterness and a dry finish. Full body, quite thick and creamy with a nice robust feel. Enjoyable beer

Really it is that good on nitro. Creamy chocolate slight burnt. Nice grain aroma. Just awesome overall. Good mouthfeel and sweetness. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Dark brown colour with nice beige head on top and lots of lacing. Aroma has roasted malts, dark chocolate and some coffee. Taste has espresso coffee, dry roasted flavours and more coffee. Medium body with medium carbonation.
Nice and roasty, notes of coffee, bitterness that sticks to the pallette. Overall, very nice yet thinnish stout.
Another great beer to style from deschutes. Robust coffee and some toffee and caramel to round out beer. Very mild hops. Silky smooth carbonation and toasty finish.
roasty, alcohol, smoke, black, tan foam, light sweetness, medium bitterness, medium sourness, umami, soft carbonation, bitter, medium body, two months till due date.
Very nutty and malty to the taste. Good carbonation and lacing. Aroma of nuts and malts.

Excellent example of a Pacific Northwest stout. Jet black with tan head. Coffee aromas come out nicely. No alcohol like a RIS. Flavor of slight vanilla earthy hiops and an abundance of light roast coffee.

Black wih reddish hue. Nice dense head. Espresso, fruit hints, hops. Taste is little acidic and fruity at the front end, light sweetness, then becomes drier roasted malts, coffee, hints of cocoa. Oily/creamy mouthfeel, average carbonation with very small bubbles. Balanced, very drinkable and satisfying.

Pours dark brown, almost black, with a medium/large beige head, moderate lacing. Aroma is chocolaty and roasty with a hint of espresso. Medium bitterness on taste. The body was surprisingly light for a stout. Mouthfeel is slightly oily and there is a long lasting bitter finish. Overall, a good stout. It could use a little more body and sweetness.

American stout from this renowned brewery, with a very dark, hazy burgundy colour, practically black, under a creamy, lacing, dense, tan head with very good retention. Strong and very pleasant, flawless aroma of espresso and coffee beans, cocoa powder and meat broth all working well together and forming a Â’trueÂ’ stout experience, hoppy hints of black pepper and grapefruit peel (I even fancy myself in a black IPA for a brief moment), wet leather, dry autumn leaves, peat, Â’bloodÂ’ (iron in a natural kind of way), brown bread, chestnuts, dried plums, subtle hints of cigar tobacco, elderberries and whisky, even a very subtle touch of sweet cherries as it warms up - in fact, it becomes sweeter and Â’friendlierÂ’ as a whole when warming up, so IÂ’d recommend serving this at cellar temperature and letting it warm to room temperature to be able to fully savour it. Dried fruits in the onset, only restrainedly Â’raisin and datesÂ’ sweetishness but also bittering already a bit on the tip of the tongue; creamy, soft mouthfeel with finely sparkling carbo, smooth, with a full, decent maltiness growing Â’darker and darkerÂ’ in the end; deeply nutty at first but already with a big dosis of bitter chocolate, and a clear coffee-like roasted bitterness, already well noticeable in the beginning, but gaining strength as it evolves and eventually supporting a generous dosis of peppery, spicy, long-lasting, resinous hops and some lingering yeastiness, though it is still the Â’black coffee roastednessÂ’ which establishes itself as the final impression; alcohol remains almost perfectly hidden (as it should be in a beer of this ABV). Dry, smooth but coffeeish and bitter with a strong hop bitterness in the end: this is indeed a very typical and well-crafted example of the Â’ordinary American stoutÂ’ style (if such a thing exists), related to the old European dry and export stouts.  I particularly like the fact that it keeps an overall bitter flavour throughout its palate and ends satisfyingly dry - that is, no cloying sweetness at all.  Extremely well-balanced.
Pours black with beige head. Aroma is roasted, espresso and pine. Flavour is roasted, coffee, light to medium sweet and light bitter and dark chocolate.
Black with big brown lasting, lip sticking, lacing foam head. Coffee aroma, coffee, chocolate and roasted nuts in taste. Wonderful beer. (Houston 201505)

If youÂ’re going to name your beer after a gorgeous Oregonian natural wonder, your beer damn well better be a gorgeous Oregonian natural wonder. Obsidian Stout delivers. It pours the color and consistency of ink. Lovely head and lacing, too. Its aromas are roasty and somewhat chocolaty. Flavors follow the aroma with coffee and traces of (milk and dark) chocolate. When I say this Stout is bittersweet, I mean it truly treads the line between bitter and sweet. The bitter hops go nicely with the toasted malt flavors (which are redolent coffee bean acidity). On the sweet side are the malty, chocolaty notes. While the balance is splendid, itÂ’s also the thing that keeps Obsidian from being a perfect score for me. While some love balance, I tend to prefer a Stout (even a complex one like this) to choose side rather than pick the middle. I say be rich or roasty. Still, itÂ’s hard (and perhaps unnecessarily nit-picky) to fault the balance. Obsidian is a brilliant example of the American-style Stout.

Black pour with a two finger, creamy to rocky tan head that has excellent retention. Aroma is roast, dark chocolate, dark roast coffee, pine, a little molasses and a hint o char. Flavor is roast, chocolate, toasted pumpkin bread, molasses, bittersweet baking chocolate, dark roast coffee and a hint of woody pine. Medium body, creamy to syrupy entry, light, blanketing and sharp carbonation and dry, slightly chalky finish with a light boozy burn. Good stuff overall.

Aroma: Roasty/ dark chocolate balance; light to moderate blackberry jam. Appearance: Oily black with a nice, bubbly mocha head that fades into a bubbly ring. Flavor: Not surprisingly similar to Black Butte; more dark chocolate than roast up front; roast picks up more toward the finish, which is surprisingly, but pleasantly bitter and brings back a little of the jam from the nose. So, kinda bittersweet really. Palate: Medium body, creamy texture, soft carbonation, bittersweet finish. Overall: Liked this better than BB; also a great price to quality ratio.
355ml bottle from Saveur-Biere.com. Pours opaque black with thin tan head. Light fudge / coffee aroma. Great bitter / roasted malt taste. I like.

First rate stout. ItÂ’s hard to believe they can pack so much flavor into a 6.4 abv brew. Lots of malty complexity in the flavor and mouth feel - marshmallow , coffee, wood smoke. The price was right too for such a fine release.
12 ounce bottle purchased at Archer Liquors by Midway Airport Chicago. Very good!

Poured on nitro. Opaque, jet black. Ample creamy tan head. Deep dark expresso and dark chocolate, sausage and umami. Dark roasted bitterness, not much in the way of sugar and sweetness. Long dry finish, bigger body, creamy mouthfeel. Good.

355 ml bottle from Saveur-biere.fr, France. Black body with a thin light brown head. Aroma of chocolate, coffee and roasted notes. Taste is bittersweet with chocolate and dark fruits, paired with coffee and roasted notes. Medium body with low to medium carbonation.

Pours opaque black brown with dark tan head. Aroma is caramel, chocolate, overall chocolate covered malt balls. ItÂ’s well hopped, so the chocolate combines with the bitterness for coffee and caramel in the mouth. Not quite the heights of black butte, but damn good.

Great roasty flavour, nice lacing. Overall a fantastice medium bodied stout with mild carbonation. Beautiful rich taste with hints of chocolate and coffee. Mild sweetness and a nice bitter note to it.

Pours opaque deep brown with barely present brown highlights, two fingers of fluffy tan head, good retention and excellent lacing. (4/5) Nose is dark roasty malt, dark chocolate, coffee, toasted grain, mild liquorice and vanilla. (8/10) Taste is moderate sweet, mild bitter. (8/10) Medium to full body, mild carbonation, dry and slightly warming finish. (4/5)

A very good stout, and only slightly Â“AmericanÂ” - the ABV is somewhat higher than most traditional English stouts and thereÂ’s a tiny hint of citrusy tartness in the finish, but thatÂ’s the extent of its variation from type. IÂ’d like to try it on a nitro tap, though, for some extra smoothness. (16/20)

Cervesa amb aroma i gust a cacau, en boca tÃ© una textura molt sedosa.
Cerveza con aroma y sabor a cacao, en boca tiene una textura muy sedosa.

Pours a nice dark brown, almost Guinness-like though the head doesnÂ’t come close. Had a much more pronounced coffee taste than chocolate...not a bad thing. Left a bit more bitter taste than I wanted, Was actually expecting to rate this higher but 3.5 isnÂ’t a bad score.

Bours black with a fine tan head. Nose is coffee and milk chocolate, a little caramel. Body is heavy and rich. Chocolate cake, coffee, spiced chai, a little burnt toast. Medium to heavy body, surprising given itÂ’s not that heavy a beer. Creamy and viscous mouthfeel. A bigger beer than I expected.

[2/16/15] Draught at CameronÂ’s Inn in Half Moon Bay. Black with a nice brown head. Nice roasty aroma with dark chocolate and coffee. Bittersweetish roasty flavor with coffee and some dark chocolate. Creamy and slightly watery nitro mouthfeel. Good.

Black body, large, creamy off-white head, soapy lacing. Earth, bittersweet chocolate, light roast, a little bit of chalk. Medium bodied, velvety effervescent on Nitro tap, mild bitterness, semi-dry throughout.

Bottle: Clear, dense, red hue, light head and moderate lace. Lifted fruit, spice, malt, anise, clean, fresh and certainly not excessively roasted. Dry, not sour and moderate bitterness. Palate is clean, only medium weight. Good balance and texture. Flavours are complex with coffee, chocolate, fruit and brown spice. 
Nice beer but lacks the next level of saturation and mouthfeel that iÂ’m looking for.

10.7.2014. Black beer, quickly disappearing brown head, looks highly carbonated. Oily appearance. Aroma is sweetish, slightly roasted, malty, some chocolate. Lowish carbonation, slightly oily texture. Similar notes than in aroma, plenty of malts, some chocolate, roasty and liquorice which maybe gives the sweetish touch. Slightly bitter finish. Guess this is somewhere between stout and IS but not quite there. Rather simple still but good.

Dark beer with some reddish hues when held against the light. Frothy beige head. Nose of some sweetened coffee, chocolate and toasted grains. This is a very nice, full flavored stout with lots of bitter chocolate and coffee notes, some dark grains and a bit of sweetness with molasses and burnt caramel. The finish has some ash and a bit of coffee bean bitterness. I forgot how much I enjoyed this beer.
Nice full bodied stout. Big choco and coffee also bit of spice. Nice stout, checks the boxes but nothing Too special-- rated with beerbasher/winphone
Black pour, big brown head. Roasty, cocoa sweet aroma, flavor is also roasty and strongly of cocoa. Fantastic mouthfeel: creamy, smooth and full. Excellent.
Nitro draft. Black. Creamy beige nitro head. Nitro creamy. Lighter medium body. Light roast. Cocoa. Licorice. Smooth Mild dry. Pretty clean. Too quiet. Speak up a little!

Aroma and taste were too sour for my taste, though it may be what you'd expect for a beer called Obsidian.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Solid stout with a very full body and a subtle undertone of espresso and really dark chocolate. Very smooth and delicious.

Bottle from Systembolaget. Roasted to burnt malt nose. Coffee, dark, red fruit and alcohol. Medium body. A bit oily. Soft carbonation. Sweet. Bitter ending. Roasted malt, some milk, smoke, hint of chocolate and caramel flavour. A bit to roasted flavour without a body to back it up, but quite good nonetheless.
Poured black with a foamy, tan head. Aroma is cocoa. Taste is chocolate with a little bit of orange rind on the sides of the tongue. Great stout.

Pours black with a tan head. Roasted coffee malt aroma with vanilla bean and cocoa. Flavor is Roasted malt start with black coffee with cocoa and vanilla finishing with dark roasted coffee bitterness.

Deep brown to black color, light brown head. Coffee nose, milk chocolate, roasted malt, brown sugar. Licorice taste, roasted malt, sweet, coffee, dark chocolate, dry finish. Medium body, soft carbonation.
Dark brown stout with dark brown head. Roasty dark espresso stout aroma. Flavors of light molasses booze and some black coffee. Semi sweet finish. Very nice stout.

Typical black body with a fine thick beige head. Good lacing. Dark malt, espresso and some chocolate. Medium + body. Nice balance between sweetness and bitterness. Creamy texture. Lovely complex and tasty flavor. WoW! Dark malt, espresso, toffee, mild roasted and some chocolate. Oh yeah. Spot on![Bottle from a trade with RickFifty]

Pours a dark black with some ruby and a medium khaki head. The aroma is dark roasted malts, burnt caramel, sweet, and slight alcohol. The taste is very strong and full flavored. There is some bitterness and dark fruit, as well as, pine.

12 oz bottle. BB 03/02/15. From saveur-biere.com.
Pitch black colour with a small tan head. 
Sweet roasted malt, vanilla, liquorice, coffee and 
Roasted malt, coffee, mild hops, liquorice, some caramel sweetness and some bitterness in the aroma. A bit thin. But tasty.

Black body, brown head. Aroma has sweet roasted malts, liqourice, some ash, robust and midicinal hoppiness. Light sweet sugary coffee. This at first and the comes quite intense roasted notes. Liqourice and alcohol in finish. Thin and turns bit watery, which is strange.

08.26.14. Best by date.
Poured from a 12 oz bottle into a tumbler on 04.06.14.

A: Completely opaque black. 1/2 finger head.

S: Cocoa, chocolate, roasty malt. Some sweetness too.

T: Roasty malt, chocolate.

M: Creamy smooth.

O: I poured some of this over ice cream and it was very good. On its own, this did not have any weird hop bitterness, which I canÂ’t stand in a stout. The roasted malt kept the sweetness in check.

12 oz. bottle from BevMo. Aptly named as it pours absolutely jet black with a finger and a half high dark tan head that dies quickly. Nose of roasted malts with some espresso and dark chocolate.Taste of dark, bitter roasted malt underlying the coffee flavors and semi-sweet dark chocolate playing nicely together without any of them dominating. Finishes dry. Nice carbonation helps to moderate. Flavors are nicely complex, rich and smooth. An excellent stout.

A very nice chocolately and smokey stout. A nice dry coffee finish. Outs deep brown in color with a thick tan h ad. Had au cheval 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Best by 5/13/15. Opened with huge hiss, good sign, bottle conditioning in full effect. Black as black. Smells like cocoa, coffee, and some faint sweet malt. Tastes more of the same and quite smooth. Nice drinkable black beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Color negro con reflejos rojizos y espuma beige duradera. Aromas de regaliz, maltas tostadas, caramelo y leves frutos rojos. Cuerpo medio, inicio ligeramente dulce de melaza con final tostado moderadamente seco.

Subtle Coffee aroma, hints of bread and chocolate. Well defined roast hits both the nose and tongue. Deathly black with that wonderful froth. The combination of malt and hop hit the nail on the head here. Well balanced and only a slight hint of the alcohol in the aftertaste. In the mouth I am getting the feeling that I chose a good one for my first stout. I am satisfied.

Opaque black, sludge like appearance. No head. Absolutely remarkable chocolate milk, roast, and vanilla aroma. Texture is surprisingly thin on the palate. Smooth and creamy. Initial taste is dark chocolate and roast, and the finish consists of a wonderful combination of sweet vanilla, milk chocolate, roast, and mildly bitter hop. Gustatory bliss.

Poured an opaque black with a very fine mahogany edge tint and a one-finger dark tan foamy head that retained very well leaving a thin head for the entire drink. Laced OK. Carbonation medium. Aroma of sweet malt, dark chocolate, coffee and a hint of dark fruits. Taste first up dominated by roasted malt plus sweet chocolate and with a light to moderate bitterness. Medium body. Creamy smooth, dry and with a long lingering roast malt bitterness. Very nice!
33cl bottle from saveur-biere.com. Dark brown, red color with thin to medium brown head. Smooth body. Taste is light to medium bitter, light sweet. Aroma is coffee, chocolate, roasted.
Opaque brown, small off-white head. A bitter roasted coffee aroma and taste to go along with the DeschuteÂ’s hop profile.

It will not be the last time I have this stout, what a black bewtie with a good sized head which lasted well, earthy aroma, long lasting flavours of chocolate and coffee along with roasted malts, bitter full bodied stout, slick, excellent.

Robe noire, mousse fine et peu persistante. Nez fruitÃ©, torrÃ©fiÃ©, notes dÂ’alcool. EntrÃ©e de bouche douce, forte note de malt grillÃ©, trÃ¨s bon Ã©quilibre. Fin de bouche onctueuse et persistante. On ne demande quÂ’Ã  en reprendre une gorgÃ©e.

UPDATED: AUG 30, 2015 From bottle, 2013 Class of ?88. Black pour with thick tan head and lots of thick lacing. Aroma is espresso and roasted malts. Taste is expresso, nicely bitter with a very slight sweetness behind. Medium mouthfeel, no more. Bitter finish. This has been my stocked stout for years. Always good. Better after a year or so.

Nice roasty aroma, with hints of coffee and chocolate. Pours an opaque black with a thin tan head. Slick mouthfeel with a strong roasted flavor, and a slightly slick mouthfeel. The beer fades into a slightly bitter, roasted finish. A very nice stout to spend some time with.
Very Thick tan head. Yeast and malt smell. Roasted coffee flavor a top a medium body. Black as night with little carbonation. Smooth throughout.

I canÂ’t believe this is my first time trying this beer. It pours a very dark brown color with a beautiful tan head of creamy foam. The aroma is classic with hard roasted coffee, dark chocolate, hints of graham cracker and tobacco ash. The flavor is really nice with more hard roasted grains, hints of ash and black licorice. Dark chocolate. It has a very bitter, roasted finish. ItÂ’s pretty viscous and creamy on the palate as well. Hints of caramel and sasparilla add some complexity as it warms. This is a top notch stout as the ratings seem to agree. I guess IÂ’ve been missing out all these years.
Beer 600 on draft. Black with a one finger creamy head. Coffee bean aroma. Taste is similar with some bitter chocolate. Very smooth stout.
A good and creamy stout. Nitro at Black Friday Blackout. Really smooth taste going down.
Bottle. Pours dark brown with tan head and nice lacing. Nose is chocolate and a little coffee. Maybe some dark fruit. Taste adds some roast. Bitter aftertaste. Nice stout.
Really good. I also like it is a little lower abv. Nice roastedness, chocolate, coffee and sweetness.

Bottle, opaque black, mocha colored head, good lacing. Aroma is roasted barley and raisin, cherry. Flavor is chocolate, cherry, coffee, roasted barley. Palate is a little light, but carbonation is good. Finish is dry.
Julie says nice Carmel malt a little bitter in the back end. Overall she gives it a 3.2
Draught at Arcadium. Light creamy bittersweet chocolate stout that is very easy drinking and full of flavor.

Pint on tap at Cock & Bull in Hyde Park. Black color. Good layer of khaki head. Cool ascending-nitro body. Good sheets of lace. Medium body. Smooth, creamy, lighter carbonation. Light slick. Good coffee, dark roast. Some dark chocolate. Earthy hop. Moderate bitter taste, moderate sweet. Great, super-easy drinking flavorful stout.

Aroma is typical Premium American Stout, coffee, deeply roasted malts, slightly beery. Pours nearly black brown, nice frothy dark coffee and cream head. Flavor is rich and dry... strong coffee, lighter chocolate, dark roastiness. In spite these strong and rich flavors, it is not overly heavy and actually has some of that refreshing quality. This is an exceptional stout without crossing into the Imperial range.

From the 12 fl oz bottle dated 03/17/15. Deep dark black pour with tan head and a lot of lacing. The aroma boasts notes of dark malts, chocolate and sweet malts. Medium body. The taste also has a wonderful sweet dark malty character. I think if the body was bolder I would have rated it higher.

September 25, 2014. Bottle at SBWF. Pours black with a small creamy brown head. Aroma is coffee, dark chocolate, ash. Taste is bitter dark chocolate, light sweet caramel notes. Finish is dry bitter roasted coffee and ash. Medium bodied and average carbonation.
Pours black with a big tan head. Aroma of roasted malts, coffee and clean hops. Taste is the same with a nice clean finish. Nice.
On tap at HarryÂ’s Hofbrau. Slight cocoa and moderate low roast transitions to a moderate, dry bittersweet finish. Medium thin mouthfeel. Roast picks up as it warms.
Overall: Malt, chocolate. Porterish.Note: Bottle 355 ml at Bishops Arms. Reviewed 2014-10-11.
Poured from nitro tap. Black with creamy beige head. Strong roast malt and dark coffee with very subtle chocolate notes. Mild sweet finish. Milky texture, sweet burnt finish.

Bottle. Midnight black pour with a tall foamy dark-tan head. Aroma is roasted malt, bitter chocolate, some wood / earth notes. Taste has lots of chocolate, some coffee, roasted malt. Nice heavy body. Very nice stout.

12 Oz. Bottle poured into a frosty mug. Pours like 40 weight oil with a nice thick, dark head. Smells of coffee and licorice. Nice sweet flavor that has a nice lingering aftertaste. Found this 6 pack of 12 Oz. bottles and a local market. IÂ’m going back for more.
Sample at SBWF 2014. Hoppy and fruity smell with dark malts, chocolate and some coffee. Similar taste. Nice and malty, flavourfull beer.

Bottle @ weekly tasting shared by Joes. Opaque pitch black color, medium sized brown head that lasts for a decent while. Aroma is malts, lightly roasty, raisins, lightly earthy, lightly ash. Taste malts, lightly roasty, a hint of coffee, pretty bitter, a touch of liquorice. Decent body, decent carbonation. Pretty damn good!
Bottle @benzai shared by Joes. Pitch black colour with a medium sized brown head. Smells coffee, sweet, roasty. Tastes sweet, roasty, chocolate, coffee. Medium body, soft carbo.

Bouteille 33cl, DLUO lÃ©gÃ©rement dÃ©passÃ©e (25.08.14), dÃ©gustÃ©e dans un teku. LÃ©ger col de mousse beige, carbonation moyenne. Nez: caramel/sucre cÃ©rÃ©ales rÃ´ties, cafÃ©, rÃ©glise. Idem en bouche, bcp de corps, excellente plÃ©nitude, amertume moyenne et astringeante. mÂ’Ã©voque le royal porter de chez nomada en moins chaud/alcoolisÃ©. bon breuvage.

12 oz. bottle viscously poured to a Czech-pils glass, showing a black/brown hue with enough clarity to show the rush of bubbly effervescence from the base, a billowy, brownish tan head that gradually formed a creamy, mousse-like hat, and thick, ribbons & spots of clingy lacing. The nose was roasted, malty, with cocoa, a bit of coffee, and light woodiness. Medium bodied, the taste contributed a medium hop bitterness that was earthy, dry, and included some lingering charred & tannic astringency. Carbonation was okay, but expended a good deal of itÂ’s liveliness on the opening act. A solid, flavorful Stout, nonetheless.
One of the prettiest pours I?ve had, black with a luxurious head like mousse. Dark roasted coffee and cocoa in a surprisingly light body. Could be more complex. A better version of Guiness.

Bottle on 9/18/14. Pours pitch black. Nice, tight, silky light tan head. Nose is faint dark roasted malts, dark chocolate but not much else. Taste bitter dark chocolate, dark malt, a dash metallic, burnt wood at the end. Not noticeably sweet. Some sweetness would be nice to balance out the burnt and bitter taste IÂ’m left with. Thin mouthfeel, dry. Maybe its the bottle I got but this seems pretty middle of the road to me. Was looking for more.

Bottle: IÂ’d say the name is accurate... Obsidian, charcoal colored body with a soft, velvety mocha head that grows nice & large before slowly trending downward leaving lots of splotchy, sticky lacing behind. Lovely balance of roast & sweetness on the nose. Slightly milky, bittersweet cocoa nibs, burnt caramel, a hint of roasted barley, light brown sugar, & I get a moderately sweet cookie dough aspect that I love. More of a roast punch on the flavor; roasted malt, faint char, blackened coffee beans, adding a touch of bitterness but never losing the sweet, tame undercoat. Dark chocolate, a touch of faint milkiness, burnt brown sugar in small amounts. A tiny bit of anise lingering in the finish with a big aftertaste of slight smoke, roasted malts, & dark chocolate covered coffee beans. I would like a little thicker of a mouth feel, but it still has a decent amount of creaminess. Overall, a very nice stout to have around the house.

Pours black with a thick tan head that holds. Bitter cocoa and espresso aroma, with some molasses and stonefruity notes. Very smooth and creamy mouthfeel. Feels like silk down the throat. A little smokey flavours to compliment the well-balanced coffee and chocolate bitterness and raisin sweetness. Very difficult to fault
Bottle. Black. Nice soft roasty coffee, dark chocolate on nose. Soft body, roasty, slight ashy. Dry bitter. Very flavourful nice.-- bb

nose: oh my, this is heavenly. brownies, espresso, dates, figs, licorice. like a refined version of old rasputin

palate: ...and the fat lady gagged! well, not quite, but this is very roasty, very hoppy, very bitter. think starbucks espresso with pacific nw hops profile. thereÂ’s fig and date sweetness underneath, and nuance once you get past the heavy roast but it requires a bit of mental acrobatics to ignore the slamming smoky and herbal bitterness that grabs your throat. finish is like root beer and cigar and heavily oaked wine [iÂ’m thinking syrah]. still, itÂ’s worth exploring the corners of flavor this offers.

Bottle from Five Bar. Pours black with a small, firm tan head. Nose is very coffee forward with mild dark fruits and brown sugar. Taste is dark fruits engulfed in espresso bitterness and fresh coffee. Very brekky stout-like. Has that fullness and coffee focus one would expect in a brekky stout. Kind of like a less sweet Founders BS. Very decent stuff
Bottle at GBBF, 2014. Black pour with a beige head. Roast malt, raisin and dark chocolate aroma. Smoke, dark fruit and chocolate flavour. Easy going stout action. I like this.

Bottle bought at GBBF 2014. Opaque very dark brown to black, tan creamy head. Nose is nice roasted malt, dark chocolate, expresso coffee, creamy body and all nicely balanced. Taste is smooth chocolate, black coffee, roasted malt. Smoothly balanced and in harmony.

Bottle picked up at GBBF. Pours a very dark ruby/browm black with a tan head. Lightly sweet vanilla milk chocolate aroma (reminds me of sam smith choc organic). Light to medium body, Light bitter coffee, light dark chocolate, a touch of citrus hops initially then you get a ton of it - lemon, pine, grass and choccy lime. Smooth initially though. A decent beer, lots of citrus hops for a stout. A bit messy.
Like a Russian Imperial Stout, but more mellow..........................................

Pours a dirty brown with copperish tinges on the outside of the glass. Aromas toasty, cooking, with some sweet smell IÂ’m unable to discern. Moderately carbed, it has flavours of choc, raisins and a brown sugar hint. Hops are more obvious than in traditional stout.
I love the robust espresso character, the thick and fluffy palate and the pitch black color and tan head. This is a true stout. Pretty good flavor. And respectable ABV for the breed. Nice.

A new world stout, with lots of alcohol and a noticeable hop presence. I love the dirty brown head. There are raisins, coffee, liquorice and toast in the aroma and those grapefruit and alcohol flavours give it a real kick. Very pleasant.

Bottle in a hotel room in Las Vegas. Black pour, thick tan head. Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate, molasses, licorice, caramel and somewhat creamy. Flavor is quite smooth roasted malts, slightly bitter, slightly sweet caramel and a bit thin bodied. Well balanced.
Bottle - pours black with big foamy tan head. Chocolate,roast malt, coffee and some treacly sweetness. Sweet upfront before a big roast bitter coffee kick. Long dry bitter finish. Creamy mouthfeel.

12 oz. bottle pours an opaque dark brown/black with full mocha head and good lacing. Aroma has chocolate, coffee, and roasted malts. Taste is sweet with a hint of smokiness and some bitterness in the finish. Body is only medium, with light carbonation. A well-crafted if somewhat thin stout IÂ’ve tried on a couple of occasions.

bottled march 2014. choc, coffee, roasty, aromaÂ’s check. colour of a black hole, light bronze head. lasting long but thin. sweetness high, low bitters. low hits of salt. low carbonation, oily thin texture. Maybe the beer is too young and needs to devlope more. IÂ’m willing to buy another and give it a second go in a year.

Bottle. Pure black, thick mocha head and strong lacing. Dark chocolate, espresso and roasted malt aromas. Similar flavours of dark chocolate, espresso and roasted malt, made more complex with just a lick of smoke and and underlying savouriness. Spicy hops and a long, bitter finish, coupled with a smooth, perfectly carbonated mouthfeel make this a highly drinkable, fantastic stout.

Pours very dark brown with large brown head out if bottle. Aroma of cocoa beans, vanilla, and bread. Flavor of light cocoa with vanilla finish. Excellent beer.

Bottle from Saveur-Biere.com - Color: opaque black beer with small carbonation and medium brown head. Smell: oat domination with black bread, coffee and caramel notes. Taste: nice balance of malt with bread notes and oat. Aftertaste: smoothy sensation, creamy coffee taste, caramel ! Nice finish. Impressive sensation on mouth! Good work!

23/VI/14 - 12Fl. Oz. bottle @ home - BB: I/13/14 (2014-661) Thanks to PriorL for sharing the bottle!
Clear dark brown to black beer, irregular beige head, bit stable, non adhesive. Aroma: roasted, mocha, caramel, some coffee, chocolate, chlorine. MF: ok carbon, medium body, creamy texture. Taste: caramel, mocha, some coffee, little bitter, bit sourish. Aftertaste: dark chocolate, mocha, bit of caramel, bitter hops, roasted finish.

UPDATED: AUG 7, 2014 Pours a dark Red almost black amber with nice creamy Head. Aroma Is mild chocolate and roasted malt.  Taste is dark chocolate. Upfront with. Some dark cherries. And mild coffee. Nice stout. Leaving malt rings all the way down the glass.

355ml bottle. Near black colored beer, dark brown head. Roasted malts, espresso and licorice in aroma. Flavor has dark chocolate, roasted malt, licorice. Dry finish. Long finish. Decent above average stout, tasty.-- rated with beerbasher/winphone

On nitro at Stouts. Dark black pour with a thick and creamy tan head. Malty chocolate goodness in the nose. Starts a touch sweet, then coffee, bitter chocolate and just a touch of hop bitterness in the finish. Excellent.

Bottle. Black pour with a nice mocha head. Aroma is chocolate, coffee, some roasty malt and a touch of dark fruit. Flavour is espresso and dark chocolate with some more roasty malt, bitter at first but sweetening as it warms. Fairly full-bodied for a stout. One of the best regular stouts, in my opinion - very nice.

Smells of chocolate, roasted malt. Pours black with a tan head. Tastes bold, slightly bitter, not sweet, roasted malt. Heavy body, moderate carbonation dry finish. 

A good solid stout, however a little more one dimensional than I would have thought, but is nails the profile on that dimension. Being a higher than normal ABV, I would expect a few more bright notes, but the malt is the most prevalent feature about the beer.
Bottle. Pours black in color with a tan head. Bitter chocolate, espresso and more roasted notes in aroma. Nice. Dark chocolate, coffee and light spicy sweetness in taste. Quite smooth as well.

355ml bottle. Jet black colour with average, creamy, fairly lasting, minimally lacing, tan head. Roasty, dark malty aroma, slightly salty, herbal, tart-ish. Taste is dry, roasty dark malty, notes of espresso, high-percentage dark chocolate, very subtle dark malty sweetness, herbal and minimally bitter hoppy overtones, a salty touch. Bone dry, clean, intense dark chocolately.

Bottle at TimÂ’s place. Thx for sharing todayÂ’s beers! 
APPEARANCE: black beer, small stable beige head.
NOSE: caramel, sweet, liquorice.
TASTE: chocolate, coffee, caramel, vanilla, long lasting taste, though little watery, nice though!

Black bodied and small stable head. Nutty, roasted and dark chocolate malts. Very nice hop backup to really bring out the full malt character, funnily. Very clean yeast, very appealing. Really stunning beer without being over the top ever. Perfection. (Bottle from Saveur BiÃ¨re),

A colablack beer with a dense and light brown head. The nose has roastiness, black coffee, nice chocolate, some sourness of milk. Taste is roasted, coffee, some chalk and liquirice. Succesfully sweetness thus the taste is not totally dry. Medium bodied, quite smooth to drink. Succesfully stout with strong flavours. Good beer.

355ml bottle from Saveur Biere


Deep black colour with a large brown/beige head. Very nice aroma of roasted coffee. Good flavour of chocolate, coffee and some toastiness. Good basic stout.

12 oz bottle, best by 10/13/14. Pours dark brown black with a huge creamy light brown head that retains well and leaves some lacing.

The aroma is dry chalky roast chocolate malts and some grains with a little coffee.

The flavor is burnt roast bitter chocolate malts with some coffee and a little sweetness and a fairly bitter finish. The mouthfeel is medium to full bodied with low carbonation and a little watery.

Overall, some sweet chocolate and heavily roasted / burnt chocolate malts with a little coffee and a bitter burnt finish. A little too burnt for me.

I was surprised 12 oz bottle from Country Club Liqours. Nose is dark bitter chocolate with some roast nuttiness. Black with a medium lightly lacing tan head. Flavor is lightly bitter with chocolate and a very nice body and mouth feel. Very nice drinkable regular stout at a decent price.

Bottle.

A- Black color, black liquid, brown head.

T- Coffee, cocoa, roasty, malty, slightly bitter.

P- Medium body, slightly thin texture, average carbonation, roasty finish.

O- This one was good but by the end, it just didnÂ’t quite leave me wanting another. The aroma was very rich but the taste didnÂ’t quite fulfill the promise that the nose brought. Now, there certainly arenÂ’t any complaints for this one, but just nothing wowza about it.
Tap. Dark pour with a finger of mocha head. Wow. Milk coffee, raisin, roast. Smooth. Silky body with a great balance of bitterness and milky sweetness. Very nice

5 oz draft from the brewery. Very nice aroma of expresso and cocoa. Medium bodied. Creamy texture. Very good stout.

great color and beige creamy head. woody taste with a smoky charcoal on the back end, good stout especially for a session beer

Draught (Nitro) @ Deschutes, Portland, OR 

Pours pitch black with a smooth brown head. Aroma of smooth roastiness, cocoa, chocolate and coffee. Taste is slick, smooth, chocolaty and oily with some coffee and cocoa notes. Finish is slick smooth and roasty. Nice.

bottle pour..black color slight mocha head..nose is excellent with notes of chocolate, espresso..dark roasted malt..mouthfeel is pretty tasty with medium body action..slight bitterness on linger..a pretty tasty stout that has got everything in check..a solid stout that feels more substantial in both taste and character than the 6%..

Very persistent and solid mineral colored head over nearly opaque mahogany body. Aroma of toasted biscuit and roasted cocoa and sophisticated and delicate like a French chef took a shot at making cocoa puffs. Mmmm. Taste is bitter on the order of coffee or dark chocolate. Body is disappointingly thin. But the board said only 5% whereas itÂ’s listed at 6.5%, here. ItÂ’s a solid beer but IÂ’m not getting the ultra.

12 oz Bottle. Tasted on 5/26/14. Bottle from Total Wine & More. The aroma has chocolate, espresso, roasted malt. The taste has similar profile with a rich smooth flavor & a clean finish. Mostly chocolate & more dry than sweet on the finish. Overall a very good stout.

12 oz bottle. Thanks Jason! The pour is a nice dark black and a touch of ruby around the edge with a medium dark khaki head and some light lacing. The aroma is big and full. There is a nice roasty maltiness to go along with great chocolate and coffee aromas. This definitely doesn't smell like a normal stout. The flavor is nice and roasty. There is a great chocolate and coffee presence, and it's just a very solid beer. The mouth feel is thick and viscous. Nice and creamy with good coating and a great carbonation. The aftertaste is lingering and roasty. This is a great stout!

Deschutes donÂ’t play. I have never had a bad beer from them. They definitely have great quality control. This one is another classic, it doesnÂ’t stun the shit out of me but it delivers on itÂ’s simple promise. Bliggity blacker than a Chris Rock special but not enough head to get Bill Clinton in trouble. A stink-boom of chocolate, vanilla, coffee and burnt bread. Taste is that too with enough hops sting to hold the fort down. Nothing wrong here.

Pours black with tan head and lots of lacing. Aroma of sweet dark malts, a little roasted coffee and cocoa. Taste is bitter sweet like dark chocolate with roasted coffee. Lingering dark chocolate after a sip. Heavy bodied and moderately creamy.

355 ml bottle. Pours black with a small tan head. Aroma is sweet with roasted malt, coffee and chocolate. Flavour is sweet with roasted malt, chocolate a hint of licorice and a dry, bitter coffee finish.

Nice deep rich taste tastes lightly bitter taste but refreshing on the palate. Would pair well with pizza.
