At my place with Taylor on a Friday night while trying to figure out what to do. Pours is black with huge grey cream head the drops to a film. Aroma is roasted malt that is on the leathery side, paper, slight stout tang. Taste is big stout tang, leather cardboard, roasted malt. Finish is kinda quick, and all of the bad flavors go away.

Bottle @ home from WholeFoods SF
Pours opaque blackish brown, modest beige head. Smells like iced espresso, cacao not chocolate. Bit sweetish, light sour.
Very straight stout, balanced, crÃ¨me caramel, hint of rye, dry finish.
Not heavy, as souts can be.
On tap at JL Beers in Grand Forks, North Dakota. Creamy head, dark rich, coffee with a hint of chocolate.

Courtesy of umich03jm
Bottle: The aroma consists of moderate-heavy dark chocolate, lighter espresso, roasted malt, light anise, burnt notes, and a hint of smoke. It pours a dark brown, virtually black, with a large creamy tan head that has great retention. There is a lot of thin webbing left on the sides of the glass. I rarely give 5Â’s for appearance, but this beer probably deserves one. The flavor starts with a quick dose of dark chocolate with a hint of dark fruit. The finish has moderate black coffee, burnt notes, roasted malt, light anise, and pine. ItÂ’s medium bodied with mild carbonation and a somewhat soft mouthfeel.

12fl oz BB 06/08/14
Pours a near-opaque black beer with a thick creamy persistent espresso-like head.
Moderately intense nose; bitter chocolate, licorice, burnt nutiness, roast grain, with a good whack of hop citrus and resiny spice.
Full bodied, nice chewy maltiness, restrained carbonation.
Nice smooth, lengthy palate, packed full of roasted malts, dark chocolate, nuts, rich toffee and spicy citrus hops. Finishes with a decent bitterness, roast character lingers.
Very nice, class act really.

nitro at brewpub. black with puffy cream head that clings to glass like nitro. Light oatmeal and roast nose. Front is sweet, faintly lactic before roast dominates in singular mid before metallic finish, thin and drawn from the nitro, spent grains in the frothy body as fullness surrounds.

From 341 ml bottle. Pours an opaque black with a large brown head that collapses to a thin cap. Good lacing on the glass. Aromas of rich stewed and dried fruits (raisins, prunes, stewed apple, fruit mince) with hints of cocoa, black coffee and smoke. Taste is roasted malt with more dark fruit up front. ThereÂ’s then a light coffee bitterness that dissolves into tobacco, cocoa powder and cinnamon. Not as full bodied as the colour might suggest but still an excellent easy drinking stout.

This is a great stout that justifies its higher gravity by packing in more flavor. ItÂ’s a nice looking beer too, deep black in color with a ring of had that lasts the duration and big ropes of lace on the side of the glass. This has a nice coffee aroma especially when first poured with an underpinning of died plums. It has a nice creamy texture and mild carbonation that help bring out some chocolate note without the beer being cloying or heavy and finishes with a lingering cocoa bitterness. This is very definitely one of the better American stouts out there.
Dark black. Smells like coffee. Roasted coffee flavor. Thin lacing. Nice stout. On tap in Portland.

Tan head, black and brown color. Aroma is licorice, roasted coffee. Taste is all coffee, bitter espresso, heavily roasted malt. Some pine hop bitterness in the finish. Nice mouthfeel- creamy. Very dry- needs some sweetness for balance.

Not bad. A very subtle aftertaste, will eventually buy again, but not anytime soon. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Cap leapt off with gusto and a fresh roasted coffee bean aroma filled the air. On a closer whiff there is more coffee; bitter and heavy roasted, a touch of charred wood, liquorice root, topsoil, heated tyre rubber - all in quite pleasant and sound. Appearance is impressive. A messy plumage of tannish foam holds steady atop a midnight brown body - opaque in the depths. Unexpectedly lean on the palate. Malty bitter with a touch of cola tanginess. Long, roasted malt, coffee bean and burnt wood finish. Not much melding on the palate, but it is dark malt dominated. Pleasant drinking but a little weaker than IÂ’d anticipated. Quaffable, besides its ABV. (12fl.Oz, BB 06/08/14, The Liquor Shed, Jandakot)
Aroma of dark chocolate and espresso, rich brown color with a creamy head. Taste of espresso with a hint of dark chocolate. Slightly bitter palate.
Coffee, chocolate taste dark, earthy, smoke taste. A drinkable stout not super heavy.
bottle. thick black with one finger head. very big roasty stout. bitter chocolate, coffee and just a hint of anise. really smooth mouthfeel.

From a bottle. Aroma is of coffee and chocolate. Color is definitely obsidian with a small brown head. A fairly strong coffee bitterness upfront with a sweet chocolate, malty finish. Medium carbonation and a full body.

Pours black with a medium sized bubbly tan head. The aroma is big on espresso with a healthy balance of chocolate. Roasted malts and licorice are present as well. The taste has some sweetness in it to go along with some bitterness. Flavors of espresso and to a lesser extant chocolate remain strong. Long aftertaste of espresso. Medium bodied, with a thicker texture, with softer carbonation. This one doesnÂ’t do anything to crazy. Its just very solid.

Reviewed from notes.
The appearance had a dark brown/close to black colored body with a two finger off-white/tan foamy head that rises a bit and then drops gently leaving some thick spider web lacing gracing the sides of the glass.
The smell has a smokey, woody, espresso, and roasty combined fantastically.
The taste took all of those previously mentioned aromas entering a sort of sweetness from some light chocolate and some light vanilla, dry espresso aftertaste, dry sticky finish.
On the palate, she sat about a medium, semi-sessionable, carbonation is done very well for its style and for me, becomes slightly creamy.
Overall, I would definitely have this one again.
Nitro. Creamier mouthfeel, lots of caramel malts and cocoa, not super roasty or hoppy in this serving type.

UPDATED: JAN 26, 2016 On nitro, poured into a shaker. Being on nitro, the aroma was mostly muted, but what did come through was a tobacco hint, an espresso note, and a slight grass aroma. Of course, aided by the nitro, this pours a beautiful black body with a very soft velvet, marshmallow head - tan in color - which sticks around forever and leaves a heavy spray of lace all over the empty glass. The taste is a nice blend of medium light sweet and medium light bitter with flavors of espresso, grass, some ash-like quality, toasted grain, nuts, and chocolate milk. ItÂ’s a pretty slcik texture with a medium full body and an unnoticed / impossibly smooth carbonation. As it mellows out, some caramel starts to show up, along with a note of pine, at the finish, but itÂ’s mostly espresso.which sticks around in the aftertaste with notes of cherry and dark chocolate.
Black with a thin tan head. Aroma is roast and coffee. Flavor is coffee, roast, nutty, and chocolate. medium carbonation with a creamy mouthfeel.
I had this on nitro tap. Dark black brown blocks out light. Big creamy head. Nutty smoothness in the scent. Creamy head floats on a chocolate coffee nuttiness, perfect beer for nitro.
Tap, black with a khaki head. Definitely notice the chocolate and coffee notes. Slight bitter aftertaste. Excellent stout.
Black pour with tan head. Aroma is dark berries, chocolate. Flavour brings out smooth roasted malt flavours followed by a light citrus bitterness. Really tasty.

Pours a dark black with a sliver of highlight at the edge. A big khaki head that settles to a dollop and then a film and leaves excellent lacing. Aroma is a bit subdued, maybe because I have a cold, but still detect roasted malt, chocolate and some caramel sweetness. Taste had some sweetness at first and some underlying fruitiness which was a bit surprising but enjoyable. You get the dark chocolate and smooth roasted flavor combining and then transitioning into a coffee with light cream. Finishes with a little sweetness and lingering coffee and bitterness. Mouthfeel flirts at being both soft and creamy with a medium body and medium/high carbonation. Good stout that has more sweetness than some but not too much. Has a smooth bitterness and overall smooth character to the flavors. Nothing overpowers but blends nicely and tastes bigger than it is. If it has any fault itÂ’s that may be over carbonated. IÂ’d drink again.
On tap at ling and Louis dfw Airport. Large black body and frothy tan head. Creamy expresso and roasted malt nose. Medium light body.

This was one of the best beers I have had in a long time, guam doesn't know about beers and they imported this gem.

Bottle, cellared 1.5 years.
Big, creamy, fluffy, thick deep brown head. Very dark beer. Smell is crisp, clean, vanilla, chocolate.
Very soft and silky mouthfeel. Nothing overly going on at all. Cellaring really took all the sharp edges off. Soy, umami, chocolate, doughy, marshmallows.
Gets some smoke as it warms up. Not bad but prob not worth cellaring.

From notes, consumed on 6/21/13. Bottle poured into a tulip pint glass. Pours black with two fingers of tan head that fades slowly. Aromas of coffee, chocolate, vanilla, caramel. Tasting notes of bitter coffee, chocolate, caramel. Medium-light body with a semi-dry finish.
On nitro at World of Beer. Looks fantastic, mouthfeel isn't as creamy as I thought it'd be. Also was hoping for more espresso. Maybe it's the nitro? Not sure.

Pours a nice consistent dark stout color. Thick tan head with a creamy consistency. Good aroma and flavor.

355ml bottle. Pours an opaque black, with a moderate beige head, which lasts fairly well and leaves very good lacing. Milk chocolate, bittersweet espresso, a little cocoa and an alluring sweet spice scent make up the aroma. Mild herbal hops and sweet spice up front give way to roasty malt and espresso in the mid-palate. Bittersweet dark chocolate appears in the finish. This is a really enjoyable stout, with its sweet spice flavour giving it a bit of a point of difference. Plus, itÂ’s not too expensive either.
A black beer with a small tan head. The aroma is coffee, chocolate, and lactose. The flavor is the same.
Coffee, chocolates, Nitro?, nice dry finish. Very Guinness like. Good choice for a sipper or with red meat.
Coffee mostly at the beginning, with a little chocolate as well, then fades into resin hops with lots of hop bitterness at the end. Interesting beer, pretty good.
Great stout, and fairly cheap too. Coffee and chocolate, with a bit of malty sweetness.

Black with frothy tan head. Decent lacing. Roast, chocolate, caramel, and coffee notes. Medium bodied, like aroma, and bitter hop notes. Decent balance and medium bitterness.

Aroma of espresso and roasted coffee and chocolate. AppeArs black with an ample light brown head . Taste is dark fruit, currant and cherry followed by espresso and toasted coffee and chocolate. Great 6 pack stout.

Solid black pour with very thin tan head. Mild roasted coffee and chocolate aroma. Thin palate. Taste is very acidic and bitter to start, then chocolate and bitter dry finish. Not bad but there are better options in HK.
Pours totally black with a black head. Aroma is malt, roastiness, coffee and chocolate. Taste is moderate sweet leading to a roasty finish. Good one.
Solid stout, nice roast and good balance. Not a show stopper but definitely one to look out for.

(Backlog) Dark, black in color with brown tinges. Creamy tan head. Looks good. The smell is roast, dirty, cocoa, dark baking chocolate, and burnt malts. The taste is malts, burnt, roast, cocoa, coffee, and good.

Pours opaque black with a toffee colored head. Nice hoppy aroma with notes of coffee and malt. Goes down smooth with a bitter back end. This goes down easy with chocolate. I like the Black Butte Porter better but this was really good.

This is a local of mine, and for some reason, I canÂ’t even remember what it tastes like. Shame on me!
Best by: 7/25/11

A: Pours a black coffee with a hint more darkness and has only limited translucency. Single finger light latte head dissipates leaving a medium sheet of the same. Spots of lacing.

S: Roasty, oaty, coffee, grains, malts, light earthy hops. Hints of fruity yeast. Somewhat sandy scent. Very nice. Not quite Kalamazoo stout, but very good.

T: Taste matches the nose, very good. Only diff would be that here is a good bittering component I didnÂ’t anticipate. I really like this as a stout. As it warms, it gets better too. Absolutely one of the finer examples IÂ’ve had.

M: Creamy and smooth beer. Mouth velvet. Lower carbonation, long resonance. Again, very nice. Lovely.

D: I think I might make this part of my regular lineup. ItÂ’s just outstanding as a stout. I wonder why theyÂ’ve never made (to my knowledge), an imperial of this one.

Tap. On nitro. Black with thick tan head. Malty aroma. Very smooth. Chocolate creamy flavors, finishes very nice.
Tap at stone brewing, escondido. Black color, brown head. Aroma is roasty, coffee, chocolate. Medium body, coffee, roasted malts, some smoke.
Tap (nitro) at Deschutes, Portland. Colour is black with small brownish white head. Aromas and flavours: Coffee, chocolate and roasted malts. Very soft and creamy.

Dark brown/black color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of toasted malt, chocolate, & coffee; Flavor of roasted malt, dark chocolate, some hops, caramel, and coffee; Nicely balanced; Very nice stout.

A very competent bargain stout; viscous, heavy bitter malts and sharp carbonation, coffee chocolate. Some prominent sweetness as well; no alcohol presence, but makes up with a pleasant body. Really nice six-pack build beer; drinkable and tasty.

Absolute zero light pass-through. Frothy, tan head. Burnt malt and dark coffee aroma. Great palate: medium carbonation, creamy, frothy, only light bitterness. Taste is similar to aroma. Long aftertaste, bitter, coffee. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy

On draft (Nitro) at Toronado SF. Roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, licorice. Silky, creamy mouthfeel with a dry bitter finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Wow... Really impressed with this high rating... Pours a deep dark black brown with a tan head. Some lacing... Rich deep aromas: chocolate malt, coffee, light alcohol, light butterscotch, vanilla, very light licorice. The taste is (nearly) perfectly balanced. Wonderful light velvet mouth feel, soft carbonation, and a lingering bitter finish. Will drink again... IÂ’ll even pay for it!

On nitro at Tap Shack in Newport Beach , CA. 

Opaque, brown-black with a large tan head and excellent lacing. 

Heavenly aroma of chocolate, roasted malt, leather, strawberries, toffee and pleasant citrusy and fruit scents. 

Taste of roasted malt, caramel, chocolate, toffee, coffee, leather, strawberries, toffee and molasses. 

Full/medium body and low carbonization with the smooth mouthfeel of a nitro beer. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Nitro draft @ Hopleaf . Just looking at this beer makes me want to chug it down. Thick full tan head that looks alive after it is poured. Black tar looking color. Smells of roasted charred malts, chocolate, dark fruit and barley. Taste of dark roasted grain hints of plums, dark / bitter chocolate, and traces of coffee dregs. Finish has a large amount of dry roast. The sweetness from the malts with the dry roasted finish works really well together. The Nitro provides a creamy, full bodied mouthfeel. For a standard stout being under the imperial qualification, this is damn good!
Cocoa puff cereal nose. Bakers chocolate. Sweet milk. Quite milky taste. Hint of shoe polish. Creamy and very dry finish.
Pours a tar black color with a tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, espresso, and chocolate. Roasted malt flavor with coffee, licorice, and chocolate. Great beer!
Smak och doft av choklad, espresso, laktris med aningar av lÃ¤der, trÃ¤ och rostade toner. Rund och len med en tydlig bitterchoklad beska.
Very roasty aroma, deep and dark. Toast, roasted malt, coffee, cocoa. A bit of char and some earthy tastes, then a long and smooth finish. Not quite creamy or thick, but still full enough.

Wow. Delicious. Pours out as black as engine oil with a mocha tan head. Aroma is coffee and barley, very potent. The taste is dark roasted coffee and black licorice that melds together very well, but the best part of this beer is the amazing mouth-feel, like heavy cream. IÂ’ll be looking for this again.
from the tap. A nice black with tan head. A very good stout and easy to drink.
Bottle at Monks. Very dark pour. Light tan foam. Expected chocolate/coffee stout flavors with some slight spicy hops for balance. Well mixed stout. Maybe a bit slight though.

Black like coal with the perfect thick tan creamy head. Aroma and taste of bitter roast grains. Coffee, chocolate immediately come to mind. Deserving of itÂ’s score for sure. Another beauty from Deschutes.
Sample from bottle @sbwf13. Pitch black with tan head. Aroma mainly of coffee with bitter chocolate, cacao and some hops. Taste of coffee, acidity, chocolate

On tap. Pours black with a medium mocha head. Aroma is dark roasts, chocolate, and slight sweetness and hoppiness. Taste is much the same. Some decent astringency from the roasts........kind of close to Bells Java Stout.

Pours a deep dark black/brown color with light brown head. Big rich chocolate aroma with a nice balance of roast and dark malt. Flavor of roasty dark malts, some chocolate and coffee....not as smooth at the aroma. Some bitter astringency from roast but overall, pretty tasty.
A big rich & bold stout yet so light & creamy on the mouthfeel. Wow! Complex & unique - has a perfect stout pour. ItÂ’s like oatmeal meets a milk stout & it really works! Well done!

Pitch black, tan head, good retention and lace. Coffee/espresso is the dominant flavor with a touch of bittersweet chocolate and moderate hopping that both add a lot of depth. Pretty dry on the finish, especially considering the abv. Definitely the quintessential american stout.
Black pour at twin anchors in Chicago. Super foamy. Nutty easy chocolate flavor. Good stuff
Nice Smokey flavor and smooth taste. Deep dark color and an aroma that reminds me of the old country. A fine stout
UPDATED: NOV 14, 2014 Pours jet black with a robust tan head. Aroma is amazing chocolate, roasted coffee, and the taste is exactly that, with a creamy smooth mouthfeel. The best stout there is.
Bottle pour of black tarry ink reminiscent of the seaside sign WARNING: Contaminated Water. Good but not great.
UPDATED: OCT 8, 2013 Nitro-Fruit, roast, chocolate, pours a pitch black with a mocha colored creamy head. Smooth creamy, roast coffee, espresso, o so delicious

This beer is opaquely black. YouÂ’d have to hold a flashlight up to it to see any light through it. Aroma is black malt and a bit of fruitiness. Dark chocolate and espresso with malty sweetness and hops to carry it through into a balanced finish. ThereÂ’s an ash-like note in there that is actually good along with the caramel malt sweetness. Big mouthfeel. One of the best American Stouts out there.
This one is a winner! Smooth as silk, no sharp bitter edges. Reaaly nice creamy head, hints of toasted coffee, molasses. This is a beautiful example of everything good about stouts.
From a bottle poured a dark brown color with a small amount of head. Toasted malty flavor with a lingering aftertaste.

12oz bottle. Pours a jet-black color with a two finger dark-tan head with good retention and lacing. Aroma is of grain husk, espresso, wheat, dark bittersweet chocolate, and a subtle hint of alcohol. Taste is of dark molasses, burnt wood, espresso, drying alcohol and a touch of hops. Mouthfeel is fizzy with a medium body.

Bottle thanks to JRob21. Aroma is wonderful with malty nuts, cocoa, and espresso. Pours black with a big thick beige head. Taste is very roasty with notes of coffee grinds, chocolate, iron, and malts. Super rich and roasty. This is a bad ass stout!

Light stopping black pour with a brown head. Aroma is roasted malt, dark fruit, and chocolate. Taste is roasted malt, thick, chocolate, tasty beer. Hooray for showing up in my area(Granville, 1400 population, more livestock than people). Chalky roasted malt finish. Nice lacing. If I finish the 6 pack, I might just go tip a few cows over.
UPDATED: OCT 8, 2013 Bottle. Carbonated front with a mildly bitter cocoa taste. Tastes a little nitro, but the espresso bitterness diminishes the sweetness.
Tap. Near black thick tan head. Aroma is roasted malt, dried fruit, light chocolate and coffee. Flavor is chocolate, roasted malt, light coffee and fruit. Medium bodied.

bottle. The pour is dark with a thick full head. The aroma is very strong sweet malt with hints of dark fruit, and some smoke. The taste is a little thin. The malt comes through in a nice way. Overall a very solid drinking stout.
Bottle at Fenix. Pours black with a medium sized tan head. The aroma is very roasty, has dark chocolate, big coffee. The taste is sweet chocolate and a ton of roasted coffee beans. This is delicious.
Lacing coated glass with sticky foam. Deep barley and roasty oats flavor. Nice coffee notes as well.

Good solid stout. Nice roasted and chocolate aroma. Very dark with brown edges and a light tan foamy head. Medium weight palate with solid carbonation. Roasted malts and coffee with a dry hoppy finish but not too bitter. Some cocoa in the back but not sweet. Fine beer.
January 2012. Sampled at the brewpub in Portland. Black with a beige head. Roasted malt, chochlate, coffee aromas. Bitter hops on the finish.

As advertised in the description. Definitely a top of the line stout above and beyond. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured very dark mocha with a tan head, with nice lacing and good head retention. Overall, loved this, it was exactly what I was looking for. Lots of aroma and flavor, with particularly nice layers of roasted malts, dark chocolate, and fruit. Definitely getting more, and looking into Deschuttes more as a whole; IÂ’m sold.

Bottle. 
chocolate, coffee, roasty, herbs, spruce, earthy, woody, black, hazy, minimal head, brown foam, light sweetness, very bitter, full body, thick feel, creamy, soft carbonation, bitter and long finish,

Bottle 355ml @ Public House -Venetian, Las Vegas, NV
Pours black with a tan head. Aroma has notes of roasted malt, chocolate, oat and hint of floral, ash and alcohol caramel. Taste is medium sweet and light to medium bitter with a long chocolate finish. Body is medium, texture is thin to oily, carbonation is soft.

Bottle. Pours black with a tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, coffee and some fruitiness. Flavor is sweet and roasted with some ash, slight sourness and some berries. Medium body, average carbonation.
Good balanced stout. Coffee, dark chocolate, balanced hops, hint of anise and mint. Light body, medium finish..
Another winner from this brewery. Aroma and flavor are pretty well matched. Toasty, roasted malts, chocolate, some mild bitterness. Medium bodied and a nice finish.
Pours black with mocha head. Smells of roasted malts, chocolate, and dark fruit. Taste is burnt malts, dark fruit and bitter sweet chocolate. Medium thin mouthful. Good stout!
Smooth. Had this on tap at iron barley in St. Louis. Very nice beer pours very dark, and though somewhat roasty is smooth.

On tap at Deschutes in Portland. Pitch black with a never-ending brown head. Light roasty aroma with leather and tobacco notes. Roasty taste, highly bitter. Surprisingly thin, but smooth and creamy all the same. Good stout.

Bottle from Total Wine for RBSH3. Black pour with a tan head. Roasted malt, cocoa powder, and a bit of earthy hops. Coffee, slight toffee sweetness, and a bit of dirt. Flavor is really earthy. Coffee, cocoa powder, and dark chocolate. Light toffee sweetness, some dark fruit, and maybe a hint of ash.
This is good stuff. Aroma is roasty, toasty, malt, and some coffee. Nice solid body thatÂ’s about medium. Taste is rich and delicious. The finish is nice with a good smoothness. Great after dinner!

Appearance was clear jet black with beige creamy lasting 2 finger head , rings of lacing. Aromas are cocoa, coffee, roasted malts hints of cherry and alcohol. Taste was roasted grains, chocolate, hints of coffee, cherry? Palate was soft smooth CO2 with medium-full body, lasting slick roasty cocoa, coffee finish. Wonderful smooth creamy stout.
Jet black colour with a tan head. Fairly big aroma with a chocolate and roast aroma. Similar aroma and very nice tasty beer with a long finish. nice stuff.

Deep black in color... Aroma is roasted barley... Flavor is oats, dark malts, hints of chocolate, minimal bitterness on the finish... Solid

I havenÂ’t seen a better looking beer. The aroma is full of coffee and chocolate. The taste is incredibly smooth with chocolate and coffee as well. Very good.
Very deep and dark pour from a 12oz bottle. All of the great roasty flavors you want from a big stout.
Pitch black pour with fluffy brown head... aroma of fruit and marshmello... taste is bitter espresso... awesome

You can taste the coffee notes. It has more of a hoppy after taste then Guinness. I would place it as a drinkable stout.

Jet black pour with an active tan head. More roast and cigarette. Body is solid but nealy.

Near black pour with toffee head and lace that sticks to the glass a little. Chocolate mint on the nose with medium roast coffee and a solid bit of hoppiness. A little less intense on the palate but that chocolate mint note sticks around.

Jet black with a light tan head, which left a large amount of lacing.
Raisin, plum, burnt toast all one a rich boozy nose.
Bitterness of burnt toast follows into the taste, bitter dark chocolate, stone fruits and a thick brown sugary alcohol note.
The beer finished with an earthy, malt and hop bitterness.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured from a 12 oz. bottle into a tulip.

With the initial pour, Obsidian Stout has a huge, thick, frothy mocha head. It recedes over time but still retains a reasonable cap and leaves some nice lace down the sides. The beer itself is impressively dark with just a little bit of a dark cherry edge.

The aroma is totally full of roasted flavor. Some dark chocolate and smokey tobacco complement the malt nicely, with a small bitter hop presence as well.

Dark roasted malt really dominates the flavor. There are some notes of coffee, smoke, and dark unsweetened chocolate. A citrus hop kick comes in at the end, and there is a modestly bitter aftertaste.

There is a bitter and slightly acidic feel, like a strong cup of coffee. The carbonation is creamy with a little bite and ends up being a little bit on the light side of medium. There is a light acidity toward the end of the sip. 

This is a solid stout all the way around.

Poured from a bottle. Almost black with mocha head. Aroma is chocolate, roast and espresso.  In the taste, the chocolate comes though sweet and mild. There is a bit of hop bitterness in the finish and somewhat dry. Body is smooth, but  slightly on the thin side. Overall, very nice stout.
Pours dark with a thick lingering caramel head. Faint roasted malt smell. Thin mouthfeel and almost bland taste. What taste there is, is good and slightly malty
Bottle. Pours a near black color with a thick tan head on it. Nose is lightly roasty and velvety. Taste is very dark and roasty with some coffee elements to it. Very inviting and pleasant stout.

Pours black with a tight brown head. Aromas of chocolate and coffee, but floral and citrus hop notes do come thru as well. A hint of sweetness at first, but burnt toast and espresso follow. The astringency works fairly well with the bitter hops. Rich, thick mouthfeel.

Type: 12-oz. bottle
Glass: Stone Ruination IPA
From: Bine & Vine Bottle Shop in Normal Heights (San Diego), Calif. 
Price: $1.99
Purchased: June 4, 2013
Consumed: June 11, 2013
Misc.: Best by Aug. 12, 2013

Poured a black tar color with 3-4 fingers of tan and light brown frothy head. Good amount of circular lacing along the sides of the glass. Good retention on the top all the way down.

Smelled chocolate, dark caramel, espresso and roasty malts. Seemed to be stronger than 6.2 percent, more like an RIS. Very good nose and had me looking forward to the taste.

Tasted similar to the nose, only better. Got rich chocolate, fudge, dark caramel, toffee, roasty malts, chocolate milk and chocolate malt. 

Full-to-medium body. Slick texture. Average carbonation. Long, smooth, warming finish.

A fantastic stout. I am only upset that it took this long for me to figure it out.
Coffee roasted aroma; subtle licorice. Roasted malt flavor, balanced with caramel sweetness. A little licorice. Spicy fruity hops; moderate bitterness. Drier coffee-like aftertaste.

Best by 11/26/13 into bowed highball @ 45Â°; black body with 1" medium khaki lasting head, nose is big coffee, dark chocolate, figs with a balancing restrained hop presence, earthy and enjoyable on a creamy ml body, finish follows, standout stout

Bottle pours a deep dark brown to a black hue w/ a big frothy brown head dies down to a nice rocky covering. Moderate aromas of roasty malt, chocolate, coffee, and grassy, herby hops. Initial flavor is a mild sweet to a moderate bitter black coffee finish. Tastes are dark bittersweet chocolate, espresso, peppery hops, and just a hint of sweetness. Medium bodied watery-to-creamy mouthfeel, and a clean dry bitter finish.

12 oz bottle with best by date of 30 Sept. 2013.
Pour is black with only a hint of dark bown at the edges.  Opaque, even in bright light.  Creamy tan head has moderat retention and leaves bands of sticky lacing. 
Aroma: sweet and dark roasted malts
Flavor: Sweet up front, mildly bitter by the finish. Loads of dark roasted grain flavor. With hints of dried plums, dark chocolate, and coffee. Very slight burnt toast component. 
M: Full body; medium carbonation. Approaches 5. 
O: A excellent, robust stout.

12oz bottle in an English pint.  Pours black with a lacy, tan head.  Aroma of roasted and chocolate malts, a little coffee, some doughiness, and light floral hops.  Flavor the same with a nice dark malt character.  Average texture.  A pretty good stout.

On tap at Toronado. Nitro pours a deep black with a tan crisp head. Smooth mouthfeel.

Nice dark chocolate, coffee, burnt aroma. Pitch black with dirty lacy head. Medium body, slightly thin, mildly bitter finish. Good chocolate and coffee flavor. Solid, straight forward stout. Nothing too fancy, but delivers.

Tap (nitro) at Deschutes, Bond St Bend 23/05/13.
Mid black with a good sized tan head.
Nose is a little thin, roast malt, mineral notes, dark toffee, light chocolate.
Taste comprises light roast, touch of choclate, dark toffee, mineral tones.
Medium bodied, fine carbonation, smooth on the palate.
Ok - Other than lend towards a smooth mouthfeel, nitro does little favours to a beer!
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: 12oz bottle into the vase-like 300ml Deschutes glass. Pours a deep dark brown, with just a hint of ruby red around the edges; frothy mocha head dies down to a nice covering. Pleasant aromas of roasty malt, chocolate, coffee, liquorice with grassy, herby hops. Flavours of bitter black coffee, with an edge of dark, bittersweet chocolate, mingling with good bittering hops, and just a hint of sweetness. This bottle is a little too carbonated for my tastes, but good medium bodied mouthfeel, leading to a long, drying bitter finish.

Poured from bottle (best by 9/30/13) into snifter, served at 52 degrees. 

Appearance - dark, dark brown. Thick mocha head has great retention. 

Aroma - dark chocolate, espresso, and roasted barley

Taste - a dry bitterness gives way to a slight dark chocolate sweetness and finishes dry and bitter. 

Mouthfeel - medium body with good carbonation. 

Overall - a world class stout.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12 bottle thanks to Crajun. Amazing aroma of deep dark malt, coffee, cocoa and dark chocolate. Flavor is equally dark and filled with many wonderful accents. I taste sweet chocolate, espresso beans, black licorice, and a mild bitter hop finish. Well put together stout!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Had this on Nitro at St. AugustineÂ’s. Not entirely impressive. Pours jet black with carpet head and lacing. Creamy texture. Aroma has roast malt and a twang of hops. Finishes very light - with only a nutty bitterness and some sourness. Aroma has coffee as well.
UPDATED: JAN 25, 2014 Bottle->Nonic.  Black with thick tan head.  Aroma: chocolate, coffee, roasted malt.  Taste: burnt chocolate, roasted malt.  A little thin, but quality.
On draft at The Holy Grail in Plano, TX.  Taste is black coffee, dark chocolate and cream.  ItsÂ’ twin brother would be a Guinness.  Decent.

UPDATED: NOV 6, 2014 On tap at St AugustineÂ’s on The Drive in Vancouver. Full black with tan head. Overfilled glass allows little nose. Rich chocolate and coffee overtones on the palate. Rich and satisfying. Medium body, oily texture and soft carbonation.
and again Nov 06 2014 at Alibi Room in Vancouver. Impressions are about the same. A great stout.

12 oz bottle poured into a pint glass.  Pours black with a big creamy tan head and nice lacing.  Aroma is roasted malts, chocolate, and coffee.  Taste is roasted malt, chocolate, caramel, and some hop bitterness.
Excellent stout. Balanced. Not too sweet. Black as night. Black as coal....sun being blotted out from the sky.
An all-time favorite. A smooth beer and easy to drink. Classic. Dark with a delightfully rich aftertaste.

12 oz bottle from trade with crajun.  Pours pitch black with a 1 finger head that fades normally, leaves some lacing.  Aroma is dark roasted malt, burnt coffee, dark chocolate, and a little smoke.  Taste is intense but still very easy to drink.  Lots of burnt coffee and bitter dark chocolate.  Smooth finish with lots of roast and a little smoke.  Thin to medium body, creamy mouthfeel.  Really good stout here.  Intense and goes down smooth but would be hard to drink more than one in a sitting.

This an okay stout, but a bit thin and mellow for my tastes.
Pours dark brown, almost black with a foamy cappuccino head. Notes of chocolate and toffee. Sweet upfront, with a bitter edge.
Nice, but not my go to stout.

Jet black colour with a small & creamy mocha head. Aroma of burnt coffee, bitter chocolate and warm alcohol. Nice, smooth body with a pleasant creaminess. More bitter coffee & chocolate in the flavour. A very good quality stout
Bottle.  I always get this when I am in OR.  This is one of the best widely available American stouts.
caramel, toffee, toasted, smoke, black, muddy, cloudy, creamy, light brown, diminishing head, light sweetness, medium bitterness, minerals, medium body, thick feel, lively,

Pours a midnight black, with some faint brownish highlights, foamy mocha colored head fading very slowly, with just a few spots of lacing left in the glass. Lots of milk chocolate in the nose, faint coffee, and nice burnt/charred edges. Taste follows right along, just the perfect amount of sweetness, nothing overly bitter. Creamy mouthfeel, medium level of carbonation. This is just plain delicious, and drinkability is completely off the map. Extremely impressive stout.

Bottled sample at the public house in Las Vegas.  Quite sweet with notes of chocolate. Hops cut the sweetness.  Very drinkable

Deep, rich, dark-roasted malt, balanced by enough hops to make this an extremely drinkable stout. Mild sweetness upfront with coffee and cocoa, and smooth lightly bitter hops on the finish.

Pour is nearly pitch black with a little light getting through on the edges and a light brown head. Lots of dark chocolate and toasted malt on the nose, with a hint of coffee. Very dark earthy taste, dark bitter chocolate, espresso, toasted malt, and a fair amount of hops. Medium bodied, not too sweet, and very well balanced.
Very dark color. Can taste the malt and barley. Has slight taste of chocolate. Good drink overall.

Black with big, foamy, brown head, strong legs / Nose of roast grain, tobacco, dark chocolate / Medium to full body, some chew, dry but fine balance and bitter finish / Flavors of dark roast coffee, bittersweet chocolate, weed, tobacco, caramel, lemon / A very nice, regular old, dry stout.
After 2nd day in Zion.  Pours a black beer with a long lasting, lacing, rocky tan top. Scent is roasted malts and coffee. Taste runs coffee, roasty, sweet and earthy.

Bottle.  Pours a thick black color with tan head.  Chocolate, freshly roasted coffee beans, burnt roasty aromas. Rich, chocolate, roasty flavors. One of the first craft beers I tried.  Really fucking nice stout.
Pretty excellent stuff. Once again shared RonÂ’s bottle. Really solid stout in every way.

Best by: 07/23/13

Poured into a snifter revealing a black body with a finger of brown head that retains and laces nicely.

An inviting aroma of roasted coffee and chocolate chip cookies.

Comes in roasty and chocolatey. There is a fair amount of hop presence providing bitterness and a touch of grassiness.

Medium bodied with moderate carbonation. Drinks smooth.

Draft at iTap, Soulard. Served in a Shaker pint glass.  Pours a jet black with a thick, creamy tan head.  "Creamy" is the operative word, as the consistency of the head borders on the density of cappuccino foam--maybe even denser.  Thick, creamy texture of the foam breaks through to the smooth, slick mouthfeel of the stout underneath.  Toasty aromas; overtones of coffee; hints of dark chocolate.  Slightly dry but not astringent, Obsidian is a smooth, quaffable stout that does not bite.

Pours black with tan head that dissipates quickly. Nose is roasted barley and coffee with a bit of chocolate. Taste is smooth bitter coffee going into chocolatey sweet then mellowing back to a nutty dark chocolate bitterness. A decent amount of carbonation sparkle lightens the body. Great stout with bittersweet notes, satisfying without being too heavy, a new favorite.
Big chocolate, coffee, toffee candy nose. Can taste the alcohol but not over powering. A little bitter but over all very tasty  beer. Nice lacing on glass.
Pour black with tan head and nice lacing.  Aroma of creamy chocolate and dark coffee.  Taste is espresso with dark chocolate in the back end.  Smooth and drinkable.

Refrigerated 12 oz. brown bottle poured into a shaker.  Pours black with big light brown head, and nice small bubble lacing.  Medium thick body, low/medium carbonation, and slighty sweet roasty aroma.  Taste is slightly sweet roasty malt and milk chocolate.  Pretty good.
Not as good as DRBÂ’s porter, but solid.  Tall, dark, and hansome.  A little soapy, but that will go away if you take advice: Drink with chocolate....it really enhances the flavor.
UPDATED: APR 22, 2013 Very good stout drank in San Francisco out of a bottle, dark, malt and barley all around.

Uploading old ratings that were missing comments. Nice stout with prominent licorice notes. Tasty and drinkable. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
UPDATED: JUL 27, 2013 Good rich aroma and creamy mouthfeel. Nice roasty taste and each swallow ends with a nice hops bitterness for my palate. Overall very good stout to drink with spicy foods.

The beer is opaque, dark brown nearing black. The beige head is thick and massive, coating the glass with a thick sheet of lacing as it slowly recedes. The aroma really inviting dark roast, coffee, chocolate. Ooh. I can already see why this is so highly rated. The flavor brings a heavy dose of roast with a splash of coffee. The finish brings a hop bitterness that melds beautifully with the charred roast character. Long lasting aftertaste. A solid beer. If this were in my market, I would keep it around all year.
Bottle pour at a local Italian restaurant - go figure... This is a very dark pour that balances nicely.

This beer is black with a prominent tan head, and the aroma is subtle with chocolate and roasted malts. The taste is mildly bitter and mildly sweet, and the palate compliments the taste with its full body, creamy texture, soft carbonation, and bitter finish.

Poured two fingers of tan head on a black body.
The aroma is roasted malt, dark chocolate and 
The taste is great. Lots of roasted malt and bitter-sweet chocolate. A dry bitterness through; results in a complex drink.
The texture is smooth and crisp with low carbonation and medium body.
ItÂ’s just about everything I ever wanted in a stout.
12 oz bottle.  Pours black with a light brown head thatÂ’s lasting.  Roasty malt aroma, coffee and chocolate.  Rich flavor with a moderate hop bitterness.  Smooth and creamy

On tap at ITAP in St. Louis. I was really happy when i got this brew. Nitro. The bartender compared it to guiness. IÂ’ll agree but also strongly disagree. The palate was alot of the same qualities yet just a bit more full. Appearance was beautifully black with a gorgeous head. IÂ’d have to say the most pleasing part of this beer was the finish. HOPS!! YAAYY. Such a wonderful happy ending.

Bottle thnx to Bytemesis, cheers Mike!! Pours a blackened beer with an one-finger of beige head. Aroma is very chocolate forward with tones of kandi sugar and dark caramel. Flavour is an exact copy of the aroma, but it also has a creamy subtleness to it. This is full bodied, even for a low abv beer this is awesome. Not as powered as an imperial stout, but this is a very good one!
Good dark color, small dark tan head. Nose is chocolate with coffee notes. Taste is mocha with emphasis on bittersweet chocolate. Solid stout.
Draft (nitro) in pint glass.  Consistently dark, yet clean looking.  Fine, small head. Smooth and creamy.

Pours black (which is appropriate) with a thin, barely there brown head. Aroma is bakerÂ’s chocolate, vanilla, roast, coffee; malt bomb but with some bitterness to balance things out. Pretty intense flavor; surprised it wasnÂ’t higher in alcohol. Full bodied, thick mouth feel. Pretty carbonated. I really liked this.

Bottle - Bitter chocolate, coffee and all the usual suspects in a stout.  Opaque black, brown thick head.  Taste of dark chocolate is prevalent, but a nice hop bitterness to cut the sweetness.  No over the top sweet alcohol finish.  Rich on the palate.  Nice stout.

Serving: from bottle--purchased at Total Wine & More.

Aroma: chocolate.

Appearance: small, frothy, brown, initial head with fully diminishing longevity and fair lacing.  Black-hued body.

Taste: moderately sweet initial taste with heavily bitter, roasted malty finish with hint of smoke and long duration.

Palate: medium to full bodied with oily texture, lively carbonation.

Overall: very good, but the heavily bitter finish was too much for my tastes.
It poured an almost black color with a small tan head. The aroma was of malt, chocolate and some coffee. The taste was roasted malt, chocolate, dark fruit, smoke and a hint of hops. Decent.
Out of 12 ounce bottle.  Deep dark roasted notes and creamy texture. Nice balance of coffee and chocolate flavors.

One hell of a big stout with a creamy oat, roasted intense malts and a big French roast espresso. A hint of hops on the finish with a creamy mouth feel and a mostly dry finish. A bit lingering, but a great stout regardless.

12oz bottle poured into a pint glass.  Pours dark black with a brownish tint.  Thin mocha head that lingers.  Aroma is lightly charred malts and earthy hops.  Taste is creamy bitter black roasty malts.  Rich but not overly so.  Finishes hoppy and bitter.  Nice low ABV (relatively speaking...), this is very easy drinking and sessionable.  Not heavy bodied, which you might expect.  For a straight up, plain old, not imperial, chocolate, coffee, belgian, whatever stout, this is as good as it gets.

Poured from a 12 ounce bottle thanks to khoffman. Pours a near black with a thick, khaki colored head of foam. The aroma has lots of chocolate, dark roasted barley, and some espresso with just a touch of creamer. Taste is more on the roasty side than the sweet side. ThereÂ’s some bitterness that hides out in the background, but itÂ’s not really a hop bitterness. ItÂ’s more of a malty bitterness. Nearly chewy mouthfeel. Thick on the tongue.
One of my favorite any time stouts, black pour and dark brown head. Clean roasted taste thatÂ’s always balanced. Clean dry finish. Great with a deli sandwiches, stir fry or desert.

12 oz. bottle to mason, christmas coffee if you will. Dark black, not quite blackout black. Dark tan head, fair amount of lacing. Smells like coffee/chocolate/roasted malt. Really nice balanced flavor, the hops are done tremendously with this beer, just the right amount to balance the malt bill. Medium to full mouthfeel, medium carbonation, great drinker... goes down really easy. Wish I could get more :(   Long espresso finish. Super solid stout! highly reccomended

black pour, thin tan head.  dark roasted malts.  noticable hops.  black licorice.  a bit of stale coffee.  slightly above medium thickness. dry smooth finish.  lingering malty taste.  similar to kalamazoo stout.
Bottle pours a black beer with a long lasting, lacing, rocky tan top. Scent is roasted malts and coffee. Taste runs coffee, roasty, sweet and earthy.

12oz bottle.  Pours black as night, great lacinÂ’, big olÂ’ head burns off nicely.  Taste is burnt, strong coffee, chicory, and dark chocolate.  Sits exceptionally well on the tongue, heavy but not unbearable.  One of their best.
Weak aroma for the intense blackness to this stout.  Dark chocolate at the finish a very bitter stout this one.  A very carbonated stout.  No trace of alcohol for the 6.2% rating
Black with a nice nitro smooth brown head. Ashy and smooth. A very good session stout!
Smokey, bitter, roasted malts in aroma and taste. Body is smooth and easy to drink. Has a nice, lingering bitter finish.
Black, thick dark brown head.. pleasant aroma, chocolate, coffee, raisin, roasty.. medium-bodied, good flavor, nice sessionable stout.

"American Guinness, gonna mess your mind
American Guinness, she gonna mess your mind
American Guinness, gonna mess your mind
American Guinness, gonna mess your mind

Say A, say M, say E Say R, say I, C Say A, N" 
-Me, after a 6Â’er of Obsidian. Seriously though, I would be willing to argue that this tastes as good as fresh Guinness off the cask.

This is a decent beer but seemed to lack the complexity I look for in Stout.  Just a little to harsh for a go to beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at Collins Pub on nitro. Pours coal black with super smooth even head. Aroma has coffee and caramel with some earthiness. Taste follows, perhaps charcoal in it? More bitter than sweet. Nitro smooth. Finishes bitter and somewhat rough in flavor despite the nitro smoothing out the edges. Nice on election night!

Enjoyed via a bottle from St. Paul, MN. Pours a dark brown/black with a medium tan head. Smells of coffee and some grassy hops. The taste is coffee, chocolate and some hoppy bitterness. There is a slight taste of alcohol as well. The aftertaste is bitter and dry with lots of coffee.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Not the best stout I had so far. Nice black body with a minimal, vanishing tan head. Smell is roasted malt (coffee). Taste is dry, bittersweet with coffee notes again. Body is low. Bitter finish

UPDATED: OCT 31, 2012 ItÂ’s built like a brick house, full figured and smooth going down.  Nuts, coffee and roasted stuff in a creamy package. Smells like a unsweetened, post-meal dessert. Dark black with a brown head. ItÂ’s satisfying and will fill you up quick.
UPDATED: APR 28, 2013 Excellent stout. A coffee nose with a smoother malty finish. Thick creamy head. Great example of the genre.

Pours black with a huge brown head that dissipates into a frothy sea foam with good lacing.  Aroma is roasted coffee and malts, and the taste follows suit.  Not overly complex, but itÂ’s got the right amount of bitterness in the end.

Davvero un ottima stout. Nera con schiuma poco persistente e marroncina. Al naso il classico aroma delle stout: caffÃ¨, malto tostato e una venaura infinitesima di cioccolato. Al palato di nuovo caffÃ¨ e malto tostato con una struttura di fondo luppolata che cresce ed "esplode" nel finale. Una birra sobria e di pregevole fattura.

A very solid stout! Hm whatÂ’s important is... how is this different from other stouts IÂ’ve had? The "chocolate" aspect is more attune to bakersÂ’ bitter chocolate than average. Sad to say but some breweries canÂ’t even make a 6.4% beer without a hint of SOME alcohol, this one youÂ’d never guess.

Deschutes Obsidian Stout

A- pours pitch black with a loose tan head. 

S- dark chocolate, some smokiness. Good coffee like flavors with a bit of sweetness to it as well.

T- again dark chocolate bitterness, big robust stout flavors. Borderline imperial. Tastes great, a lot of chocolate flavors.

M- medium to thick with pretty aggressive amount of carbonation. Still smooth though. Also as a bit of warming alcohol presence.

O- one of the best regular stouts I've had. No barrel aging, no vanilla, no extra bells and whistles. Just a superb example of beer that doesn't need to be limited to be great.

-

Nitro draft. Aroma is dark malt. Appearance is awesome. The taste is dry and dark. Very smooth and dark. Great palate. Overall, a decent stout.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: JUL 4, 2015 First ratingSampled at GABF on Saturday October 13, second sessionDark brown to black color, brown head. Sweet, roasted scent. Sweet, chocolate taste. Medium mouthfeel, medium bitterness.8/4/7/3/14=3.6ReratePart of a flight on July 1, 2015. At the brewpub in Portland.As "Nitro".Black color, tan head. Light roasted, sweet, grainy taste. Roasted aftertaste. Smooth, thick mouthfeel, medium bitterness. Roasted, grainy scent.7/4/8/4/15=3.8

355 ml bottle. Rated on 13.10.2012.Pours a pitch black colour with a beige, creamy, firm head. Aroma of roasted malts, tobacco and milk chocolate. Flavour of roasted malts, ash, milk chocolate and loads of burnt coffee. Medium bodied, rich mouthfeel and soft carbonation. Finishes roasty and rich in coffee. Really pleasant and smooth.

Dark mocha brown with grayish mocha head, firm and creamy. Aromas of chocolates and blackberries. The flavour is charred chocolate and roasted malts. A touch of coffee is not bad. Although it is complex, itÂ’s a bit too thin, as I expected a full-bodied stout. Nice bitter & sweet finish, well balanced. Not nearly as good as its cousin, the Deschutes Porter.
On draft st toronado in san francisco. Pours black with a creamy tan head. Currant and roasted malt nose. Smooth and creamy mouth feel. Bitter finish. Quite a nice stout.

StanleyÂ’s Beer Fest 10/6, BOTTLE. Aroma of roast, dark chocolate, coffee. Taste is bitter (like you get from dark chocolate) and a bit thin for a stout. Overall, a bit thin and lacking especially for a 99 in style

Wow, what a great stout. Toasted malt so big you inhale it before you even get near the glass, aromas of burnt chocolate, coffee and molasses, with a doughy earthy sweetness. Pour is black, with a rocky, frothy, lasting tan head and a murky body. Heavy in taste, but light enough in body to quaff, this totally belies its 6.4% ABV, its oily and a touch creamy with the expected flat carbonation - palate is its biggest asset. Flavour is a nice balance of burnt chocolate coffee sweetness and a bitter dry, hoppy backbone. Not overly complicated, just an exceptional  stout.

From tap. Pours opaque with thick, creamy, tan head. Nose is mostly various roasted malts, all sweet with little to no hops. Taste is similar to aroma with truffles and chocolate standing out to me. Some bitterness underlying if you look for it. Mouthfeel is typical for your nitro pours- smooth, creamy/buttery and easy to gulp. Overall a solid option for a session stout (if you forget the ABV).

Thick and rich and chocolate. Not creamy, but more roasty. Roast coffee up front, plus some burnt raison fruitiness. Complex layers of flavor- sweet espresso, dark chocolate and dry dark roast malt bitterness. I could drink this stuff all day.
Bottle from Liquor Max. Pours jet black with almost no head. Some roasted malt on the nose. Viscous, very thick mouthfeel. Big roasted malt on the tongue. This feels like a bigger beer. Very nice.

UPDATED: DEC 10, 2012 Appearance is really quite flawless - pitch black and immense, thick fluffy head that retains exceptionally well, leaving impressive, big rings of lacing.  Aroma is somewhat modest by comparison, primarily consisting of semi-sweet chocolate and just a hint of coffee.  Flavor is much more coffee-forward, finishing nicely with the semi-sweet chocolate and a touch of bitterness.  The mouthfeel was a bit thick, the aftertaste doesnÂ’t linger a whole lot, and the bitterness punch is a little less than I was hoping, but this is still a very good stout.

Bottle and tap. Excellent, dark color. Not much of a head, but the taste makes up for it. Strong, roasted flavor and dry. Earns label "stout". Bitter after taste not as pleasent as it is up front, but that hardly makes it undrinkable. A bit on the heavy side too, so drink slow and enjoy.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2013 Roast cocoa aroma with a hint of grapefruit.  Very dark with thick foamy tan cloud of head that lingers and lingers.  Not bad overall. Very nice roasty flavor and nice full body. The finish had a little more hoppy bitterness than I like.
silky with strong head.  Nice flavor, arresting from the first sip.  A stout is a true beauty when done

12oz bottle - pours pitch black with voluminous tan head and decent lacing.  Nose is roasted malts, smoke and chocolate.  Flavor adds some evading fruity notes.  Taste is moderately bitter with light sweetness: well balanced.  medium to full body.  dry finish.  Glad to have a cousin that travels a lot and picks up good beers to share!
Dark brown with ruby lowlights and a creamy tan head.  Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate and light nuts.  Taste of roasted black patent malt, chocolate, salt and a touch of nuts.  A touch chalky.

Pour is a black with a large tan head.  Aroma is a nice char and roasted malt.  Flavor is roasted malt, espresso and a silky chocolate.  Finish has roasted malt left on the tounge.  Very smooth and tasty.

UPDATED: MAY 2, 2014 On tap at CaponeÂ’s, Coeur dÂ’Alene ID. Superb aroma of roasted malts. Taste is slightly bitter, roasty. Really good.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Tasted from 12oz bottle into nonic pint glass. It poured an opaque black with thick moussy brown foam, long-lasting with excellent lace. Perfect appearance. Aromas of roasted barley, smeet malts, dark chocolate and black coffee. Flavor was toasty, roasty, malt sweetness nicely balanced by tangy hops and grain bitterness, with hints of raisins and plum sauce. Medium body and carbonation, bready and slightly chalky mouthfeel, very dry but somehow simultaneously stone-fruity finish. A true-to-style yet particularly delicious stout.
Pours a deep brown color with aroma of roasted nuts.  Taste is clean with a chocolate malt flavor.  Overall a good beer for the style.  Slight roasted malt flavor with a simple flavor.

Pours a deep black with a thick, creamy, tan head and some lacing. Aroma is mild with roasted malt and cocoa. Flavor is roasted malt, dark chocolate, coffee, and toffee. Creamy, full body with little carbonation and a rich, creamy mouthfeel. Very good.

Pours very dark brown with a large sturdy tan head.  The aroma has heavily roasted malt, cocoa, molasses, dark fruit, coffee and tart apple.  Medium / full body thatÂ’s a bit smooth until the carbonation hits.  While the carbonation is mild and smooth it roughs up the smoothness that was there previously.  The flavor begins with dry roasty bitter malt, some apple and a good amount of char.  The finish is a bit ashy and chalky with some earthy / spicy hops.  Very nicely done stout. especially for a line priced beer.
Decent beer had on nitro at a bar in San Francisco. Guinness like but with lots more flavor.

Pours a dark black colour with a big brown head. The aroma s strong chocolate and coffee with a it of roasted malts. Flavour is dark chocolate bitter with more coffee notes. Very smooth thick feel on the palate. Vey enjoyable

Pours as black as they come, small tanned head. Dark notes of coffee, chocolate. A good stout, and my first one from this brewery!
Note to self: Stored in a freezer instead of a fridge, need to re-rate at a later time
Pours almost black with minimal head. Taste of oats, malt, chocolate and some other notes. A great beer from Deschutes
On tap.  Comes almost black with a small tan head.  Aroma of malt, chocolate, and coffee.  Taste is roasted malt, chocolate, dark fruit, smoke, and hops.  Nice.

UPDATED: AUG 27, 2012 Pours thick and almost black in color. Has an aroma that is roasty with chocolate and coffee. Has a roasted malt flavor with chocolate and coffee. Leaves a smooth creamy texture on your palate. Overall, a great beer for those who like dark beers and stouts.

Good looking brew, black as night with a nice brown head and good lacing.

Smells great.  Good roasty and burnt aromas of roasted barley, a little sweet malt character.

Taste wise this is one of the best stouts IÂ’ve had in a long time, itÂ’s downright fantastic.  Great burnt, smoky and roasty character, a bit of chocolate, great coffee flavors, and a bold hoppiness that add just the right amount of bitterness.  

Body is also wonderful, very thick and rich, acrid bitter and roasted barley aftertaste, perfect amount of carbonation.  For a pretty low ABV American stout this beer has incredibly big body and flavor.  

This beer is just fantastic.  Deschutes continues to impress me every time I try another one of their delicious beers.
deep opaque black with a dark tan head.  Roasty aroma with coffee and cocoa.  rich silky body,notes of espresso and bitter chocolate with a dry finish.

From notes: Classic stout profile. Coffee, espresso, nutshell, liquid molten rock, and bitter chocolate. Mild carbonation. Long, lingering finish of dark espresso and roasted malt. Impressive for price!! A must buy!

--- tasted while on a long journey to understand the world around me...

Pours dark black. Smooth creamy head sticks to the glass. Coffee, mineral, burnt wood. Smooth, char, bitter.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Thick and rich and chocolate. Not creamy, but more roasty. Roast coffee up front, plus some burnt raison fruitiness. Complex layers of flavor- sweet espresso, dark chocolate and dry dark roast malt bitterness. I could drink this stuff all day.

12oz. bottle.  Pours black with generous brown head.  Aroma is roasted chocolate malt.  Roasted malt flavor with coffee notes.  Creamy mouthfeel and roasty finish with just a bit of sweetness.  A very good stout.

Shaker pint nitro draft at Waldo Pizza in Kansas City, Missouri.  The pour is a black, with a creamy one inch tan head.  The aroma is chocolate malt, light roast, perhaps even a bit of ash.  There is also char coffee and a mineral.  Roasty nose, generally.  The taste show a touch of malt sweetness initially, though this gives way really quickly to the roast, toast and char of the malts.  Very dry, nice mineral character in the finish.  The palate is medium bodied, silky nitro mouth feel, dry finish.  Easy drinking stout, nitro worked well for it.

Pretty good. Served a little cold with a smallish taan head and a bit of lace. Color is an opaque black brown. Aroma is roast, malt, molasses, licorice, bit of honey and dark ripe fruit. FlavorÂ’s like nose, muted, fairly dry, toast, carbonic tang, and bitter up front, in fact itÂ’s all up front. Body is great, ditto carbonation. Finish is like flavor, a bit long, and also a bit boozy. Good drinkinÂ’ stout.
Tap @ Taphouse Grill, Seattle. Nice creamy head with excellent duration. Color is black. Aroma and taste are rich roast malt, chocolate, licorice notes and hops. Nice and dry.

Black-as-night pour. Nose & flavors of coffee, bitter chocolate, licorice, roasted malts, & some smoke. Ending w/ a little bit of creaminess, vanilla, & a good hop bitterness for balance. An excellent representation of the style. Love this beer, even when itÂ’s 110 degrees outside!
A solid beer from a solid brewery. Black, rich, with a nice oily palate.  Chocolate, molasses, and almost no alcohol. Tried this for the first time at Philmont in 2008.  Multiple times since.
Kind of a one dimensional stout, lots of coffee notes in a chocolate body, but otherwise like any other stout. Its cheap!
Nice. Roasted everything, malt, grain, fruit, spice, wood and grass. Somehow it all remains drinkable and tasty with enough sweet to glue it all together.
Nitro @ Portland pub. Oily black with a thin but dense head. Bittersweet chocolate and lightly roasted coffee. Seems better than I remember bottles being.

355 ml bottle @ Hotel room, Seattle.
Pours deep dark ruby red, almost black color with small head. Aroma of chocolate, dry malts, ash and dark ripe fruits. Flavor of dark dry chocolate, ash, dark malts, dark ripe fruits and some spice notes. Very aggressive stout.
4426
140712. Tap a the brewery. Pours black with a nice full head. Aroma chocolate, roastef malts. Dry palate. Not Bad.

Poured into tulip glass with a best by: 7/28/12. Glad I noticed this since it is 7/15/12

Appearance: Big beautiful 2 to 2&1/2 finger size head that is khaki color with tight condensed bubbles. It is a dark black beer with absolutley no light penetration through this beer. The lacing on this is ridiculous as I swirl the glass it really sticks to the side. I was taken by the head that formed on this. Awesome!

Smell: Upfront is the espresso and toasted malts along with dark chocolate and nuts. I get some slight molasses and some fairly noticable hops.

Taste: Roasted malts big time! Some bitter chocolate and mild coffee present. A noticable bitter hoppy finish for a stout that prevents any overly sweet finish.

Mouthfeel: Somewhat thin for a stout and rather carbonated. Not slick or viscous but that is nice on this one because it makes it highly drinkable.

Overall: This is a nice change of pace stout for me. Slightly hoppy and roasted goodness through and through. Low abv makes this easy to drink and that is apparent as my glass is nearing empty and only after about 10 minutes.

UPDATED: AUG 4, 2012 
Draught @ Deschutes Brewery & Public House, Portland
Aroma is surprisingly light with some roasted notes, chocolate, english hops and hints of hay. Flavour is fruity with some english hops, salty licorice and hints of ash. Dry finish. Close to the Black Butte.
16-07-2012: A bit better from the bottle; less salty and more licorice. 3.6.
Very good stout,  doesnÂ’t have the flavor of an oatmeal stout but it really that s top quality nonetheless. It would go great with a steak or beef in general and be incredible with bbq pork.

Wing Central. 

Pours black with a finger tan head. Smell is fruity, roasty. Taste is roasty body and a chocolate aftertaste. Very smooth stout, good beer.

UPDATED: JUL 26, 2012 
Location: 12 oz bottle from the Wine Corner in Paia, Maui, 7/8/12


Aroma: The aroma has burnt malts, roasted malts, coffee, and a little smoke

Appearance: Pours a dark brown-black color with a thick beige head and heavy lacing

Flavor: The flavor is rich and roasty, lots of dark malts/coffee flavors, and a later earthy hop bitterness

Palate: The body is medium-full, with a smooth and creamy feel, average carbonation, and a dry/roasty finish

Overall Impression: 
Overall, this makes for a pretty nice burnt/roasted malt stout.  The flavor profile is pretty true to what I can only assume was the goal, lots of dark malt flavors along with some earth hops to balance out all those rich malts.  Nice stuff.

Draught @ The Collins Pub in Seattle.  Oily black with a small whitish head.  Aroma of burned sugar.  Flavor is slightly sour with a ton of roasty malts, and Mallard goodness.  Immensly thick, perhaps the most so IÂ’ve ever tried.
12oz bottle. Clean, dry stout, nicely tart hops. Juicy finish. Undistinguished brew, but Tasty.

12oz bottle, best by November 5, 2012.  Served at cellar temperature.

Pours black with a huge foamy 4-finger brown head that leaves clumpy rings of lacing behind and holds a really good cap.

Aroma is cocoa powder, coffee, roasted malts, dark fruits such as plums and figs, but the cocoa is the dominant component.  Good to very good strength.

Flavor is roasted malts, chocolate & coffee, dark fruit, caramel, toffee, molasses, a hint of herbal hops.  A bit of sweetness, mild bitterness, minimal alcohol.

Mouthfeel is medium bodied, soft carbonation, smooth and easy drinkinÂ’

Fantastic Stout.  One of the best IÂ’ve had in this style.  Lovely cocoa notes with additional complexity underneath.  Not too big, so it is relatively easy to drink.  A real treat.  Hopefully some day Deschutes will start distributing out to these parts and I can get this on the regular.
Aroma is roasted malts, yeast, fruit and a mild earthiness.  The flavor is roasted malts, fruit/berries, a note of earthiness and a mild tartness in finish.

a couple days ago I purchased a sixer of black butte porter and after pouring a nice glass of what I though was the porter I was surprised by something even more roasty and flavorful.  apparently the customer who last purchased some of this stout made a mixed six with the porter I bought.  Nice!
Deep chocolate notes swim amongst a dark mocha head. this opaque brew is a positive experience from bottle too glass to mouth and back to the store for another.

I really liked this one on tap but I didnÂ’t care for the nitro version.  This is a very well balanced stout that doesnÂ’t knock you out with the flavor but it is very good.  The appearance is probably the best thing about this beer.  It has a great chocolate head on it and there is pretty of expresso goodness in this beer.
ItÂ’s alright...a little pricey 4 a mediocre beer...you can choke a few down if you have no other choice..

The aroma is dominated by the roasted malts as well as the espresso. While the taste brings forth many other flavors. The way the espresso, malts and chocolate play off of each other, makes this a great stout that you can find widely available.
Tap in Portland - Nice looking stout, mild nose, mild palate. Seemed to have pulled a punch, think putting it on nitro muted too much.

Bottle. Light tan head on a slate black body. Quite hoppy actually all-round, with roasty dry notes and slight coffee as well.  Chocolate and coffee driven flavors, and finishes dry.  Medium to thinner velvety body with vibrant carbonation.
Nice opaque pour; aromas somewhat subdued but chocolate coffee aroma presents; taste is well balanced with mild hops and chocolate contributing to bitterness.

Pours a deep opaque brown with a robust tan head and tons of lacing. The nose is roasted grain and a hint of sweetness. The taste is burnt/ roasted/hoppy/tarry/bitter. The mouthfeel is full with some nice effervence. The aftertaste is roasty. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Had this at the blue dog. 
Appears quite black with a rocky tall head that dense and lingers for a long while. Looks to be about average carbonation. Lots of sticky lacing to the bottom of the glass.

Aroma is rich and robust with roasted malts and esspresso hints of molasses comes through too.

Taste is of rich roasted malts and black coffee.
Some hop bitterness comes through to balance out the sweetness.

Mouthfeel is thick and creamy. Slides down nicely.

This was a good stout with lots of flavor.

Pours pitch black with dark brown edges.  Thick and foamy light brown head dissipates quickly leaves nice lacing down the glass. Smells sweet roasted malts.  Tastes dark roast coffee, mocha and dark roasted/burnt malts in the aftertaste with a little hoppy bitterness. Nice medium body.
On tap at Churckey for the Funky Buddha event. Chocolate caramel and brownie like mocha lead to cocoa nib and creamy espresso. Thick rich palate with a dry roasty finish
From a traditional English pub glass; dark, roasty deliciousness. Love to see it w nitro

Pours nighttime black into random Baltimore pint glass appointing its head a khaki tannish to it, foamy and lacy before sinking only a half-inch into itself. Smells of roasted malts (predominately), heat, charcoal, and noble hops. Tastes the same; finishes dry and musty. Damn nice stout!

Tap. Pours almost opaque black with a small brown creamy head with great staying power and good lacing. Aroma is nice, roasted malts dominating, coffee, a bit of chocolate. Flavor is somewhat sweet, dominated by roasted malts and coffee, with a slightly bitter finish. Creamy, full bodied mouthfeel.

UPDATED: JUN 22, 2012 A thick creamy bitterness lingers in the suds that wash over your mouth. silky mouthfeel like an oatmeal stout. Frothy burnt overtones. Great mouthfeel. Overall beer for a great longhall! Two

Poured into a stein. Extremely dark with frothy brown head. Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate and coffee. Taste had some hop bitterness cutting through the sweet flavors. Full-body with thick, creamy texture and a lingering espresso flavor. Very nice stout.
Burnt and molasses in the nose. Bittersweet chocolate, very dry astringent mouthfeel, bitter roasted malts provide dry and bitter finish.

Originally reviewed: 4/10/09. Pours a perfect dirty motor oil black. Thick and chunky this one is. Great foamy tan head on top. Retention is great leaving with it nice lacing rings. Smells of deep dark chocolate, espresso, grape jam, and wine. Nice. Great thick oily mouth on this one. Drinkability is high. Flavors of roasted cocoa, bitter coffee, finishes slightly acrid and burnt. Decent. I like this brew alot. Great stout. Recommend.

Pours jet black with tan head into pint glass. Smells of fresh roasted coffee, dark chocolate, sweet caramel. Taste is bold, hoppy, roasted malt, big for the ABV. Probably the best regular stout IÂ’ve had.

On nitro tap at the Bend pub. This is the ONLY way to drink this beer....at the pub on nitro. It is the mother of all stouts.We gauge all other stouts against this one. Pitch black with a creamy head.Seems to start out dry but finishes a little sweet as your pint warms and settles. What  a great beer this is.

Black pour with large thin tan head. Aroma of malt and chocolate. Taste of roasted malts, chocolate and a tinge of molasses. Nice creamy mouthfeel, low carbonation, and some bitterness in the aftertaste. Very good beer.

Coming out of rating retirement for this one because it so worthy.   Aroma is roasty chocolatey goodness, with hints of coffee and burnt sugar.   Pours nearly black, with a thick tan head.  Flavor is deep, dark roasted malt, coffee, again some burnt sugar, maybe some molasses.   Mouth is full bodied, thick and chewey, with a lasting bitterness.   Under appreciated, up there with the best stouts.

Pours a pitch black with a foamy tan head which fades to some nice lacing.  Aroma is of roasted malts, coco, and some coffee.  Taste is of bittersweet coco, espresso, roasted malts, licorice, and some hop bitterness to balance out the malts.  Has a medium full body with a thick, creamy mouthfeel, and a semi dry, bitter finish.  overall, a pretty nice, drinkable stout.

Black with a big beige, soapy head that laces pretty thickly. Aroma of roast, dark chocolate, coffee and burnt wood. Taste is roasty and bitter as if from both chocolate and hops. Mild sweetness. Rich is a good description. Medium-full bodied, pretty smooth. Excellent stout.

UPDATED: SEP 5, 2012 This is a solid milk stout. Pours black with off-white head. It does that cool thing that murphy?s and guiness do where the bubbles foam up from below the headafter the pour. This is on the level of guiness, but there is very little aroma from the beer. The taste is nicely hoppy for a stout, with bitter chocolate and no sweetness. The mouth feel is like pudding, thick and creamy.  It leaves a thick tan lace around my pint glass and opens up as it warms. If it just had more of a noise this would be in the neighborhood of Sam Smiths imperial or rogue?s oatmeal stout.

Nice smooth stout - tasted good with Newman's Own Mint Wafer Cookies. The cookies brought out more of the coffee flavors in the beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12oz. bottle (thanks James). Pours jet black with a creamy tan head. Aroma of dark coffee and roasted malt, Taste of dark chocolate and roasted coffee with a hint of smoke. Medium body with a velvety creamy texture. Solid beer!

Bottle. Tis a solid stout, pours black with tan head, dark riated grain in aroma and flavor with hints of bakers cocoa and dry...medium-heavy mouth feel with high carbonation. Overall, bad ass name and pretty solid stout but nothing that will be stuck in my head.

[Thanks to MatSciGuy]. 12fl. bottle. Black colour with a good formation of a creamy, frothy and foamy tan head. Good lacing and perfect lasting. Aroma has chocolate notes, dark coffee and toasted malts. Flavour has notes of strong licorice and black coffee, some toasted and roasted malts are also present. On palate results a dense beer with a decent aftertaste. Carbonation is medium. Body is medium to high. Texture is oily to creamy.

Very strong coffee bean flavor. A bit too strong. I'd like a little more carbonation. Could've just been bad pipes at Toronado. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pitch black pour with tan head. Smell of dark malts, hints coffee and chocolate. Taste is much like the smell. Smooth enjoyable stout.

So how many awards has this beer won? Beautiful thick mushroomed cream head over blackness. Aromas of roasted malts and cacao. Taste is freakinÂ’ outrageous. Very well balanced. chocolaty, espresso, sweet, bitter, perfect carbonation. A great Stout. I love this beer.
bottle. Black, nice tan head- looks amazing, Smells nutty, woody, roasty. Has a slight burnt taste, not too much though. Nutty, roasted. Quite delicious. Very good.

Nearly opaque black but a little brown shines through.  Tan head that lasts and leaves nice lacing.  Roasty, coffee, cereal and maybe a little woody.  ItÂ’s very smooth and enjoyable.  I have been pretty impressed thus far with Deshutes beers.

A deep opaque black with a thin head that dissipates quickly. Aroma is of roasted and black malts, Taste is of heavy rostiness and coffee. Not too viscous, but has nice body. Carbonation is about medium.

355ml bottle pours almost black in color with a finger of light brown head that left behind some really nice lacing.  Aroma is dark roasted malts with chocolate and hints of coffee.  Taste is dark chocolate sweetness with some roasted malty bitterness and mild hop bitterness as well.  Very well balanced with a medium to full body and decent carbonation.  As far as stouts go, they donÂ’t get much better than this.

12 oz pour, no age.  Low chocolate aroma.  Deep toasted malt and a subtle chocolatey overtone.  Clean aftertaste, though a bit chalky. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
12 ounce bottle pour.  Black color with a medium tan head.  Roasty malts.  Light bitter.  Full bodied.  Very drinkable for a  stout.  Nice beer.
Appearance is a small brown head and black color. Aroma is a roasted chocolate. Taste is a flat roasted coffee and chocolate malt like Guinness but better. Overall very drinkable.

Pours a very dark brown, almost black, with a half inch of creamy tan/brown foam that leaves behind some fine lacing. Aroma is roasty and nutty, but rather faint. Taste is roasted malts, coffee, some dark chocolate, a bit bitter finish.
Bottle.  Dark brown pour with a big dark tan head.  Aroma is roasted malt.  Taste is slight purple grape, bitter, and roasted malts.  Body and carbonation are medium.
12 ounce bottle. Tons of chocolate and roasted malts.Hints of caramel. Some creaminess. Hops are fruity. A nice beer thatis easy drinking.

Dark, black in color with brown tinges. Creamy tan head. Looks good. The smell is roast, dirty, cocoa, dark baking chocolate, and burnt malts. The taste is malts, burnt, roast, cocoa, coffee, and good.

Not an overwhelming over the top kind of stout but the stuff that was in there comes through nicely and makes for a really good almost sessionable stout.  Nice amount of roasted malt, chocolate, and a bit of coffee.  Could easily drink 2-3 of these and be happy.
On tap. Pours a dark black brown color with a light brown head. Notes of roasted malt, dark chocolate, smoke, licorice, and fudge. Nice mouthfeel, long finish. A great stout.

Courtesy of Chris at fermentation. Black pour and a creamy brown head. Aroma is chocolate, coffee and some light roast. Flavor is leather, licorice, chocolate and coffee. Wonderful mouth feel and texture that finishes thick with a touch of bitterness. Good stuff.

looks like anchor porter. please refer to that rating to see what i had to say about. moderate chocolate, not much coffee. decent malt backbone, roasted malt etc. fairly light mouthfeel, closer to what i expect from a porter. i could drink a bunch of these pretty easily.

Draft on nitro @ deschutes.  Pours a thick black with creamy tan head and caked on lacing.  Sweet malt, chocolate, roasted on the nose.  Taste is sweet and dark roasted malts with more chocolate.  Medium body for a stout.  Very nice and would like to try off the nitro.

Beautiful pour on tap.  Deep dark color with a thick brown head.  I almost get some black licorice in the aroma. Tastes malty and slightly chocolatey with some roasted coffee notes, as well. Full bodied, but seems to thin out in the finish. A quality stout.

This is a fantastic, flavorful but not overpoweing stout.  Roasty, chocolate and a little soy in the aroma. Rich mocha and hop bitterness balance and blend perfectly. Almost always on sale for $8 or cheaper out here so you cant miss with this beer
Poured from the bottle. Aroma is of coffee, and chocolate. Palate is watery. Flavor is of roasted coffee, and chocolatey. Very basic stout. Nothing special, but no drain pour.

12 ounce bottle, best by 05/27/12.  Served in a pint glass, the beer pours dark brown/black with about an inch tan head that stayed around for a while.  ThereÂ’s also a good amount of lacing left on the glass.  Aroma is good and malty, the brew smells like roasted malt, coffee, bittersweet chocolate and charred/burnt malt.  I think the taste is similar to the aroma, with the roasty/charred bitter flavors being the strongest.  ThereÂ’s also some light hops noticeable, along with a roasty/ashy bitter finish.  Mouthfeel/body is medium, itÂ’s a little creamy and has moderate carbonation.  It also goes down easy enough.  I think this is a good brew, definitely worth a try.

On tap at Cannery Row Brewing Company, aroma is full of chocolate and malt. Nice creamy tan head. Taste was surprisingly bitter , and not full of flavor as expected . Finish is a bit flat, quite disappointing with this stout and surprised at such a high rating.
On tap, a pitch black appearance, tan head, and aroma of roasted malts. Taste is of roasted malts, chocolate, and coffee. Nice smooth, bitter finish and a solid stout.
UPDATED: JUN 23, 2012 Fantastic aroma, nice lasting, thick head. Fairly roasty and somewhat bitter. Not as complex or as interesting as I would like, but pretty solid stout.
