UPDATED: NOV 29, 2014 just a taster of this compliments of the bartender. dark brown with a chocolate and coffee aroma which matched the flavor very smooth and silky medium to light body not overpowering and the roasted malts were spot on.
11/28/14: had on nitro at the nachbar...this was the one dud of the night. nitro did nothing to enhance this beer for me actually it made it thinner in body and flavor and wasnÂ’t very happy with the results.. sorry guys

Draft @ Hoppy Monk, El Paso. Llovely creamy black with thick lasting tan head. Big silky cocoa aroma. Inky, with clay, asphalt, minerals, and stone. Lingering chocolate on tongue with some cocoa powder on palate. Dry finish is nearly burnt but has enough licorice smack for balance. Healthy brew. 4,7,4,8,15. Real yummy.
On tap at Aces. Pours black with creamy tan head. Aroma is subdued roast, coffee, and earthy hop. Dry roasted malt flavor and good mouthfeel. Dry clean finish makes this an excellent beer.
Fantastic stout! Pours almost black. Full bodied with great roasted flavours.

12 oz bottle poured into a snifter. Pours black with tan frothy 2 finger head. Aroma of bitter dark chocolate and roasted coffee. Taste is mostly bitter with the roasty coffee and hops, and the mouthfeel finishes quite dry. Nice solid stout.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On nitro-tap at the Holy Grail Pub in Plano. 

The beer pours a deep, black color with a large nitro-induced tan head. The aroma is full of roasted malt and chocolate, just as I expected. The flavor is where the nitro really takes away from the beer. I get quite a bit of chocolate and roasted malt, but the nitro thins out the mouthfeel and makes the beer taste watery. There is also a little bit of coffee in the flavor. Thin to medium, watery mouthfeel. I am not sure why people put beers on nitro, but the next one I enjoy will be my first. 

Hopefully I will be able to try this beer in the bottle or on regular tap so I can re-review it, since I am sure it is a better beer when not on nitro.

(12 oz bottle) Pours completely opaque - gorgeous black-brown color with caramel head. No lacing, but head is appropriate to style. Aroma and flavor show best at cellar temp. Soem burned toffee, espresso, and dark chocolate in the nose. Great bittering, dark roasty malt, and espresso in the taste. Great beer - a classic for late fall to early winter.
Pours very dark in the glass with a medium head. Aroma had some coffee and figs. After letting it warm up a bit the taste really started to open with some chocolate & molasses. Good stout.

Bottle. Deep black pour with a frothy tan head. Strong toffee aroma with a sense of roasted malt and grilled cherries. Milky taste with some coffee and roasted malt notes. Smooth. Not much of a finish, but still a good tasting stout.
what a great stout thanks colin! pours a jet black with a huge  brown frothy head. smooth and silkyon the palate nice and roasty/malty flavor and aroma
Bottle. Smokey sweet aroma. Chocolate, coffee, roasted flavour. Dark. A nice stout.
UPDATED: AUG 25, 2012  It has the color of a dark brewed coffee, pours thick with very nice mouthfeel. with distinct flavors of coffee and chocolate.

Brown-black with red hues and tan head.  Deep, heavy roasted malt, freshly brewed coffee, light cream and cocoa.  De-bittered coffee, roasted malt, cocoa, cream, toffee, with slight dark fruit end.  Great roasted residual.  Medium body and absolutely perfect carbonation to match.

Pours matte black with a fine, dusty light-brown head.  Aroma is slightly sweet, grainy, oaty, light roast, hints of rye bread, some pine forest and resiny sap.  Light bodied.  Big bitter burnt roast and burnt oats, some sap bitterness, but not too much.  The sweetness is light and floury.  Now the bitterness is coming out more- it doesnÂ’t linger for too long, but it hits hard with all that burnt grain flavor.  Ewww a good, interesting take on a session stout.
On Tao at square burger.  Pours black with a medium tan head.  The aromas are coffee, chocolate.  The mouthfeel is smooth, ready and slightly bitter with a heavy body.  Great beer!  Cheers!

Very solid burnt malt aroma and taste.  Nothing really outside the realm of a "good stout" though.  While enjoyed towards the end of the night, I still payed attention to details and didnÂ’t find much.  Mostly one note and faded into the back ground of other better beers.
It is smooth and black and full that distinctive roasted stout flavor with a slightly conservative hop presence to make it eminently drinkable.

Serving glass: Poured from bottle into Nonic Imperial Pint.

Appearance: Extremely dark brown that might as well be black. Has a large brown head at first that leaves some lacing rings.

Aroma: Roasted barley, coffee, molasses and just a hint of chocolate. Initial whiff seemed hoppy as well, but that did not last. While it smells very good, this is the least powerful part of the beer.

Taste: Strong, almost burnt, roasted barley with a major coffee profile, some bittersweet dark chocolate, molasses, and just a titch of licorice. Ends somewhat bitter with a burnt and hoppy bite.

Palate: Moderate carbonation, very smooth, full and creamy profile, and a dry finish. The carbonation was a little higher than expected (krausening process?) but it is not overdone and may even make the otherwise full beer more lively.

Overall: This is about as good as a non-Imperial American Stout can get, but I may give the edge to BellÂ’s Kalamazoo. Deschutes really knows how to make roasted beers (this, Black Butte Porter, Black Butte XXI, Hop in the Dark) - I have yet to try Abyss but I assume it will keep this trend alive.
UPDATED: SEP 5, 2011 Smooth rich chocolatey malt. There is a taste of coffee. what guinness aspires to be.

Date: August 7, 2011 Mode: Bottle Source: Total Wine, Las Vegas, NV Appearance: Opaque black, good amount of tan head, some lacing. Aroma: Roasted malt, coffee and sweet maybe vanilla. Flavor: Consistent with aroma except did not get the sweet, medium bodied, bitter coffee finish, nutty after-taste. Other: Very good stout, but would have liked it to have a little more sweet flavor.
On tap.  A chocolate brown pour with a creamy, foamy head.  Lots of roasted flavor in this, with just the right tinge of chocolate sweetness.  Silky smooth mouthfeel.  Just a delight on tap.  Nice.

This is such a tasty stout.  ItÂ’s got a big, rich combination of roast, chocolate and coffee, all backed up by some caramel.  The body is creamy and smooth.  ItÂ’s fairly bitter, which helps tone down the malt sweetness.  Black body with a mocha head.  Bubbles stick all over the glass prettily.  It drinks easily, despite all of the flavor.  Good stuff.
A beer inspired by volcanic rock. Wonderful taste, excellent Stout. IÂ’m running out of things to say.

On tap - Rugby House in Plano.
Dark brown, near black brew with a very creamy tan head.  Looks delicious, tastes and smells even better!  Wonderful aromas of roasted malt, chocolate, and coffee.  Incredibly smooth with a nice chocolate forward flavor.  Just the way I like my stouts - Deschutes continues to impress me with their beers.

12 oz. bottle. Pours very dark with a frothy brown head. Pretty aromatic -- smells of coffee, chocolate, and roasted malt. Taste is a wave of roasted flavors against a solid background of coffee, chocolate, caramel, and crisp hops. Feels thick, creamy (with slight crisp carbonation), and full bodied. Very nice.

Nitro pour Black cascading pour creamy off white head .... aroma is sweet and roasted malts .... taste is sweet creamy and roasted with a nice sweetness, light bitter dark chocolate and rich caramel malt .... dry roasted finish .... great balance and very drinkable ... a great stout
6-pack from ChuckÂ’s. Tastes a lot better than IÂ’ve ever had at the bar (probably because itÂ’s usually on nitro). Thick and sweet and roasty. Definitely better than the porter.
Pours black with a dark tan head. Aroma is chocolate, little smoke and malt. Flavor is dark chocolate and toasted malts. Medium bodied and light carbonation..

Biggish brown head. Opaque black body. Roasty minty perfumy aroma with chocolate notes. Dry-sweet burnt minty chocolatey taste with perfumy vanilla notes. Mid-bodied. Mild, soft mouthfeel. Dry roasty burnt oaty aftertaste with resiny mealy grainy notes. Some earth and butter, too. Perfectly OK, but not great. (0.355l bottle, Amsterdam CafÃ©, San Francisco.)

On nitro @ Concordia Ale House. Pours dark black with a creamy one finger beige head. Aroma is very roasty!  Notes of roasted chocolate malts, black coffee, and an earthy undertone. Flavor is just as roasty with the chocolate and coffee characters. Surprisingly smokey too. Extremely velvety and smooth mouthfeel, because of the nitro serving. Overall, a very solid stout! Deschutes FTW!
From notes at 2/20 tasting:  Chocolatey aromas.  Light chocolate flavors with a little smoky note.  Overall a very good stout.

12 oz bottle poured into a pint glass.  Dark, thick black pour with a tan head that sits on top about a half-inch thick.  Aromas are coffee and roasted malt, with some cocoa as well.   Taste is roasty with toast notes and chocolate and coffee in the finish.  Palate is medium with a nice creamy mouthfeel and moderate carbonation.  Overall this is a great stout that I would gladly stock it were easy to find near me.

Appearance: nearly black with notes of dark caramel; one-finger dark brown head; minor lacing.   Aroma: bitter dark chocolate, hint of licorice, whisper of sour lactic tang.  Taste: dark, rich chocolate, toasted malts, subdued notes of resinous pine.  Finish:	dry, but not overly so, bittersweet, a little toasty, with slowly fading notes of dark chocolate. Notes: Very nice stout.  Good, balanced flavors.  Worried that the lactic tang in the aroma would carry over to the flavor, but it was nicely absent.
12oz bottle. Dark brown, brown head. Roasted malts, dry mild hops, some smoke. Thin bodied, not much of a finish and get some unpleasant vegetables. Was hoping for more.

Dark pour, dark tan head dissipated quickly.  Aroma of toasted malt with some earthiness and a hint of cherries or similar dark fruit.  Flavors follow the nose well, with an initial toasted malt flavor and earthiness.  Good flavor, not huge, but lingers nicely.
Sampled in a 12oz bottle. Pours deep dark and brown. Very little head on this one. The aftertaste is a bit strong for a stout but I really enjoy the roasted flavor.

11th May 2009Opaque black stout with a brown edge. Thin soft palate. More porterish. Well toasted malt without getting bitter or dry. Minerally freshness abounds! Just a glimpse of hop bitterness in the finish. Decent.
Very malty with notes of coffee, hops, and licorice. Easy drinking and not too filling. Very good balance between dry-sweetness and bitter-hoppiness.

Deep roated malt aroma.  Hints of chocolate and coffee.  Nice head dissipates slowly and supreme lacing.  Coffee and dark chocolate malt flavor.  Not as sweet as I would have expected from the aroma.  Has a slight peppery finish.  I would have to call this an imperial stout though it doesnÂ’t say so on the label.  The mouthfeel is a little thin for the style but damn tasty!

4/16/11. 12oz bottle courtesy breaks808. Opaque black pour with a nice fluffy brown head that fades to a ring but lasts and sticks a lot. Slightly fruity aroma with coffee and roast in there as well. A better flavor in there with milk chocolate, dark chocolate, coffee, roasted malts, and more... very nice, actually! Mmm!

Bottle. Very dark brown - almost black, small to average fully diminishing dark brown head. Moderate, malty and sweetish aroma, roasted/burned malt and some coffee and hoppyness. Body is medium, malty and sweetish flavor, roasted/burned malt and some coffee. Finish is average, malty and lightly sweetish, roasted malt, some hoppyness and coffee. Sweetish stout with lots of roasted/burned malt. Nice but too sweet for me.

From notes:

Pours pitch black and completely opaque with a large frothy mocha head that has excellent retention, only slowly fading into a lasting cap that coats the glass with rings and large chunks of soapy lacing.

Roasted malt aroma with hints of chocolate, caramel, toffee, coffee bean and burnt toast. Slightly acrid smelling but the sweeter notes still come through in the nose.

Medium bodied with a blast of dry, bitter burnt malt flavor that lingers throughout into a lingering bone dry finish. Very roasted with a dominating burnt toast/espresso bean presence that overpowers the faint sweetness that lies underneath. Kind of smokey with hints of oatmeal, cocoa and toffee.

Chocolate coffee aroma with a hint of roasted-ness. Black with reddish-amber around the thin areas of the glass. Minimal head. Light bitter sweet taste that earns kudos for being extrordinarily complex!!! Full-bodied with a creamy texture that lingers temporarly after swallowing. Soft carbonation with a semi-abrupt bitter finish. Not a bad stout....

12oz bottle courtesy of dwm1034. Thanks!  Pours a jet black color with a light tan head and some lacing.  Aroma is chocolate, roasted malt.  A little thin on the palate with average carbonation.  Flavor is roasted malt, coffee, with a nice bitter coffee finish.

12oz bottle thanks to Colby, served in my Narke tulip. Review # 1200, tick beer #98 of the new crappy top beers list...An 11pm black pour, dark throughout. A light tan head that rises about three fingers, average retention but really nice think lacing, almost covers the whole glass...An aroma of roasted coffee and a little smoke. Not sweet malts at all but this is really nice, almost perfect roastiness very light sweet chocolate on the very back...The taste is shockingly sweet. The roastiness is gone, replaced by a very sweet chocolate with a hint of vanilla and dark fruits. A touch to sweet especially for the low abv but its totally 180 in taste is fun and refreshing...A light palate easy to drink.

A low abv stout that is super easy to drink and tasty. An A+ Englishish stout that you could just crush all day. WasnÂ’t expecting much but this is a great one.

Old rating.

Pours the color of coffee with a big bold tan-brown head. As the head dissipates, a medium thick lacing sticks to the glass all the way down.

Smells of caramel and molasses and other things dark, roasted, and delicious.

Tastes like caramel and coffee flavors up front with a mild hoppy finish that really balances the initial flavors. There is a tiny spiciness that comes through the carbonation on the tongue.

Smooth and creamy, with a mildly fizzy carbonation to finish every swig

12 oz bottle from my recent trip to Minneapolis. A single from Zipps (Minneapolis, MN). Pours a  pretty much opaque black pour, good sizes dark brown head atop that cakes a bit, laces a ok and stays fairly large. Aromas are roasty and creamy, strange, almost sweetened lactose in there. Moving into roast and creamy silky chocolate, coffee, soda bread, and toast. Some caramel, toffee. Rich roast and sweetness. Initial is medium bodied, perhaps a bit fuller as some roasty malts come to the forefront, burnt coffee grounds, some caramel, toffee, dark cocoa and some more burnt roasty grains. Moves into sweet toffee and caramel, to temper the roast. A touch dry finish, moving into lingering roast and silky sweet malts of cocoa, toffee, and milky chocolate. A bit bitter, the beer is fairly balanced and full, not complex, but a by-the-book stout that does some work. Not bad.

Almost black, very dark pour with a tan head. Long lasting head retention. Looks delicious. Coffee and bitter chocolate on the aroma alongside smoke and a hint of dark fruit. Slightly creamy, medium-full body, low carbonation. Low alcohol warmth. Overall a great stout.

Pours opaque deep sable with not much head. Rich, oily aroma has firm coffee and chocolate tones - very inviting. Sweet, coffee-ish flavor has hints of chocolate and licorice and a bit of hops. Smooth, barely fizzy texture still leaves a persistent tingle.
bottle, walnut brown color with high tan foam, aroma is hoppy dry cocoa, espresso,molasses,  flavor of bitter cocoa, roast coffee, hoppy dry pine needles, bitter finish

Bottle @ hotelroom, Denver. Pours black with a huge tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, plums, coffee, milk chocolate. Taste roasted malts, chocolate, raisins, coffee. Medium to full body, medium carbonation. Overall a nice easy drinking stout. 050311

12 oz bottle in Portland....pours black...thin tan head....coffee malt nose; rich taste of roasted coffee / malts....very tasty ... excellent brew from Deschutes...glad there are 5 more on the porch...

Got a 12oz bottle in a trade with StumpyJoeJr (thanks, Ryan!)
Poured into a nonic pint glass.

A: Jet black but slightly translucent. Nice dark tan, foamy head that retains well but lacks lacing. 

S: Typical American stout with a light dairy quality, a touch of roasted malts and dark chocolate.

T:  This is everything I look for in an American Stout - sweet, tasty,  milky/oaty flavor up front and deeply roasted (almost burnt) malts on  the backend. Not quite as robust or complex as IÂ’d prefer, though. It  remains sweet throughout, but the malty notes fade as I drink on.  ThereÂ’s a touch of chocolate here, but I have to reach for it.

M: Not too thin, not too thick. Slightly fizzy on the tongue - very belch-inducing for a stout.

D:  Because the palate is flavorful, but not too intense and the body is  only medium, Deschutes Obsidian stout is dangerously drinkable. 6.4% ABV  actually seems a little high as this beer has the drinkability of a  more deliberately sessionable stout.

Overall, a good American  stout. IÂ’m surprised this beer is rated as high as it is because thereÂ’s  nothing here you canÂ’t find in any other American stout. Definitely a  solid performer, though.

NOTE: Watch the video version of this review at:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qT78unRljIs
A decent stout. Decent roasty flavor, ok bitterness.  A good stout, not amazing.

Pours smooth jet black with full, milk chocolaty brown head. Smells like roasted malts and barley, thatÂ’s it, if you donÂ’t like those smells you probably wonÂ’t like the smell of this. It has a strong roasty flavor, very little hop flavor, but very strong, roasted malt flavor. Full-bodied with a smooth, creamy texture and very mild mouth-carbonation, Deschutes Obsidian Stout has a malty finish and has a little lasting sweetness.

Bottle. A fantastic find, this is as smooth as the volcanic glass that inspired the beer.  Pitch black with ample off white head.  A roasty, malty slightly sweet aroma that carries through into the taste.  This is smooth, velvety, on the sweet side of balanced with toasty, roasty, nuttry flavours not the mouth puckering bitterness and astringency of most stouts.  Easy drinking and moreish.

Bottle.

A - Very dark, opaque black color. Good sized, rocky, sticky, fluffy, creamy, cafe colored head. Very nice retention leaving a thick creamy lace.

S - Wonderful aroma full of chocolate (both mild and dark), coffee, roasted malt and an earthy tone. Chocolate and coffee are the strongest. Touches of citrus and grassy hops. Touches of hops provide a nice kick with the strong stout aroma.

T - Great mix of dark chocolate and coffee provide the strongest flavors. Nice bittersweet flavors. Slightly burnt/toasted dark malt that fits the bittersweet flavor profile. Earthy tones come out mid sip. Finishes with a nice citrus and slightly earthy and grassy hop kick. Very enjoyable beer.

M - Medium body with adequate carbonation. Smooth although not quite as full as I would want.

D - Very easy to drink. Balanced with great chocolate and coffee flavors and a nice hoppy taste showing up. Goes down easy, with a somewhat low ABV (for an American stout) and loads of flavors.

Notes: Best by 04/21/11. Very tasty stout that is incredibly easy to drink. Has a nice hop kick toward the finish that compliments the bittersweet chocolate and coffee flavors. Overall a joy to drink and a great price.

Tap @ THE Steakout Saloon. Dark brown/black appearance with a one finger creamy tan head. Dark roasted and slightly burnt chocolate malts in the nose. Creamy (nitro) mouthfeel. Flavor is a fairly roasty chocolate malty body that has a slightly burnt taste. Roasted chocolate finish.

bottle.  pours black with a 1 finger tan head.  chocolate and coffee on the nose with a touch of licorice and dark fruit.  smooth creamy solid body with more chocolate notes, big roasted malts, coffee, sweet dark fruits and a touch of bitterness.  chocolate and roasted coffee finish that sticks around for a bit.  solid stout.

Bottle.  Pours a ruby and cola hued dark brown with a large tanned beige head.  Chocolate and coffee on the nose, toast and a light sweetness.  Medium bodied, lightly sweet at first before moving into a more pronounced roast note.  Dark caramel and roast.  Finishes up with a slow gentle roast bitterness.  Easy drinking and quite tasty.
Awsome beer with a roasted flavor, pour is dark and smooth. Has medium malty head
Pours black with tan head and some lacing.  Notes of roasted coffee and dark chocolate.  Well balanced taste with short bitter finish.  Smooth and creamy.

Pours a solid black with a thin tan head that dissipates quickly. Aroma is a roasty chocolaty affair with some dried fruit and a touch of hop aroma for good measure. Taste follows the smell, but lingers with a bit of ash in the finish. Full body, creamy texture, ample carbonation. If not for the ash in the finish IÂ’d love this beer. As is its still good, just not spectacular.
Pours a nice dark brown (not quite as inky black as some imperials) with thin to medium head. Very strong roasted grain flavor overpowers some of the other elements in the beer.
Bottle from Cavie.  Obsidian pour (!) with a small brown head.  Aroma is roasted, coffee, molasses, and a little chocolate.  Taste is very roasted, lots of dark chocolate, and plenty bitter.

Bottle courtesy Sparky. Pours a very dark brown to black color with a beige head. Aroma is a lovely chocolate coffee roast with heavy dark malts. Nice aroma. Flavor is heavy roast, dark bitter malts, chocolate and some smoky tones as well. This finishes dark and bitter. Very good.

pitch black with large white head.  nose of roasted malt with some medium crystal.  some bitterness before some medium crystal and a lot of black and some chocolate malt coming through.  a lot of english yeast esters in this and a touch of floral english style hops.  a moderate amount of residual sweetness in this brew that does leave it mildly cloying by the end of the 12 ounces.  overall though not out of touch with an english style stout, a very nice version

Poured into a pint glass.

4.0 A: Used motor oil black. Two fingers of frothy tan head that retains well and leaves lots of lacing.

4.0 S: Semi-sweet chocolate comes out first. Some molasses and roasted malts. Mild hoppiness as well. Pleasant, but weaker than IÂ’d like.

4.0 T: Strange chalky roasted flavor. Healthy bitterness that seems like it comes from coffee rather than hops. There is a bit, but not too much coffee flavor. Lots of burnt flavor.

3.5 M: Lighter medium body. Good carbonation and smooth enough, even with the burnt flavors.

4.0 D: Not bad. Would like to see the burnt flavors supplemented with some malty sweetness though.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-28-2009 00:56:32
12oz bottle. Super black pour, thick and oily. Thin brown head with oily lacing. Dark chocolate and roasted malts in the aroma. Chocolate flavor and easy to drink.

355mL bottle.  Pours black with faint brown highlights, a medium head that slowly settles and leaves a decent amount of lacing.  Aroma of roasted malt, caramel and dark fruit.  Roasted flavour, mild-medium sweetness.  Medium bodied, soft carbonation, silky smooth with a lingering roasty finish.

aroma- licorice, smoke, olives, grass, roasted malt, very light sugar.  pours black with tan lingering head, some lacing.  taste is roasted malt, alcohol, licorice, black coffee, light chocolate, light sugar, light smoke.  palate is medium bodied with some carbonation, smooth.  A solid stout.

Notes from 12/23/2010
12 oz. bottle

Ar: Burnt coffee, bitter chocolate, and a bit of smoke.
Ap: Beautiful black with a pillowy 1" cinnamon head that refuses to dissipate and leaves good lace.
T: Medium sweetness for a stout, huge coffee background.  Slightly metallic.  Still nice.
P: Medium body, medium carbonation.  As expected.

O: Good stout.

Bottle from a Portland buddy.  Black pour with a decent beige head.  Left lots of lace.  Aroma was quite subtle, roasted malts mixed in with some metallic notes and that general off smell that comes with generic run of the mill stouts.  Nothing upsets me more when this comes out in a stout.  Flavors were light roast, metal and a soapy presence.  Nothing to rave about here, somewhat disappointing all around...

Draught, Toronado, San Francisco.  Black as a ravens wing with a small tan head. Decent nose with dark chocolate, roasted malt and coffee notes. These themes continued on into the flavour accompanied by a hint of some dark fruit. Nice n smooth fullish body and mouthfeel. Dried out somewhat towards the finish. Well executed and tidy stout.

UPDATED: SEP 7, 2012 BB Mar 2010 Tasted Sept 2012
Travelling well. Chocolate and sweet stones on the nose. Palate is dull, by comparison, but still a pleasant drink. Some bitter roast and faint chocolate with a sweet fruit tingle underlay.  I wouldnÂ’t think thereÂ’s much point in cellaring further. (score relates to original tasting)
BB Mar 2010Tasted Dec 2010
Fairly straight ahead and full flavoured for the style. Very dark brown in the glass with no head. Nose shows faint dark chocolate and a hint of roast. All quite subtle really. More chocolate in the palate but quite a bit sweeter and more obvious. Very smooth and soft in line with the commercial descriptor, although the flavours do harden a touch on the finish.

Bottle served in a Guinness pint. Obsidian pour with a beige top. Decent retention and lacing. Dark chocolate and roast on the nose. Flavor is quite sweet for a stout. Medium-full body, creamy and thick texture, bitter finish with more dark chocolate sweetness showing.
Bottle. Pours a deep blackish brown body with nice brown lacing. Aroma is chocolate and roast. Mouthfeel is smooth and slightly dry with great light roasty notes.

Pours black with a small dark head.
Nose shows intense roasted coffee and dark chocolate with a hint of smoke. Very nice.
Very similar flavours, lots of roasted malt and coffee beans with more noticeable smoke. Finishes with a light roasty bitterness.
Carbonation is a little too high.

Black pour with brown edges and a small, dense, tan head.  The aroma has notes of rolled oats, with a mild balance of dark fruit, chocolate, coffee, and tobacco.  The flavor is similar to the aroma.  ItÂ’s a bit sharp though with notes of dark chocolate and a bitter coffee finish.  The body is a bit thin but creamy with lots of carbonation.
Bottle with patfannon and jredmond. Pours a coke black with little head. Nose is a slightly toasty. Taste is a rounded chocolate with just a little burnt roast. Finishes very quick and clean. Nice.

bottle from lagunitashomer.  Thanks TIM!  pours deep brown with a big tan head.  aroma of doughy malt balls and stale chocolate.  weird musty basement rotten coffee note that was slightly offputting.   Taste is a bunch of nice clean roast, dark chocolate, peppered espresso.  pretty nice.   taste>aroma.   clean and crisp.  nice body.   bitter, roasty chocolate espresso beer.   taste reminded me a bit of the hitachino espresso stout I had the other day.  pretty solid beer, despite the weird musty malt ball note.  like.
Black with a tan head, chocolaty roasted malt aroma. Full body, tastes like it smells plus a bitter dry finish. A good stout that doesnÂ’t break the bank.

Bottle.  Big notes of roasted malts, molasses, coffee, chocolate and piny hops.  Very dark brown that sits black in the glass.  Average off-white head that left some lace and mostly diminished.  Taste is heavy sweet and heavy bitter.  Palate is full bodied and oily soft.  Overall a tasty stout that is full bodied, rich and creamy.  Good.

Chocolate pour. Vanilla, chocolate, oak, molasses, honey on the nose.  This stuff smells fantastic. Mouthfeel is lighter, low in carbonation, dryer palate.  Good but not great.

From sample pour at local December 2010 tasting.

On tap during my wife and IÂ’s lovely trip to Bend, OR in August 2009.

A: Pours jet black with a nice deep tan head.

S: Loads of chocolate atop a slightly sweet roasted malt base.

T: Good amount of chocolate alongside coffee and roasted malt. Nice balance between everything.

M: Medium body with lighter carbonation and a bit of a chewy nature.

D: Very nice all around. Nothing too outstanding, but a quaffable, fairly low abv dark brew, which IÂ’m always happy to find.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 05-07-2010
12 oz bottle from Fred Meyer - Pours black with a brown head.  Roasty aroma and flavor.  A little bit sweet coffee flavor.  Very nice.

Somehow during my all day drinkfest at Deschutes I never drank this but here at the airport IÂ’ve got a bottle to hit up. Black brew with small tan cap (tiny glass didnÂ’t help my wimpy pour), messy lacing. Large dark roasted aroma, rich coffee, dark fruity sweetness, plums, blood orange, notably hopped, almond? (my new favorite descriptor). Very nice nose. More chocolate as it warms. Tasty and yummo. Deep roast, instant mild bitterness, light pine and herbal notes, Some chocolate, nuts, biscuit. Tasty beer thankfully light on coffee. Finishes with ample carbonation and a rich malty aftertaste and a light tang.

Thick malt chocolate coloured head very dark stout aeomas coffee with a milky vanilla added touch liccorice caramel richness flavour now it is more coffee bean and roasted bitter taste smooth caramel vanilla and liccorice goes down the gullet nicely mild fizz on the tongue at the finish dry bitter lasting taste sweet malt not over done well above average stout

355ml bottle. Pours thick and black like sticky tar with a modest and level later of dark brown foam, Chocolate and burnt roasted malt aroma and a light silky mouthfeel and flavour of bitter chocolate. Well balanced and very enjoyable.

Black pour with a creamy tan head. Nice roasted, malty, oat aroma. Slight bitterness that follows through. Heavy body, creamy feel with strong carbonation that punches past creaminess. This beer was great all  on its own on a Friday afternoon, another delicious stout to add to the list.

Not the best IÂ’ve had from the brewer but is still a very solid stout.  Good nose with a bit of roasted malt up front that finishes with some medium bitterness.  Nice overall flavor with nice alcohol content to boot.

Bottled sample. Jet black in colour with moderate carbonation. Aromas are of chocolate syrup, char, and earth. Well balanced in the mouth, with elements of dark chocolate, coffee, roasted malt, herbal hops, and caramel all playing a part. Medium bodied, with a dry flinty finish. Very nice.
This is a great stout, definately one I would love to try and brew myself. Good rich roasty malt aroma and flavour, full-bodied mouthfeel. YUMMM!!!

bottle.  Pours very deep brown, pretty much black, with creamy tan head.  Rich aroma of chocolate roast, sweet vanilla malt.  Flavor at first presents bitter dark chocolate, coffee, and then recedes to a sweetness, although ultimately the bitter characteristics dominate the finish.  Medium to full bodied, smooth, nice.

Bottle. Brownish black with a tan head that fades to a good coat then lingers. Aroma has charred malt, coffee, hints of dark berries and mint (?!). Smooth texture is not quite oily. Just slightly carbonated. Taste has plenty of roasted bitterness, cocoa, some coffee astringency. Caramel and berry sweetness is there but mostly buried. Dry finish has roasted and piney hop bitterness with some salt and ash. Slightly muddled finish and something slightly jarring in the aroma, but a good stout all the same.

Bottle - Pours jet black with a massive foamy tan head. Looks beautiful. Smell is odd. ThereÂ’s a metallic/menthol smell in there that mingles with some light ash and charcoal. ThereÂ’s also a sweet frutiness that seems out of place. The taste isnÂ’t any better. A bit of whiskey sharpness (in a 6.4% beer?) sits on top of an off-putting bitter roast. Tastes like stale coffee. Real bitter roast lingers on the tongue through the finish, along with a stale hop note. Palate is slick and watery, with a bit of carbonation that bites a bit. Everything feels off in this beer. I was looking forward to this...did I get a bad bottle?
Bottle thanks to 5000. Pours black with tan head. Nose of chocolate, roasted malts and coffee. Taste is roasted chocolate malt, coffee and vanilla. Medium body.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a very dark brownish black with a two finger light tan head with good retention and strong lacing.  Aroma has a strong roastiness, a bit of coffee and some dark chocolate and a bit of nuttiness.  Light hops as well.  Initial taste is nuttiness with some coffee.  Middle palate is strong with roasted malt.  Finish is dark, unsweetened chocolate with some bitterness.  Medium body.  A little bit oily in the mouth.  Medium carbonation.

black color. thin tan head.
aroma is bitter cocoa, coffee and some dark fruitiness. 
flavour is creamy coffee and cocoa.

On Tap at the Vine Street Pub, Denver 14/09/2010 (Nitro)
Fruity and slightly spicy aroma. Beige head. Dark red coloured hoppy and smooth on the palate with a hint of bitterness in a dry roast finish.

12 oz bottle from the Four Firkins.  Deep brown pour with a luscious creamy tan head.  Amazing aroma, roasted chocolate with a hint toffee and coffee.  Velvety smooth mouthfeel with just enough carbonation to make the flavors jump on the tongue.  Flavor isnÂ’t as prominent as the aroma, but some nice chocolate notes in it.  Lingering coffee/chocolate finish thatÂ’s a little bitter but very enjoyable.

12 ounce bottle purchased a year ago at Total Wine in Tustin ($1.29).  Pours a very dark brown (practically black) with one finger of brown foam.  Aroma of dusty roasted malts, smoke, and some creamy chocolate.  Flavor has a smooth roastiness and smooth dark chocolate, but also some lightty sweet dark fruit notes.  Smooth bitter chocolate finish -- smoothness is a hallmark of this brew.  Not overly complex but nicely balanced.  A very good stout.  (697, 386)
Very dark almost black in color. Taste a light coffee flavor and a light chocolate taste. A very goos stout.

Pours a beautiful jet black crowned by a huge foamy nut-brown head. Aroma is coffee and malt. Nice viscosity - thick and creamy on the palate. Taste is coffee, malt, chocolate, dark roasted malt and molasses. Excellent flavor. This stout pairs well with cheese and sausage and/or any red meats off the grill.

The color is black with a fizzy but sticky cream-colored head that leaves a tangled web of lacing all the way down the glass. The aroma is a mild combination of chocolate and dark caramel sweetness. In contrast, the flavor has a big bitter chocolate flavor and a subtle underlying sweetness. The heavily roasted malts are right out in front, but rather than being harsh, the dark roasted malts are quite mellow, allowing the flavor to shine without overpowering with bitterness. A fizzy carbonation makes this one go down easily, but I think I would have preferred a creamier texture.

Bottle to snifter. Pour is black brown with a tan head. Aroma of roasted nuts and chocolate and licorice. Taste is bitter hops with some hints of coffee and coco. Palate is chaulky and dry. Solid stout.
This beer have a great full body taste.  You know what and why you are drinking this good classic deschutes stout

UPDATED: OCT 19, 2014 being one of my favorite stouts for a few years now, itÂ’s hard to believe i thought it was too bitter when i first tried it...but i wasnÂ’t a hop head yet. Not that itÂ’s an overly hoppy stout, but there is a great balance and complexity between the roasted malt flavors and the bittering hops. Excellent full feel

Bottle, aged over a year. Best by 12/09. Nose is rich chocolate with light acidity, roast, and caramel. Black with no head. Very rich dark chocolate flavor with light coffee notes. Extremely dry. Good texture.
Pours pitch black, nose is roasty, taste is thin, mildly bitter, with a heavy roast character.

Another great beer sent from Hayduke.  Deep black with red and a one finger tan head.  Aroma is not big and has roasted nuts with earth.  Flavors seem to resonate in the back of my mouth.  Well hopped flavor adds both sourness and bitterness.  Roasted flavor, a bit of smoke, subtle chocolate, molasses.  Delicious!
UPDATED: DEC 20, 2010 Consumed with Travlr in Tucson. Minimal head, nice dark color. Mild smoke behind a chocolate finish. Sweet for the first half, smokey for the second.

12oz bottle pours motor oil black with a medium tan head.  Aroma is heavily chocolate and cocoa and malt roasted to the point of being blackened.  Flavor brings that extreme blackened malt bitterness up front with dark roast coffee and a touch of bitter dark chocolate.  Smooth, but a slight twangy finish keeps it from reaching that mythical 5/5 stage.  Good brew from Oregon.
Excellent stout.  nice chocolate aroma.  Thick black pour with thin brown head.  Full body with just the right balance of dark chocolate, slight coffee and black licorice notes.  Excellent
From 12oz,black in color,brown head,a very good chocolate flavor to the beer and itÂ’s a great stout.

Rating #250 after nearly a year on not rating.  Apperarance is total darkness that even bright light does not pentrate.  Nose is full of roasty coffee notes and very faint hint of chocolate covered cherries.  Medium bodied mouthfeel - just about spot-on for the style IMHO.  Flavor is all about the coffee-like biterness - very nice!
Good solid stout. Great tasty slightly Malty but smooth taste with a hint of Chocolate. For a widely availble stout this beer can be a respit in Nascar country.
Solid black, milky, creamy, frothy light brown head. Aroma of caramel, roasted malts, mild hop. Taste has lots of dark roasted malts, some burnt. Medium body, smooth silky texture. Very good stuff.

UPDATED: OCT 9, 2011 Had to re-rate this one.  The first bottle I had mustÂ’ve been over aged or somehow contaminated because round 2 tasted nothing similar.  Black, with a robust rocky light khaki head.  Aroma of roasted black malt grains, a tinge of licorice, and a tinge of burnt coffee grounds.  Flavor was pretty close to the same--dark roastiness, toasted grains, with a background of bitter coffee, but not as coffee toned as I hoped.  Flavor is a little simple--roasty, and just dry.

On tap and had a beautiful cascading pour. Deep dark with a lively beautiful head.  Lush velvety texture and pillowy foam make this a wonder to behold.  Easy to sip with a robust malted toastyness with hints of chocolate, vanilla and charcoal. Great mouthfeel.  Aroma is rather thinned but has a dusty burnt marshmallow vibe to it.  Taste is simple with lingering holes of complexity which vanish quickly into the overall simplicity.  Easy to drink, not much space in the notebook needed, as it is what it is.
Draugh, JackÂ’s Bar, SF. Nitro-poured, black and very malty with a ripe berry taste flavour and rich aftertaste. Finish verges on dry.

Medium, rather dense beige head over black beer. Cucumber - fresh cucumber! Greenmalt the reason? Some hops definitely too. Very discreet burnt/roasted malt notes. Again something like fresh vegetables, if not really as convincingly cucumber. Warming up (too) much liquorice. Despite the polar serving temperature, obviously full-bodied, some alcoholwarming. Great, if not really excellent stout, with a surprising nose.

I had this as part of a sampler at Deschutes in Portland, OR.  Great dry stout, creamy cocoa and chocolate, little nutty, roasty.  Would definitely have this again in a larger glass, with more in it than what I had.

[emailÂ protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Black chocolate and some coffee aroma. Few sweetness, very roasted, good stout. It had to grow on me, I really wasnÂ’t convinced from the start. But itÂ’s OK.

Serving: Bottle. 
It pours pitch black with ruby highlights and a rich tan head.  The nose is very roasty with lots of dark, roasted malt and lots of dark fruit.  The roasted malt makes a reappearance in the taste but the dark fruit is much lighter.  Notes of earth and mineral add to the flavor as well.  The body is medium to rich and actually lighter than I was expecting.  Average carbonation with a lingering bitter finish.  Overall this one wasnÂ’t as spectacular as the ratings would have me believe.  Still, it is a very solid stout.
Great malty and coffee aromas right away. Good clarity and color but not a very good flavor or mouthfeel. It was a fairly thin beer even forced with nitrogen. Expected a much smoother creamier beer.

Nitro tap at Rose & Crown.

This beer pours black, like the volcanic rock (sorry, I stole that from the description) with a two-finger tan head and great lacing.

Aroma is a little muted by the nitro foam, but a little straining of the nostrils reveals a pleasant smell of rich chocolate and roasted malts, with maybe a little coffee as well.

This is a solid, satisfying beer with a rich roasted malt flavor (sorry, stole that from the description again).  Damn, this one is chocolatey.  The dark chocolate Ghirardelli chips I am eating for breakfast this morning as I write this (breakfast of champions I know) remind me of this beer.  It is roasty as well, with notes of coffee and charred volcanic ash, which is fitting given the name.

Extremely smooth on the mouthfeel, which I know is helped by the nitro, with medium-full body.  Some slight drying from the roastiness.

This beer reminds me of the worldÂ’s largest obsidian flows at Newberry Volcano--just a few miles south of the brewery. "The Big Obsidian Flow," as they call it, covers more than 700 acres with shiny black obsidian.  (Yep, stole that too.)  Ok, hereÂ’s something original: This beer was good.  I liked it.

12oz bottle, best by 7/2/10, from south bay. pours a very dark brown, almost black as obsidian, with a thin, whispy, khaki head leaving a tight ring of lace. aroma is very nice with dark, roasted malts, light coffee, black licorice, and earthy hops with a touch of nutty caramel. flavor is great with big flavors of milk chocolate, iced coffee, and roasted malts with a touch of charred grain and smoked almonds. palate is medium bodied and very smooth with low carbonation and a lingering, roasty and slightly bitter finish. overall, a very solid stout.

UPDATED: AUG 7, 2012 Just pouring this beer into the glass makes my mouth water.  IÂ’m not a huge fan of stouts (with the exception of imperial stouts), but this one is an exception.  If itÂ’s from Deschutes, it has to be good.  Especially when the beer (as this one) falls in the 99th percentile for both style and overall.  It pours a nice, solid black color with light sediment, forming a light-brown, very stiff and frothy head and very thick, strong lacing that stretches the entire length of the glass.  

Its aroma is delicious, with a slightly predominant note of chocolate, followed by light roasted malt and a hint of dryness.  It also has floral, almost spiced notes as well.  In the mouth itÂ’s easy-going  and just a little soapy.  ItÂ’s more dry than the aroma lets on, and the sweet chocolate aroma transforms into a bitter cocoa powder flavor.  Residual sweetness is just barely delivered, but overpowered by an almost oxidized, highly roasted malt bitterness.   

Overall, itÂ’s easy but very respectable.  Not a wimpy stout, for sure, but still really enjoyable and surely satisfies malt cravings.

ItÂ’s probably not fair for me to keep rating stouts, porters, etc., because theyÂ’re really not my style. But my wife likes them and keeps getting them, so I keep trying them. This one, completely ordinary stout across the board.

12oz. Pours a deep brown/black, dark khaki/coffee head with minor retention and a tiny bit of fine lacing. Smells of roasted malt and coffee, malt sweetness, and a tiny tiny bit of hop. A dark chocolate type flavor at the beginning, mellows to more of a coffee/roast flavor, tapers to a bit of hop bitterness at the tip of the tongue. Medium body, medium carbonation, slightly slick texture.

On tap at the Draught House.  Pours a near opaque body with some tan showing through.  Smooth, creamy nitro head that left lots of lacing   Aroma is very roasty, day old coffee, quite a bit of hops coming through and some light sweet notes.  Flavor is cocoa, fresh coffee and dark chocolate.  Nitro makes this one kind of like a creamy choco-beer smoothy.  Nice coffee bitter finish and a medium full mouthfeel and body.  IÂ’m the neighbor of the Beast at rating #667!!!!
black with thin light tan head.  roasty aroma with bitter chocolate flavor.  Some hops in there too

Bottle.  Poured black with a huge, creamy, light brown head.  Nose is roasted malt and chocolate.  Medium body with good carbonation.  Flavor is cocoa, roasted malt, and slight ash.  Finishes with some coffee-ish bitterness.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a very dark brown with a nice tan head.  Nose of coffee, dark chocolate, and burnt malt.  Taste is rich, complex, and smooth.  Quite dry, lots of dark malts and coffee with some mellow earthy hops coming through.  A great example of what a stout can and should be.

UPDATED: JAN 13, 2016 1/16 re-rating some old stouts; lowered from 3.8.  still a great aroma (8) but flavor was too roasted and overpowered everything else.  stouts have tough competition.....................found at AJÂ’s  while on vacation in Phoenix,   first Deschutes.
Dark black pout w/small dark tan frothy head.  long lasting with lacing.
roasted smell.  Very roasted taste (not sure if it was chocolate and/or coffee) but good;  borderline too much roasted flavor...
UPDATED: DEC 30, 2013 Nitro tap. Black pour with huge tan nitro head. Smells like cocoa. Creamy mouthfeel. Tastes like milk chocolate and roasted malt. Beautiful beer.

Pours a black color with a big thick head and some good lace. The aroma is oatmeal & roasty coffee with some really good floral hoppiness and some licorice. The flavor follows but is more centered around the licorice, deep roasty coffee shows up with some good bitterness both from roastiness and some fruity hops. Really damn nice beer.

12 oz. bottle from South Bay Drugs.  Pours a very dark brown, opaque and almost black, wkth a rocky, brown head that leaves some sloppy lacing behind.  Aroma of milk chocolate, coffee, roasted malts, earthy hops, dirt, and cocoa powder.  Flavor of milk chocolate, coffee, roasted matls, dirt, earth, hops, cocoa powder, and brown sugar.  Medium-bodied, with average carbonation.  Feels like any other good stout in the mouth.  I like this one.  Thanks, Joey!

On-Tap at the Fathers Office. Pours dark-brown/black with a XXXL nitro-mix head. Allowed to settle and watch the rise to the top for a short while. Chocolate and roasty aromas. Chocolate and some espresso flavours among a dry malty finish with a touch of citrus.. I look forward to experiencing this one in the bottle..

Ridiculously good. Blackish-brown in appearance. Solid light brwn head that is so dense and thick it stays on top of the beer until the beer is gone.... Just incredible and a huge contributor t the enjoyment. Lacing is like a brwn curtain all the way down the side of the glass. Clean spring water, toasty malt aroma. Chocolately, smooth taste with milk, sugar, and the kiss of bittering hops.  Velvetly mouthfeel, fleecy, smooth finish. And chocolately.

12 oz. bottle- Pours black with a nice thick tan head, aroma is coffee and sweet chocolate malt. The flavor is malt and suprisingly hoppy, kind of a dry stout, but very good. I wish this beer tasted as good as it smells, oh well still a defining beer of the style.

(bottle - 12 oz) Dark black pour with a thick and creamy looking tan head. Malty and rather smokey aroma. Dark and heavily roasted malt and barley in the aroma with a mild touch of coffee and really nicely smoked malts. Smokey and roasted at the beginning of the flavor with a very nice and dark malt middle. Bitter and coffee-like flavors at the finish with a lingering bitterness and a bitter and heavy roasted aftertaste. Creamy and easy to drink. All around really, really nice stout.

Bottle. Thanks to Mes. Black with a pale brown head. Aroma: Roasted/toasted malt, chocolate, coffee, some kind of fruitiness. Flavor: Roasted/burned malt, bitter hops, bitter dark chocolate, ash, coffee, dark fruit, some sweetness in there to, maybe some alcohol. Tasty, easy drinking stout. Oopps!, didnÂ´t notice the 6.4% until the bottle was nearly finished.

12 oz bottle into English pint. CanÂ’t believe I havenÂ’t rated this classic yet. Aromas of roasted malt, brown sugar, black coffee. Pours opaque black with a thick tan head which dissipates in a few minutes, leaving a nice long retaining centimeter thick head and sticky lacing. Taste is sweet at first and finishes just slightly bitter. Carbonation is medium. Fairly creamy mouthfeel. Could be bigger bodied. Overall, a very nice stout, but not as good as I remember it. I havenÂ’t had one in a few years.

Reviewed 1/14/2010:

(Bottle BB 2/4/10): Pours a dark black color body, average tan head, somewhat lasting.  Dark roasty aroma, alcoholy.  Some sweetness, coffee.  Funky taste, coffee aftertaste.  Light body, somewhat watery.  Some ash, but not heavy.  A bit of wildness too.  Not so tasty.

Bottle. Pours a deep black, medium opacity, with a thick tan head that laces extremely well. Nose is very roasty, notes of black licorice, coffee, sweet malt (oats?) vanilla. bitter chocolate, mild smoke. Flavors of smoke, deep roast barley, vaguely "meaty", plus sweet oats, instant coffee, , slight metallic note in the finish. Damn tasty for something you can buy at pretty much any gas station in Montana!

Dark black, big beauty coco head -- treasure? dog food? -- sweet tar, dark cooking chocolate -- what way? angel pie -- medium roast level, pleasing mouthfeel -- Hey bud, take a break and go smoke a fatty -- A good brew..
Draught from draught house.  Poured dark, chocolate and malts with medium mouthfeel. not bad.

Smells like chocolate and coffee beans and a heavy malt roast. Appearance is opaque black with a small head that clings to the glass. Initial flavor is like roasted coffee beans that segues into bakerÂ’s chocolate and back into coffee and malt. The whole time throughout there is a light bitterness (a trait of both of the dominant flavors) that gives bite. Pleasantly carbonated and a little dusty feeling, maybe even a little greasy/oily.

A black beer with a great looking head. The aroma is coffee, & roasted burnt barley-very nice. The taste is  roasted, bitter chocolate,& coffee. The roasted flavors in this are very nice & does seem like an Imp. Stout that is lighter yet has a lot of flavor. A solid stout.
12 oz. bottle, pours black with a huge tan head. Aroma is roasted malt and espresso. Exceptionally creamy mouthful, with a dark roasted malt and espresso flavour and a thick finish. Excellent stout!

(draught at draught house in Austin, tx) pours deep brown with creamy nitro head, excellent lacing. Nose of brown sugar, coffee and cream. Taste of fudge, dark chocolate and coffee.  Nice creamy thick finish.
tap at draught house.  black with a creamy head.  nose is chocolate, roasted malts and more chocolate.  smooth palate, big flavors of creamy chocolate, roasted malts and more chocolate.

Sample at the brewpub. Pours black with a medium thin and compact beige head that recedes slowly. Sticky sheet of lacing on the glass. Roasty malt aroma with notes of coffee and anise. Medium to full, dry body with a roasty character and grainy hops, malt and coffee flavors. Some hoppy notes as well. The finish is toasted malt and coffee with a lingering bittersweet chocolate aftertaste. Pretty good overall.
On nitro at Draught House.  Really nice roasty flavor and aroma, plus the nitro gives it a great creamy mouthfeel.  Medium body.  Low bitterness.  Delicious!

12oz bottle poured into a pint glass. Dark black with a decent tan head. The smell was roasty but subdued. The taste was also standard stout to me: roasty, no hops, good , dark, smooth.this was a nice beer.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-09-2007 16:14:23

UPDATED: MAY 8, 2011 Bottle. Pours a smooth creamy black with an inch of thick, light brown head. Aroma is dark roasted malts, caramel and bitter chocolate. Taste begins with strong roasted malt sweetness along with dark roast coffee, caramel and chocolate to round it out. It finishes sweet and malty with a smoky aftertaste.  Overall flavor is roasty, sweet and smooth.

Pours dark brown and inky with a large tan head, very good clinging lacing.  Aromas of coffee, dark chocolate, figs, sugarcane and some light grassy notes.  Medium-full body, velvety, and a bit sharp.  Flavors of coffee, chocolate, bread, some plum mid-palate, and a long mild-bitter grassy finish.  Well balanced.

A truly bad ass beer. A milky aroma with some good hop lurking back in there. It become full of delicious coffee and chocolate flavours. Super bitter dryness at the end from the delightful hopping.  Hyper drinkable. Loves it.
Pours deep black with a nice brown head.Got the aroma of sweet robust rosted malt and coffee.The flavor is a nice balance of bitterness and sweetness.The mouthfeel is real smooth.Very nice beer.

"One of the many Deschutes bottles sent by slowrunner, thanks again! Black/brown color with an inch thick head and very heavy lacing. The beer looks extraordinary. Lots of burnt/roasted malt aromas along with nuts, heavy cream and mild chocolate. A very robust aroma indeed. Medium bodied, highly bitter and fairly creamy. Flavor is nutty and leads to a nice milk chocolate and toast angle followed by toffee and black licorice. Nice stout, itÂ’s robust yet easy on the palate."

12 oz bottle pours dark brownish black with a good spot of tan head into a pint glass.  Aroma of cocoa, coffee, plenty of malt, roasty, faint hops detectable, toasted bread.  Much more roasted malt than I remember, yum.  Bitterness of the hops is nice and balances well.  Finishes with bakerÂ’s chocolate, loads of espresso, bit of spice, slightly woody and earthy.  Fluffy mouthfeel with medium carbonation; medium to full bodied.  This is a hell of a lot nicer and fuller than I remember it being while still retaining decent drinkability.  Very nice.

UPDATED: MAR 7, 2010 Deschutes Brewing Company--Obsidian Stout--1997 Release--12 oz. Bottle--6.74% ABV.  (4.75 / 5.0)  Stout--Deep dark black color.  Floral hops slowly overwhelmed by fruity roasted chocolate malt body.  Evolves to rich chocolate flavor.  Light palate, chalky thick texture.  Long lingering finish ends dry.  Sampled 4/11/1999.

Deschutes Brewing Company--Obsidian Stout--Black Pack--2001 Release--12 oz. Bottle.  6.70% ABV.  (4.75 / 5.0)  Stout--Opaque dark black color.  Roasted nut front with mild floral fruit notes.  Creamy roasted body with dry sweetness and rich strong mellow roasted flavors.  Chalky roasted flavors in easy smooth lingering end.  Sampled 7/16/2001.

Deschutes Brewing Company--Obsidian Stout--Hopvine Bottle--2002 Release--12 oz. Bottle.  6.70% ABV.  (4.25 / 5.0)	Stout--Light lacy espresso head.  Dark obsidian color.  Roasted mild espresso cocao hoppy front.  Dry sweet roasted burnt black creamy mild chocolate espresso body.  Crisp!  Clean chalky balanced rich hop spice end.  Sampled 1/5/2003.

Deschutes Brewing Company--Obsidian Stout--Graphics Overhaul--Hopvine Bottle--2004 Release--12 oz. Bottle--6.40% ABV--45 IBUÂ’s.  (4.5 / 5.0)   Stout--New Recipe?--Mild lace head.  Clear obsidian black color.  Roasted mild hop front.  Smooth rich roasted sweet creamy chocolate malt body  .Smooth sweet mild hot balanced hop finish.  Rich smooth and not too big.  Sampled 9/19/2004.

Deschutes Brewery--Obsidian Stout--Original--2009 12 oz.  Bottle.  6.40% ABV--55 IBUÂ’s.  (4.5 / 5.0)  Thin espresso mild lace head.  Clear opaque dark obsidian black red edge color.  Rich roasted cocoa hop mild fruit front.  Crusty dry sweet burnt dark chocolate rich clean roasted malt body.  Balanced rich hop spice crisp Stout end.  Rich not sweet NW Classic.  Sampled 3/7/2010.  6-Pack $6.99.

Bottle courtesy of Justin from TBS...thanks.  Opaque brown/black, brown head.  Smell is hardcore coffee with some dark chocolate.  Taste is the same.  Very impressive, very complex taste.  Starts bitter with the coffee taste, then finishes with the dark chocolate.  Great balance of bitter and sweet.

Pours black with red edges. Nice roasty aroma, good and chocolaty with prominent dark fruit. Mouthfilling roast flavours of coffee and chocolate, a dry hoppy bitterness. Long roasty finish with a nice hop lingering too. A beautiful subtle, hoppy stout with hops complimenting the roast, not competing.

12 ounce bottle courtesy of Sparky27. Thanks! Pours a deep, dark brown color with a medium brown head. Good head retention and lacing. Aroma of roasted malts, sweet sugary notes and light notes of nuts and coffee. Taste is roasted malts, sweet coffee notes and a bitter leafy hop finish. Smooth, medium bodied. Refreshing and very sessionable. Good stout.

Bottle. Pours dark brown with a creamy beige head. Rich chocolate malt, coffee and a presence of fruity tones. Such a good balance, nice creamy mouthfeel. A subtle roastiness comes through as this warms too. More chocolate in the finish. A delicious stout.

UPDATED: DEC 13, 2009 Bottle as shown. Pours a very dark brown almost black with a small creamy light tan head that diminishes quickly leaving decent spotty lacing along the glass. The aroma is a roasted malt with coffee, dark fruit, and chocolate. Medium mouthfeel with a dry rich malt with roast and coffee with a nice dry finish. Hides alcohol well making it easy to drink, a good Stout from Deschutes.
A 12oz bottle. The beer poured a black body with a brown head. The smell is of choloat malts. The taste is a coffe and roasted malts. Good carbonation.

Rich jet black. Thick coffee crema head that lingers like a pint of guiness. Light smokey feel with a wonderful balance on roasted malts some light pine hops and a dark creamy texture with strong tobacco hints. Served warmer and it really opened this up in its full glory

Bottle. Pours an even black, maybe with a slight reddish hue, and a foamy tan head that sits around for quite a while. Smells roasty and stouty. Maybe a little booze, too. Taking a sip... This is a pretty heavy stout, actually - very malty and sweet, a totally different character from the drier Black Butte. Nice to see some good variety, even in the similar styles. ThereÂ’s a pleasant bit of roasted malt blended with the sweetness along with a nice chocolate/coffee bitterness character. For being on the standard lineup for Deschutes, this is a nice big warming stout. Happy to try this one.

Pours a rich deep black with a finger or so of tan head.  Aroma is of crisp, dry roasted malts and weak coffee.  Flavor is more coffee, with a somewhat medicinal quality in the mid-palate, before settling back to coffee, and light bakerÂ’s chocolate bitterness.  There are also earthy and leather notes.  An interesting stout.  Really dry, and so it makes me continually reach for my glass for another whistle-wetting sip.  Nice.

Near black, thin lingering tan head, light lacing.
Aroma is sugary sweet, some milk chocolate and caramel, good roast.
Flavour is of dark fruits, burnt cake, some bakers chocolate, roasty.
Bitter mouthfeel, medium body, medium carbonation.
Finishes long, bitter, roasty. 
Aged fine. A nice milk stout. 
355ml bottle obtained in a trade with JohnnyJ, thanks Jonathan.
Opened on March 13, 2009.
Best before December 7, 2007.

Mmm mmm one of Deschutes best standards and even better on tap.  Pours brown black with a tan head and plenty of lace.  Aromas of coffee, bitter chocolate, and caramel.  Taste is much the same but unfortunately it is a bit thin.  All around a good beer to have on hand.

Bottle pours black with a creamy, khaki colored head that leaves nice lacing.  Aroma is heavy in dark chocolate, roasted malt, coffee, grapefruit and licorice.  Flavor contains the same, with additional notes of anise, and pine.  Overall body is moderate to full, with soft carbonation and a dry finish. Definately a nice transitional stout for people who get bored with their Guiness.

Dark leather pour bordering black with a creamy latte head.  Aroma is of rich cocoa, caramel, brown sugar, and coffee.  Flavor is similar with tons of roasted malt.  Not overly thick or viscous...just a good solid stout.

Draught on Nitro. Black with very thick tan head, strong lacing. Mild aroma of caramel and malt, light hop character, not overpowering but very nice. Taste is very clean and smooth, notes of roasted coffee and chocolate. Thin texture, bitter finish.

A fairly complex malt profile for such a jet black stout, thereÂ’s a ton of roast and a intermingling of faint notes of licorice, bittersweet chocolate, coffee, burnt sugar and the unmistakable Galena hop.  The somewhat full mouthfeel compliments the dark brown froth that laces the glass.  Carbonation levels are spot on for a beer with this kind of fullness and roasty character.  A tad filling with a slightly acrid sharpness.  A classic example of an American Stout.

Bottle (in NZ), pours pitch black with a think foamy brown head. Dark chocolate and coffee on the nose. Whoa boy - a big dry roasty palate. ThereÂ’s a good hopping with pine and a little spice, with that malt adding plenty of roasted coffee and then dark chocolate lingering on the tongue. Stout as it should be.

Pours a motor-oil black with creamy tan head that rings the glass. Aroma of medium-to-dark roast coffee, dark chocolate, grassy/piney hops, and a rounded depth of roasted grains. Flavor is hop forward with a dark, milk chocolate body and a coffee bean finish. Some lightly toasted, mellow caramel character is also present. There is also a hint of cola. This beer is perfectly hopped and the aroma is gentle enough to let the substantial malt profile characterize the beer.

12 oz. Bottle Thanks to Dchmela!
Great pour with a nice brown head that lasted pretty well. Chocolats, roasted malt, some molasses and coffee with a finish that stays with you. A very nice beer!

On nitro at BaileyÂ’s Taproom in Portland, OR. Colour... jet black with a thin tan head that totally coats the sides (and stays!)  when swirled. Nose... very roasty with medium bodied black coffee. Palate... creamy, yet sharp, roasty, tangy, anise, coffee, molasses and a long bitter finish. I like this from the bottle, but nitro is truly fantastic!

12 oz. bottle courtesy of a trade with ditmier.  Pours just about black with a moderate-large light brown head that lasted through mid-glass and left a nice webbing of lace.  Very pleasant aroma of chocolate, and roasted malt.  While the aroma is more dominated by chocolate, the flavor is mostly roasted malt, burnt toast and just a bit of bittersweet chocolate.  Moderate roasty bitterness at the finish.  Very good stout.

Pours black with a sizable tan head - excellent retention. Taste is heavy on roasted malts, sweet grainy coffee, chocolate, and a bit of molasses. Good body and mouth feel. Very drinkable and ejoyable.

UPDATED: SEP 24, 2009 Deep brown with a thick tan head which retains fairly long.  Has a great aroma of coffee, roasted malt, and raisin.  Flavor is a bit sweet with a lot of coffee and a bit of an acidic flavor.  This is pretty good for the price, but I think I actually like their Black Butte Porter more.

Dark rich body, thick head. Aroma has heavy roasted malts, some sweetness, molasses. Creamy mouthfeel with some finishing bitterness. Flavor is well balanced, roasted malts, coffee and sweetness. Nice.

UPDATED: NOV 14, 2009 Pour dark black, beautiful head with appropriate lacing. Poured into a duvel tulip. Excellent palate, but perhaps could be a bit softer
Rich nose, excellent dry roasted lingering bitterness. Some vanilla. Excellent balance, not too burnt, not too sweet. I love this kind of stout. 

Rerate: I love my stouts charred, but not smoked. Yum. This is a great session beer.

Pours black with a thick, sticky head - rich aroma of bittersweet chocolate, espresso, vanilla bean, black malt - creamy body - bitter dark malts are balanced by chocolate sweetness - some notes of char, burnt malts, but it never becomes ashy, like so many other highly bitter and roasty stouts - a nice mix of sweetness and dry character in the finish - this is a great stout.
UPDATED: OCT 22, 2009 12 oz. Bottle. pours very dark...roasty, chocolaty and malty flavors. ThereÂ’s also a hint of fruity flavors. Short burst that tingleÂ’s to the palate. Nice...very nice.
Poured from 12 oz, darkest of brown, with a medium sized tan head.  Nose of chocolate and malt, nice,Taste was a bit thin, but dry on the semi-sweet side. with a good mouthfeel overall.
Dark, black, chocolate, candied fruit.  Not as thick or chewy as I would have hoped, but an incredible flavor profile.  Woody and rich.  Really a tasty stout.

dark dark brown with a nice big pillowy brown head. aromas of coffe, chocolate, liquorice, bread, malt. very inviting so far. roasty flavors just on the verge of being too roasty and 1 dimensional, but this is almost perfect. creamy mouthfeel, good bitterness.

On draft at the brew pub. Not too impressed with this. Too watery for me, should have been a little creamier for the 6.4% alcohol content. Tasted weak and without a whole lot of flavor. Lightly sweet roasted malt taste. Watery, lightly dry finish. Too much like guinness.

(bottle from B&B Liquor in Colorado Springs). Black color. Medium brown head which is mostly diminishing. Roasted coffee aroma. Roasted coffee flavor with some bitterness. Avg duration. Light bitter finish. Slick texture. Moderate carbonation. Spare lacing.

Black with a brown head that displays great retention.   Smooth, creamy, chocolately roasted malt and sweet fruitcake in the aroma.   The flavor is of smooth roasted malt, light mineral water, and lightly sweet dark cake with a pleasant bitterness wrapping things up.   Just a hint of sweetness, acidity, and burnt toast in the finish.   Medium bodied with fine carbonation.   Good stuff, but has a few obtuse qualities.

12oz bottle from Lukas Liquors. Pours very dark brown with average tan head. Aroma is roasted malt, chocolate and some caramel. Flavor is dry and roasty with chocolate, caramel and a touch of coffee. Finishes dry but has good carbonation. This is a really solid stout.

12oz. Body:  Aroma of roasted malts and chocolate.  Poured very dark brown/black in color with a small, brown head that lasted throughout.  Clear.  Not sparkling.  Flavor is slightly sweet and lightly bitter. Tasted of roasted malts and chocolate.  Medium body.  Slightly sticky texture.  Average carbonation.  Light;y sweet, lightly bitter, chocolate and roasted malt finish has a hint of dryness.

Ahhh...back in Washington state! How wonderful the cool weather feels. Anyways, picked up a 6Â’er of this at QFC. Poured a slightly viscous. Nice thin head sitting on top of a dark black body. Decent chocolate head. Looks pretty good if you ask me. Huge sweet roast aroma that is not hard to smell at all. Very pungent beer. Chocolate comes through the aroma as well. Nice aroma. Huge roast flavor with some sweet chocolate notes. Rather thin, if you ask me, but no where near watery. Wonderful roast flavor with chocolate that just amazes me. Overall, damn good stout, and it is good to be in Washington again.

Out of a 6 pack, chilled mug,pours nice and black, with a good medium head. Aroma of rich coffee,smoke and dark roasted malts is strong. A perfect all around stout in a 6 pack that is still above %6. Another winner in the always good Deschutes lineup.
Jet black with a small, light brown head. Roasted malt aroma with licorice and a touch of pine hops. Strong roasted flavour with licorice, a burnt note, some sweetness and a nice hoppy finish.

From tap at Sacramento Brewing. Pours black wit a small tan head. Aroma is roasted dark malt, vague acidic touch. Hardroasted malt flavoured, light acidity and subdued fruity touch. Roasted and slight acidic flavoured finish. Nice, but also quite simple.

Dark roasted barley malt and charcoal aroma. Black with a thin tan head, reasonable glass adherence. Thinnish mouthfeel. Powerfully dark flavor of charcoal, smoke, and french roast coffee. Charred bark and hop finish. A lot of great stuff that doesnÂ’t meld. Dysfunctional, yet tasty. Schwarzbierisch.

12 oz bottle

Thanks to someone for sending this in a trade.  I lost track as it sat in the back of the "to drink" fridge but finally got around to it on a nice summer afternoon.  This was well worth the wait; if Deschutes was readily available in Ohio I might pick up a sixer for a party.  ItÂ’s a great stout that would be appreciated even by the casual drinker.

Aroma / Appearance - Rich and thick the cream colored head bobs above a reddish black body which swirls effortlessly around the snifter.  Creamy milk, a drizzle of chocolate, vanilla, and a trace amount of coffee gives this a nice overall feel.

Flavor / Palate - Fluid, the mouthfeel reveals a mix of toasted rye, dry malt, and smoke which sticks in the throat.  Sitting well from start to finish it has a good presence that is balanced.  The coffee and licorice transition about halfway through the bottle improves an already solid stout.  Those of you who can get this locally should count yourself lucky.
Dark pour with a tan head. Aroma is roast and chocolate. Flavor is coffee, chocolate, caramel, a little hop to balance it. A good daily drinking stout.
Scumy head, dark opaque brown. Deep roasted malt, dark chocolate middle, coffee bitte end. Medium body, served too cold but smooth and easy going. Excellent.

Deep black/brown, lots of firm tan head. Oily chocolate aroma, lively and green, fresh cut oak. Inky warm dark chocolate flavor, very high frequency and sharp. Dry-leaning finish with lingering resiny bitterness. Good full heft to the palate. Well-crafted beer.
Damn good brew.  Pours a black as used oil.  Nice and thick with a tan head.  Roasty, coffee and chocolate aroma.  Chocoalty sweet taste with a coffee finish.  Damn good. brew.
On-tap at the Portland Brewpub on nitro.  Rich and creamy, with much of the same flavor profile as, say, Guinness, just with so much more body!

35,5cl bottle. BB 08/08. Trade with ChristianScheffel. Pours black with a thick creamy beige head and lacings. Nose is mild but quite complex. Lots of roasted coffee, some chocolate, a little tar/smoke and a vinous/matured touch. Smooth, stikcy and full body. Bitter roasted coffee and milky chocolate in the end. A nice one.

12oz bottle courtesy of josephselander poured into a tulip.

Pours clear mahogany brown out of the bottle and settles in almost completely black in the glass with a gorgeous tan head that sticks stubbornly to the sides of the glass and remains an inch-thick cap for the duration.  One of the better stouts IÂ’ve seen in terms of appearance.

The aroma is actually a little sweeter than I was expecting with a big chocolate malt presence with hints of vanilla and caramel.  There is only a slight toasted grain character to the smell but the sweetness is really dominant.

The taste starts out like the aroma and has an initial chocolate malt sweetness with a hint of toasted malts in the background.  The finish is what really stands out vs. the aroma as there is a big roasted coffee bitterness that was nearly non-existent in the aroma.  I think there are even a bit of hops in the finish as well.

The mouthfeel is interesting as itÂ’s smooth and creamy for the first half of the sip, but the finish is extremely dry and bitter.  Very interesting to see the two elements melded together in one beer.

This is certainly one of the better standard stouts IÂ’ve had recently and the Jekyll & Hyde type taste is very unique and well executed.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a thick black color, nice tan head.  Aroma is roasty, cocoa, and coffee.  Flavor is complex, with a chocolatey nose, a smooth, syrupy middle, and a bitter finish.  Overall I enjoyed this one a lot.
Nice roasty malty aroma and flavor - fairly thin mouthfeel for a stout.  Nice appearance upon pour with one finger head.  Decent brew but not  great.

12oz bottle. Pours a black body with a dense, finger-width, brown head that dissipates slowly and leaves lots of creamy, layered lacing. Aroma of rich, semi-sweet chocolates and roasty coffees. Some citrusy florals keep this well rounded. Flavor is full of roasty, rich, goodness. Sweet dark chocolates, heavy but not aggressive roasts, some chalky coffees, and a light bouquet of citrus bittering hops. Palate is medium bodied, dry, and leaves a lot of lingering roasty, rich chocolate goodness. Overall, my kind of stout. Straightforward, but big and bold. I enjoyed this one a lot.
Poured black with a  tan head. Aroma of coffee. Some chocolate with coffee. Lots of fruit that almost overpowers the coffee.

Like everyone else I must say it is "obsidian black". Really really black, with a light tan head that is very frothy.

Aroma is of candied whopper malt balls with espresso bean candle notes. (those coffee armoa candles, coffee with vanilla waxy smells).

Simply huge roasted malt flavors. Warm, roasty, and the finish goes on and on. Some hops thrown in the mix but youÂ’re fixated on the roasted malt, of course.

Surprisingly drinkable for a richly flavoured beer - a characteristic among other beers from the fine brewers at Deschutes.
On tap @ Baker st pub in Boulder. Deep dark brown, smells roasty and a little spicy. Tastes creamy and mostly coffee with a little burnt caramel kind of thing going on. Impressive brew.
Pours a dark brown. Deep rich flavor, with notes of coffee and roasted chocolate. Can sure feel the alcohol, high abv. Very good stout, and very drinkable. Thumbs up!

12oz. bottle into a nonic. "Best by 05/28/09" is stamped onto the label. 

Pours black, and completely opaque in appearance. 3 fingers of frothy, creamy, light brown head, which fades extremely slowly to a thin cap. Lacing is thick, sticky, and prevalent.
 
Aroma of sweet malts, slightly earthy roastiness, with hints of coffee.

Tastes of moderately sweet, malty roastiness. Lightly smoky/burnt/dark coffee flavors. Very slight hint of dark fruitiness. Solid smoky bitterness lingers on the finish.

Moderate carbonation, medium-full, creamy, and smooth.

Outstanding. All elements of this brew are above-average to out-of-sight. This is a really good beer, reasonably priced, and a pleasure to drink. It is a damn shame that it is unavailable here in Ohio.

No idea how IÂ’ve managed to not rate this beer yet, a gross oversight on my part! Pours as dark and smooth as the rock for which its named with a small tan head that fades quickly. Aroma is full of roasted malt, dark chocolate, light coffee and some plum/raisin type fruit esters. Flavor is caramel, chocolate, light coffee, mild earth and pine hop notes and roast. Quite an easy drinking stout, and one IÂ’m thrilled to be able to drink on a regular basis.

DLD 2009, thanks to [?]:  It is obsidian in color, topped by a short-lived tan head.  Very nice aroma, dark malt with a light roast, dark dried fruit, coffee, and floral/herbal hop scents.  It was thinner bodied than I anticipated.  The flavor matched the aroma and had the addition of some chocolate and a nutty/woody bitterness.  Pretty decent.

UPDATED: MAY 13, 2009 pours a dark, dark black with a tan, bubbly head.  in the aroma is fruits (itÂ’s a fruit punch in here), thereÂ’s also coffee, chocolate.  thereÂ’s a ton of malt complimented by the smooth, chocolatey mid-palate.  The backend features a nice amount of hops bitterness.

Best by date 01/29/09, Purchased on 3/19/09 and Drank on 4/26/09

4.5 out of 5 on over all drink-ability

Aroma:  The aroma is complex of floral notes, dried fruit, raisons, coffee.

Appearance:  Obsidian Stout pours black.  The head is tall, tan and persistent. 

Flavor:  The initial bitterness is tames quickly and leaves flavors of dried fruits, coffee, and toasted malts.  

Mouth Feel: Full bodied, mild carbonation.

Overall Impression:  A smooth complex stout.  ItÂ’s one more beer I wish I could buy in Kansas City.

Bottle.  Pours opaque with a large, rocky, brown head, mostly lasting with excellent lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (coffee, burnt grain, dark chocolate), light hop (dry grass), average yeast (leather, earth) with notes of ash, wood, and prune.  Full bodied, creamy texture, lively carbonation, and a bitter finish.  Long duration, light sweetness, moderate acidity and bitterness.

Bottle from City Beer, at home with tashi, 4th April 09. Black with a big tan head. Very good balance of sweet and dry flavours. Nice and smooth, no hint of the alcohol. Coffee hint to both aroma and flavour too. Good stuff.

Pour black like a stout should with a really nice head retention.Easy to drink with a nice burnt roast flavor with a smooth chocolate flavor coming through.Creamy without the bitterness bite that holds so many beers back this finishes sweet leaving a pleasant aftertaste. great beer and worth the effort to find!

Bottle.  Pours a very nice black color with a large, foamy, lingering, dark tan head.  Taste is of hops, malt, grass, smoke, caramel and some chocolate.  Has a nice sweetness to it.  Well balanced.  Is a bit too much bitter and dry.  Easy to drink and rather enjoyable.  Worth getting again as it is moderately priced.

Bottle (12oz).  Black pour with ruby highlights, large foamy light brown lasting head.  Soft aroma - sweetened coffee, cream, a bit of dry mint - very roasty.  The taste follows, with more dry herbal bitterness and coffee grounds-like acidity - light alcohol, it seems almost burnt.  Creamy, rich mouthfeel, again, soft, sweet up front, but burnt roast with hints of dry bitterness in the linger.  Very, very good stout.  I could drink this all day.
Bottle from Utobeer. Almost black with a rich, lacing light brown head. Meaty roast aroma. Chocolate, some meaty saltiness, roast. Full-bodied. A stout that is not just kidding.
It pours very dark with a chocolate colored foam.  The aroma has vanilla hints.  It has a rich, coffee flavor.  It clings to your palate.

12 oz bottle from a very generous Douglas88.  Pours a black color which reveals some ruby highlights when held up to a light. A vigorous pour will net a 1/2" brown head. No lace.
