Nose is roasted malt with a trace of chocolate. Nice full, heavy mouth feel. Flavor is dark bakers chocolate with some dark fruit flavor. Mildly bitter finish. Very nice!

12oz bottle courtesy of mfielden. Pours a murky dark brown to black color with a massive two finger creamy tan head. Aroma is roasted and malty with notes of chocolate, caramel, honey, molasses, some hints of coffee and floral hops. Flavor is roasted and malty as well with notes of chocolate, ripe dark fruit, caramel, coffee, and brown sugar. Generally medium to full body with a pleasing chocolate and malty finish.

Great stout, readily available in the West.  Not sure about the East Coast.  One of my favorites from Deschutes.  Dark mocha color.  Great for a everday available beer.  Amazing for croquet on a side note.
Nice to have a "regular" stout once in a while, and this one is above par for the course.  Complex in taste, beautiful in appearance, slightly weak in the mouth, but very good overall.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a thick mocha colored head of great duration with attractive lacing, over jan opaque brownish black body which appears to be clear.....nose is rich of roasted malts with coffee chocolate hints....tastes again of roasted malts with bitter hop finish...mouthfeel is medium. A solid middle of the road presentation of an American style stout.

Chocolate and toffee are very strong in the nose.  The beer pours very black with a brown frothy head.  Flavor is surprisingly sweet-hoppy, chocolate, some malts, a bit of coffee, and just a bit earthy on the periphery.  A truly excellent stout.
Pours a jet black with a dark brown head. Aromas of chocolate, toast, and roasted malts. Flavor is packed with coffee, malts, and chocolate. Great bottled stout.
smells complex and rich. tastes a bit too burnt and smokey, a little hard to drink. not sure if bitterness comes from hops or burnt coffee. disappointed

Crushed with Jakebra.  Nice nose.  Incredibly nice.  Lots of awesomeness.  Flavor is nothing compared to the nose.   Lots of coffee and a bit of chocolate.  Still, nose was way better.  Had potential.

In short:  Standard but effective tasty dry chocolaty and slightly fruity stout.
How: Bottle 12oz, age unknown but drank before best-before date.  Graciously sent to me by Hellbilly, thanks a lot Joshua
The look: Black body topped by a long lasting small tan head
In long: Generic but pleasant moderately roasted, moderately chocolaty and moderately fruity stout.  The pleasant body is rather full but very soft and with a smooth carbonation.  Roasted dark malts held together, some thick caramel and some molasses.  Then add a bar of black chocolate with high cacao content (80%+).  The dark fruits of the nose only start to show through the taste when the beer warmed-up.  That cacao and roastiness really dry the beer.  Some green hops.  Tasty bitterness feeling like biting a in a black chocolate bar while chewing a tiny bit of fresh green hops.  Nothing spectacular or original here but this is a solid stout, the type of stout I could drink again and again.  And again and again.  And again and again.  And one last one for the road.  And pick a fight with my apartment doorknob.  And lose.
Pours very dark with carmel foamy head.  Aroma of blackberries, taste of licorice and aftertaste of coffee, overall good.
Bottle.  Pours inky black with a thick head.  Coffee flavours with some bitterness.  Very light carbonation.
Portland, OR - Nov. 2008: Nice brown amber color, more on the dark side. Small head leaving laces. Light acohol taste- espresso too. Light body- goes quick. Ok

Poured deep black, completely opaque, with a generous tan head and nice lacing. Strong roasted coffee aromas dominate the nose, with hints of chocolate and alcohol. Espresso/coffee flavors are featured on the palate, with a slight hops bitterness sneaking in. Silky smooth mouthfeel, full bodied, and a very rich malty aftertaste that lingers.

Bottle. Aroma of roasted malt, bitter coffee grinds. Flavor much more approachable and luscious with semi-bitter coffee, chocolate, creamy, sweet maltiness. Full-bodied and rich though does have just a touch of astringency to it. Still, very good.

Had to go out west for a bottle. Black obsidian body, ruby edges, light brown frothy head. Aroma was chocolate, oak, banana bread, and some alcohol. Flavor was sweet malt, bittersweet chocolate, roast coffee, smooth bitter finish accentuated by alcohol. Easy drinking and warming.

This poured an opaque black color with a very very small tan head. Aroma was loaded with fresh coffee grinds and nice roasted notes as well. Flavor is very roasted and lots of coffee flavors, not much sweet chocolateys to be found here at all. This is a very solid everyday drinking stout.
Nitro at the brewery tap in Portland.  Black, medium brown head.  Aroma of milk chocolate.  A bit thin, but decent malts in a chocolate background.

Bottle.  Pours black with a thick tan head that fades.  Aroma of roasted malt and coffee.  Flavor of roasted malt and bitter chocolate as the beer warms.  Thick, full mouthfeel.  This is pretty good!
7/4/8/4/14 (3.7/5)
Bottle at home from my GBBF08 haul ... deep back ... think tan head ... sweet malt .. hop front ... light roast good fruit ... medium body ... light chocolate.

courtesy of goodloid10
Pours clear dark - black with thick frothy beige - yellowish head.
Aroma is malty with some very nice roasted coffee.
Taste of caramel malt with the coffee being distinct and flavorful, reminiscent of mocha.
After taste is lightly hoppy with a good floral finish.
At 6.4abv, the overall mouthfeel was warming. 
An amazing treat.
Bottle at mesandsims oud gaff. Alround rating: A bit thin, roasty, balanced, fairly drinkable stuff.

Bottle 355ml.Clear medium to dark brown black color with a average to large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, beige head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, coffee, dusty. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and light heavy bitter with a long duration, coffee bitter dusty finish. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. (060808)

Great looking pour, black with a thick creamy beige froth.  Great aroma of molasses, oats and chocolate with lots of very fruity hops.  Floral perfumy first taste overtop chocolate and creamy oats with a hint of burnt molasses/brown sugar and deep roasted coffee.  Medium mouthful, very smooth and kind of airy, lots of smooth fluffy carbonation.  Its a very good beer with hints of tasty stuff, however, it leaves the mouth wanting a little more of each flavor.  Perfumy aftertaste.

Black in color with a medium light brown head. The aroma is of Swiss chocolate and coffee grounds with a hint of tobacco and sugar.  The flavor is smoky and sweet with a chocolate overtone. The texture is creamy. A very good stout. THIS IS MY KINDA BEER!

Bottle. Pours with a largish, creamy brown head and a very dark brown body. Aroma of coffee, roast, tobacco, granulated sugar, and Swiss chocolate. Taste is smoke and chocolate. Sort of a creamy mouthfeel, with light bubbles. A great basic stout.

A black brown pour with a creamish colored head. Real nice roast malt aromas, some mocha. Flavors mimic the aroma. Roast malt and chocolate up front, finishes with good coffee bitterness. Roast coffee lingers. Drinkable, solid medium body. Real nice brew, the first I have had from Deschutes.
Side note, their bottles have some nice ornamentation.
user_location: from Michigan now in Charlotte, North Carolina, USA

text: Bottle. Burnt coffee and honey aroma, with a nice tan head and a black body. Iâ€™m not a big fan of burnt flavor, but its good stout.
Draft. Pours a creamy black. Caramel and chocolate nose. Good roasted flavors. Very sour. Not my favorite stout.

This one certainly had the look. Black with a thick creamy tan head. Aroma is sweet and sour and earthy. Very rich. And the flavor is rich too, but almost on the opposite end of the flavor spectrum. There is more of a deep molasses flavor, and the sweetness only makes a brief appearance in the finish. Not sour at all. I think that this is a very good beer that may be too unusual to get consistently high ratings. But it has a great character, and plenty of layers of complexity for my taste!

Poors dark black with a light caramel head.  Aroma is more woody almost (almost spicy to my nose) and does not resemble a classic chocolate or coffee smell.  Palate is soft and very drinkable.  Best part of the beer is the finish it ends with a great chocolate flavor and plenty of roasted malt.  Overall a very good beer and certainly worth a go if you appreciate a stout - avoid if you want a knock your socks beer overwhelmed with flavor.

UPDATED: OCT 26, 2008 Bottle.  Pours black with a fair amount of puffy, tan head.  Smells of roasted malts and dark chocolate (yum!).  Probably one of the better aromas IÂ’ve found in a beer.  Mmm, this beer is good.  Roasted malts and hops shine up front, followed by a lush, dark chocolate and toasted finish.  Very drinkable for a stout and quite tasty.  Not overtly complex, but sometimes I prefer that.  A very nice stout.
Good Roasty stout with chocolatey and woody notes.  Very hoppy taste, but not so much in the aroma.  Very drinkable.

UPDATED: JUL 10, 2010 Awesome! Pours a used motor oil black with a dark brown head (like Coca-Cola fizz). Very porter like- I swear the brewery has mismatched the Black Butte "Porter" with the Obsidian "Stout". Awesome lacework. Aroma is espresso, dark chocolate, raw cocoa. Taste is similar though IÂ’m missing the roasted malt flavor. Aftertaste is dry and hoppy. This is well balanced and well-executed: my favorite of the Deschutes family. 7/4/7/3/16=3.8ReRate: Massive rocky brown head leaves insane sticky lace. Sweet, rich, non-cloying, malt backbone. Creamy palate. Still kicks ass. 7/5/7/4/15=3.8

[1694-20080907] 12floz bottle. Roasted malt aroma. Black red-hued body with quick foamy tan bubbles. Roasted malt flavour has burnt wood notes that linger. Full body is mildly bitter. Not bad, nice to try.

Bottle. Pours a pure black color with a medium brown head. The aroma is full of sweet chocolates, some dark fruit  and roasted malts. The taste is very nice; an initial coffee and roasted flavors, some sweeter fruit later, which is followed by a bitter and milk chocolate finish. Some earthy flavors also. A nice full and creamy mouthfeel. An excellent stout.
Bottled. Dark color, medium frothy brown head. Aroma of soft chocolat, rye, roasted malt, hint of blackcurrant. Sweet bitter, roasted malty taste. Overall quite decent beer.

(Bottle, Stockholm Beer Festival, 20 Sep 2008) Black colour with frothy, brown head. Roasted, malty nose with black coffee and dark chocolate. Roasted, malty taste with notes of dark bitter chocolate, black coffee, and cocoa bitterness in a fairly dry finish. Brilliant balance. Very nice beer.

12-ounce bottle in Albuquerque. Very rich dark malt flavor - chocolately, dry black malt, no roasted character. Full mouthfeel with a medium to big body. Substantial carbonation but not out of line. Dry finish with hop bitterness lying just beneath the malt. Leaves an impression, memorable in a positive way.

12oz bottle-pours a rich light brown head and trailing lace and black color.  Aroma is dark malt-cocoa/chocolate, oats, slight earthy.  Taste is dark malt-cocoa/chocolate/coffee/caramel, oats, slight earthy, some acidic/ashy/tar.  Semi dry finish.  Not quite my taste but well done.  Occasional.  Thanks to BitterBill.

UPDATED: SEP 19, 2008 Sinfully black body with a small head after a vigorous pour, not overly done but noticable black unsweetened cocoa and coffee notes and licorice, dominating roasted malts, flavor is the same dry, roasted coffee and bittersweet baking cocoa, finish is dry, roasty, and some licorice herbal bitterness, body just a tad thin,  I would have liked a little more body, that is what falls short here a bit, but a decent brew and for the price wonderfull. Drink this close to 50F, my first few impressions were at too cold a temperature, the brew felt thicker and less prickly as it warmed up.

Black body with a tan bubbly head.  Has a nice smoked roasted character to the aroma.  Chocolates and coffee on the tongue.  Quite delicious.  It does feel a little thin on the palate though, which I found the only really detracting quality.  Overall, a good beer.

Pours black, with a thick, tan head. Dark, sweet malts and molasses, with a surprising amount of hops to counter on the nose. Flavor brings in bitter chocolate, and dark roasted coffee. The barley is roasted to the point it tastes burned - there are notes of charcoal in here - but otherwise, itâ€™s robust and pleasantly bitter for a stout. Would accompany any meat wonderfully.
Black as obsidian. Malty with molasses.Roasted Barley, chocolate,coffee with some hops.Delicate yet robust flavors.Very drinkable. Not overdone

355 ml bottle. Black body with a beige head. Aroma is sweet malty, slightly roasted with a hint of chocolate and  liquorices. Flavor is rich malty, slightly roasted, chocolate and fruity. Very nice indeed.

A Mes rate: bottle at GBBF.Beautiful looking beer. Black as "Obsidian Blackbird McKnight" with a thin but very stable tan head. Gorgeous. Odd meat and pig fat ntoes in the aroma but it is overpowered by some superb syrupy and oily malt plus some excellent chocolate notes. The flavour is full of coffee and chocolate as you would expect. Gloriously roasty, superb bitter bite but not overly hoppy. A lovely thick, chewy mouthfeel. Excellent stuff. This has made me really really want to try the Abyss.

Bottle from liquidsolutions.  Man, this was tasty.  Near-black pour with tan head.  Roasty and very drinkable, with a big hop presence and an overwhelming flavor of roasted barley.  Some bitter chocolate notes as well.  Possibly the best Iâ€™ve had of this style (American hoppy) stout.  Really lovely.
Black, black with long lasting brown head.  Coffee aroma.  Roasty, burnt, dry, toffee flavor. Full bodied.

Bottle courtesy of secret santa: Poured a pitch-black color stout with a huge medium brown foamy head with good retention and some good lacing. Aroma of dry coffee with some roasted malt and black chocolate is very enticing. Taste is also a well balance mix between some black chocolate, dry coffee and roasted malt. Body is full with a perfect creamy texture and good carbonation. I very much enjoyed this beer from a brewery that I am starting to learn about.

On tap at Deschutes brewery in Portland.
GREAT STOUT! SMOOTH SMOOTH SMOOTH. Like drinking beer flavored chocolate milk next to a raging fire.

Tasted @ the Deschutes Brewery and Public House in Portland.
Brown/black colored brew. Roasted malty aroma. Flavor is roasted too, sweet chocolate and some fruits. Very nice one.

Bottle from GBBF 08.  Black, dark brown edges, thin tan head.  Moderate intense roasted malt.  I mean itâ€™s a really good intense stout.  Just a touch down from an impy stout, but is shares some characteristics.  Lovely rich aroma.  So Good.  Rich espresso coffee and creamy bitter dark choc.  Stunning aroma.  Somewhat fullish in mouth, more dark choc, 70% cocoa Iâ€™d guess, bit of ashtray.  Bit of sweetness and then dryness from the roast and a bit of hop.  Decent dryness.  A little one dimensional and a little sweet.  Great aroma, bit sweet and finish could be better.

12oz Bottle. Nice fresh roasted aroma, suavely blended with malt fermentation and molasses. Soft and milky. Builds up a good frothy head of coffee and cream over a black base. Dry stout develops interesting complexities. Faint sweetness yields to some red fruits, a bit of alcohol and a fresh rash of nicely dry and minty hops. Soft creamy body helps keep drinkability high. A bit of alcohol is noticeable, but lends to the beer. Signature yeast profile brings back memories of quaffing other Deschutes beer along the Colorado River, near Yuma, Arizona. Good stuff. Thanks Lyle!

Bottle at GBBF â€™08. Thanks to Mes for this one. Very dark brown with a tough, oily aroma that made me think of workshops and garages. The gentle, sweet chocolate flavour comes as something of a surprise and lifts the mood delightfully.
Black with large beige head. Sweet aroma with lots of roasted malt, coffee and coffe. Sweet flavor with roasted malt, caramel, coffee and chocolate. Lovely.

Strong roasted aroma but kind of mild in taste. Nearly perfect appearance but Ive come to love to see sediment in my stouts in porters which this lacks. This is a beautiful beer all around. Deschutes comes through yet again.

[emailÂ protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ of the World Live (NEC), 2008.  Black beer with a strong brown head.  The aroma is roasted, and the flavour is roasted and bitter.  Overall a very nice beer.

2008 Bottle - Pours opaque black with a small tan head, aroma is molassas and malt with a slight astringency...flavour is dominated by smoke and toast, nuanced with oak, coffee and hop flowers...not too sweet given the ABV, rather a great malt presence that isnâ€™t cloying...I have had just about every other Deschutes beer and had never tried this until recently, not sure why, because this is an incredible stout for the money...

Bottle.  Pours a, well, obsidian color, just like the name implies.  One inch tan head.  Aroma is malty with earthy grains.  Wonderful roasted malt flavor with coffee and vanilla in there, too.  Good, soft mouthfeel.  Iâ€™ve tried other brews from Deschutes, but I think this is my favorite so far.  Iâ€™d like to pair this beer with a low-and-slow smoked pork butt, roasted skin-on potatoes and a mixed green salad.

This dark brown ale poured with a decent tan head and a pleasant malty aroma. There is a very rich flavor of chocolate and coffee. There are no notable flaws in this brew, making it a great value for the style.
A great stout and incredible for the money. I always go back to this beer again and again. It is yet another example of the flawless brewing of Deschutes.

UPDATED: OCT 13, 2008 Aromas of cereal grains, vegetable, molasses, licorice, charcoal and vanilla with floral hops backing.  Kinda reminds me of rootbeer.  


Flavors of dark chocolate, smoky coffee, charred malts, and nuts.  Some dark winey/fruity notes; cherry and plum.  

Creamy palate, lots of bubbly. Dry finish.   
Good with gruyere.
Pours a dark dirt/tar, chocolate brpown with tan head that dissipates to a tan lacing. Aroma is nutty, chocolaty and malty. Strong coffee flavor with roasted malts. Body is mild and medium.

UPDATED: SEP 18, 2008 Dark brown/black, roasted malts, dark 
chocolate, a little coffee, slight dark fruit
slight crisp hop finish.

Pours black with a thick brown head. Roasty aroma with a bit of coffee. Flavor is more of the same. There is also a sweetness that provides a nice balance. No blow-me-away flavors, but a good stout none the less.
Bottle. Pitch black, small tan head than just sits there forever. Straight ahead coffee nose and flavor. Very roasty, warming, and so incredibly smooth. Surprisingly strong flavors. I love it.

Black, opaque beer with a brown head; aroma is dark chocolate; flavor is sweet (molasses?) with a nice bitterness on the back of the tongue; smooth mouthfeel; finish is roasty dry with a nice bit of hop;
Bottle.  A solid stout.  Pours a black body with a tan off white head.  Aroma is roasty chocolate malt, caramel, and lots of malt.  Roasty coffee in the flavor with little etoh or hops.  Good beer.

Bottle, Beers of the Worldlack with a beige head.  Aromas are earth roast malts with chocolate, caramel and some saltiness.  Spicy.  Flavours are bitter roast coffee with spritzy yeast and liquorice.  Bitter on the finish.  Good stuff.

V - Black pour, little head with slight lacing.

A - coffee and alcohol

T - coffee, black cherry, malt, caramel

P - standard, but not my favorite from a stout. Little hop kick at the end is nice.

Pours a dark opaque brown color witha small tan head. Nose of heavily roasted malt,  chocolate, touch of dark fruits. Initial displays that robust richness of the roasted malt flavoring enhancing to like black coffee.   Chocolate seeps in. Mid palate of hints of  mollasses. Finishing with a hoppier finish than expected and continuing deeply roasted malts. Good palate duration. Found the flavor to be too dominated by the roasted malt which lack complexity making it one dimensional. However, the beer was still enjoyable. Good head retention. Medium body.

Pours a pitch black with a thin layer of beige foam and great lacing. Aroma is pungent - alcohol, oatmeal cookie. Perfect stout taste - chocolate mousse, nice present hops, which is refreshing after so many sweet stouts. Just a tad tangy/acidic and roasty in the finish, nice warming alcohol. Body is not too thick, but still very creamy and substantial. I really like this stout, I wish I could buy it locally. Many thanks to my friend Stefan for the generous gift of 2 bottles!

Pours a nice thick black with a thick tan head. Big roasted grain chocolate malt aroma. Smooth chocolate, roasted grain taste. Very nice medium body. Finishes with a dry slightly bitter aftertaste. Very nice stout.

Bottle courtesy of SuzyGreenberg. Pours jet black with a dense, creamy tan head that leaves a blanket of lace on the glass as it recedes. The nose is a sweet and roasty malt and dark chocolate with supporting notes of lactose, faint coffee and Cavendish tobacco. Medium-bodied and silky-soft with a lightly bitter, roasted finish. The flavor is of sweet, roasted malt, bitter-sweet cocoa, light coffee and just a touch of sweet & sour lactose, finishing lightly bitter and roasty. This is an exceptional brew and one that I will drink regularly if itÂ’s ever distributed here in KC. Thanks a ton for sending me this excellent extra, Ben!

Bottle courtesy of Jake65.  Pours a deep black with a one finger tan head that dissipates quickly. Nose is roasted malts , coffee and cocoa. Palate is slightly bitter upfront, with burnt coffee grounds and some  molasses sweetness, followed by a lingering bitter hop finish.  Semi-creamy mouth feel.  Decent stout.

Pours black with a moderate brown head that has moderate retention and good lacing. Aroma is on the dry side and herbal with notes of pipe tobacco and coffee.  Pleasingly complex flavor starts dry then quickly becomes sweeter, presenting chocolate and dark roasted coffee, finishing with a solid complement of bittering hops. Lovely rich mouthfeel, just enough carbo that doesnÂ’t get in the way.  A very fine Stout.

12oz bottle thanks to a trade I made some time ago.  Very dark brown-black pour with a brownish medium head.  Very roasty aroma with big malty grain.  The flavor is nice.  Roasty malt grain with a touch of mineral, hints of dry coco but mostly roasted grain.  Medium mouth fell.  Creamy and (again) roasty.  This was a very enjoyable stout.
Near black pour, thick brown head. Very roasty aroma, chocolate too. Intense burnt malt, chocolate, coffee, quite sweet, a touch nutty. Velvety mouthfeel. Long dry bitter finish. Really terrific!
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Yummy. I was pleasantly surprised by this unassuming beer. Tastes almost like an Imperial, but with a little less complexity and alcohol. Roasted nuts, very malty, and unassaulting to the palate. This could make a great session beer, in my opinion. IÂ’ll definitely have to remember this one. Thanks Deschutes.

bottle.  Pours a very dark brown with a small but beautiful tan brown head.  Smells of chocolate malts, coffee, and charcoal.  Palate is creamy, with medium carbonation.  Flavor is rich of burnt notes, espresso, semisweet chocolate, maybe even some roasted chestnuts.  Definitely dominated by a smoky, toasted flavor.  Finishes dry and bitter.  Really a nice blend of dark flavors, though I felt like I tasted some hops in there to help round the brew.  A great beer, though not for those looking for a summer thirst quencher.

Bottle, pours a black color with a fast fading brown head.  Aromas of toast, hops, and coffee beans.  Flavor is roasted coffee, citrus and a nice blast of hops on the finish.  Mouthfeel is a bit thin, but a good beer anywa.

Sampled at the Savor DC event.  Pours a medium bodied, opaque black with a cloudy white head.  Aroma has roasted malts, nuts and coffee.  Flavor is both sweet and creamy with plenty of coffee, toasted grain, chocolate, and a hint of citrus.  Finish is dry with coffee bitterness.

Really a tremendous beer with a rich, deep character that spans the palate.  Starts midnight black with tons of visible malt.  Smells of chocolate and chicory and roast.  There is a surge of malt on the tongue, and a nice hop balance to the beer.  Somewhat viscous, medium weight.  Long, drying, bittering chocolate and coffee finish.  Still, there is more character in the beer than I can describe, with a terroir, mineral depth that few American stouts achieve.

Bottle. Pours a black color with a small longlasting tan head. Roasted malty chocolate and coffee aroma. Roasted malty hoppy bitter coffee flavor with some hints of chocolate, also some hints of licorice. Has a roasted malty licorice finish with a bitter aftertaste.

Bottle pours pitch black with a tan head.  Smells are mild for the style.  I gather some malt and hop flavors.  Has a light-medium mouthfeel.  Tastes like more hop upfront with a slight malt aftertaste.  Descent brew.

Pours a clear black with a beige head. Sweet with a bit of bitterness. Strong aromas of coffee and roasted malts. Also hints of oats. Medium bodied with a fizzy carbonation. Bitter finish with more coffee.

Pours a deep black with a creamy thick brown head which slowly gives away to some nice lacing.  Roasty grain and coffee aroma, with hints of malt and chocolate.  Nice flavor as well, mainly roasted malt and coffee.  Thin dry finish.  A good stout for the price.

Nitro tap at Papago.  Black with creamy lasting brown head.  Roasted chocolate, coffee, and chocolate chip cookie aroma.  Smooth, rich and creamy roasted chocolate with mild fruit and medium bitter finish.  Medium-full body with nitro creamy low carbo.  Very nice.

This one is always easy to overlook sometimes. Yeah, itÂ’s not a sexy imperial stout, and the label is kinda lame. But the contents in the bottle are fantastic. IÂ’ve consumed this beer several times over the years, so a 6-pack and $8.00 later, itÂ’s time to rate. 

The beer pours out a deep black color with a really nice two-finger thick tan head. The head sort of shimmers in the glass as it dissipates. An arom of smoke, charred malts, molasses and toffee. Creamy mouthfeel. Smooth dark roasted malts, coffee, and dark chocolate truffles. Pretty dry in terms of a stout. Not a whole lot of residual sweetness left. Nice stout anyway you look at it."

Dark brown in color with medium-sized bubbles that dissipated quickly.  The nose was sweet with scents of coffee, chocolate and oats.  The palate comes off soft and has a dry bitterness to it.  Fairly simple in the mouth.
This was just a tad too dry for a dry stout.  Extremely roasty, like coffee burned to the bottom of the pot, a light bit of chocolate and cocoa, burnt maltballs.  Not my favorite stout.

12oz bottle pours deep darkness with mocha head and spotty lacing. The aroma is roasty, chocolate covered malt balls and some licorice. The taste kicks off with a mouth full of highly roasted malts, burnt malts and coffee beans. Chocolate notes surface midway and ride with the roasted malts into the finish. Very nice stout.

Bottle. Huge tan head, dense and lasting with some lace, black body, roasty nose with espresso notes and perhaps some dark chocolate and maybe some floral hop notes. Pretty dry, typical roasted malt flavors, sort of like drinking powdered bakerÂ’s chocolate with some ground espresso mixed in. Could use more crystal malt. Finish sort of disappears.

Black pour, medium beige head. Aroma is roasty and coffee smells nice. Flavor is roasty, chocolate, a touch of coffee. Dry aftertaste with a touch of citrus hops. Medium bodied, smooth finish and just a great example of what a stout should be.

12 oz bottle from unclejedi - thanks! Best by 06/27/07. OK, so IÂ’m a tad late. Anyway, black with a brown head. Excellent brown lace. Rather roasty, nutty nose, chocolate and a bit of floral character. Flavors are very much chocolate and coffee, a bit more floral hop than the nose foretold. Body is on the full side of medium, pretty smooth. Finish starts oddly sweet, then moves to a herbal bitterness, a bit of burnt coffee. Nice stuff.

12oz bottle. Poured an opaque black color. Head was thick, brown, and reduced over a minute or two to a lasting film. Aroma was of malted milk balls with a hint of caramel. Slightly sweet with a bit of roasty bitterness at the end. Tasted of milk chocolate, caramel, and subdued cashew. Pretty solid.
Thick pour with long lasting white head.  Milky lactic acid aroma with some bourbon whiskey and malt.  Flavor is nothing but roasted, almost burnt malt.  Completely dry and bitter.  Good stout.

Acquired via trade with cbkschubert. Thanks! A very nice stout. Aroma was huge coffee and chocolate with a grainy note. Pour was near black with a one finger tan head. Taste was great. Roasted malt, coffee and a bitter mouth drying aftertaste. Excellent carbonation carried the flavors nicely. As it warms, this tastes almost like cold carbonated coffee. Very nice.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Bottled.  Slight coffee aroma, pours jet black, with a persistant light brown head.  Tastes of strong coffee and dark chocolate, with some bitterness.   Slightly creamy mouthfeel.  Goes down pretty smooth.  What a great name for a stout.  Gives me that warm fuzzy feeling.
Bottle. Pours black with thick light brown head. Nice hop aroma. Nice coffee, barley, chocolate flavor. Not oppressive body.  A very solid stout.

12 oz bottle from a trade with SuzyGreenberg. pours black with a nice tan hea that lasts and lasts. leaves nice lacings on the glass. aromas are roasted malts with roasted barley, coffee and chocolate coming through. sweet flavour profile with a slightly bitter finnish. borders on being a foreign stout with all the sweetness but a very good stout none the less. id gladly have it at anytime and id trade for it again.

12 oz bottle.  Finally rating this beer.  This is a regular vistor to my house.  Pours black with a thin creamy head.  After the first sip you can taste the roasty malt, chocolate and espresso.  Full bodied and the mouthfeel is sticky.  The lack of aroma is the only reason this did not recieve a rating of 4+.
very very good! I tried it bottled and on nitro. 10 times better on nitro. highly recommend. Of course anything Deschutes makes is always worth trying

Solid black with a wisp of a tan head. Milky burnt fruity hoppy aroma with leather and cocoa. Big hoppy roast flavor with caramel and lingering sweetness. Long oily finish with relatively low bitterness. Awesome stout.

UPDATED: SEP 28, 2008 12oz bottle kate brought back from olympia, wa.  black pour with nose of smoke, coffee and chocolate.  toasted malt, caramel, and alcohol on the taste.  finishes crisp and a little astringent (but not in a bad way).  kate: 8.5

Excellent EXCELLENT stout! Full flavored - the  hops are there just not as prominent as the rich, chocolate malt. Pours black, not brown - and you canÂ’t shine a light through this stuff. Flavor is light and heavy at the same time. Notes of plum, chocolate, wood and smoke.
This was a very goOd stout and was thick but not to sweet at all ,black with a nice tan head and a nice roasted malty flavor with hints of chocolate,overall a nice stout CHEERS!

UPDATED: MAR 21, 2008 Pours pitch black, with a small, tan head.  Light aroma of coffee.  Flavor of roasted nuts, espresso, brown sugar, and dark chocolate.  Palate is creamy, thinner than expected, and finishes on the dry side.  Overall a solid stout, but not spectacular.

Thanks bmartin. Poured a nice dark black with a one finger dark brown head. The aroma was very rich, roasty, molasses, chocolate, coffee, brown sugar. The flavor was also very rich, soy, molasses, chocolate, coffee, roasty flavor. Fairly thick mouthfeel. Excellent stout.

The color was very dark brown/black.  The head was thin, fizzy, and light biege.  The aroma was coffee, molasses, chocolate, roasty, and a light metalic nose.  The flavor was coffee, roasty, chocolate, sweet, and hops.  The palate was smooth and thick-bodied.  The finish was hoppy.

UPDATED: AUG 14, 2009 Bottle.  Can also get on tap around town.  Pours black with a mocha colored head that seems to last for a while leaving a rather nice lacing to the glass.  Aroma isnÂ’t this beers strongest suite...very subtle notes of toffee and roasted malt.  Flavor however is another story...nice full bodied stout with a somewhat sticky mouth feel.  Complex flavor profile with definite chocolate, coffee and roasted malts.  Very good Stout.

Props to thooper41 for sending this one my way! Pours black with a small frothy head. Aroma is licorice and toffee. Texture is very creamy, and the flavor combines coffee, toffee, and licorice. Very much a "lite" version of Dark Horse Reserve Black Bier, just a tad weaker and watery. Still a solid brew.
Poured black with a creamy tan head. Aroma of roasted coffee. Some chocolate mixed with coffee. Lots of fruit that almost overpowers the coffee. Different.

Wow, nothing this brewery creates can go wrong.  This beer was a dark black with a sticky and long-lasting brown film of bubbles on the surface.  Aroma was slightly sweet with loads of roasted malt.  Some hints of chocolate and coffee.  Flavors were really powerful and intense, with a satisfying amount of rich roasted malt with even more coffee and chocolate, and a nice balance of sweetness and bitterness.  Perfectly well-balanced.  Full bodied and slightly sticky-but-slick mouthfeel.  I love the fact that this beer exists AND IS SOLD IN SIX PACKS.  Awesome stuff, I need to stock up.

Pours a deep dark black with a three finger frothy tan head.  Held beautifully for 20 min.  Aroma of coffee, toffee and toasted nuts.  Flavor is roasted coffee with a nice dry bitter aftertaste.  Chocolaty and burnt toast.  I really like this stout.  Flavor lasts and lasts in the mouth.

(Bottle (best by 12/28/07) via trade with <A HREF=http://www.ratebeer.com/ViewUser.asp?UserID=3 target=blank>TheCheeseMan, thanks Daniel!) Pours very dark brown with four fingers of big mocha head that recedes to about 1/8" and stays. Aroma of molasses, dark chocolate and coffee. Big meaty mouthfeel. Smooth and a little oily. Lots of broken lacing. Flavor is big rich coffee and dark chocolate. Plenty of roastiness. A bit of roasty molasses emerges as it warms. Medium amount of bitterness overlays and gives a little hit through finish. A straightforward heavy-duty excellent-tasting stout with a great palate as well.

12 oz. bottle courtesy of kenb.  Pours black with a medium creamy tan head.  The aroma is roasted malt, sweet caramel and chocolate, and slight coffee.  The flavor is much of the same:  roasted/caramel malts, chocolate, a bitterness not in the aroma, sweet as well.  Medium bodied.  Solid brew.

UPDATED: MAR 20, 2008 Bottle. Pours a nice dark brown with a tan creamy head and good lacing. The aroma is that of chocolate, roast grain, malt, and coffee. The taste is very nice, dry, mocha, roasted malt flavor. Not Guinness but an excellent stout none the less.

12oz bonus bottle from buckeyeboy on 08/30/07.  Its a fitting time to drink with the recent release of Deschutes most famous beer, the Abyss.  The main trade with Buckeyeboy for a 2006 Abyss.  Now 5 months later, the 2007 Abyss is somewhat readily available in San Diego, where I live.  IÂ’ve been reluctant to drink this Obsidian stout, because I donÂ’t think I like dry roasty stouts.  Sure, enough this one is the same.  Nice malty aroma with some roasty grains.  Black color with a medium head of medium bubbles quickly fading  leaving a microbubble dense ring around the edge of the glass.  The flavor is dry and very ashy and burnt.  ingredients must have called for cigarette butts.  Yuck.
Pours a deep brown, with a light tan colored, creamy head. Aroma of coffee and roasted malts. Creamy smooth flavor of roasted malts and coffee. Slightly dry, with no lingering aftertaste. Great beer.
user_location: Mescal Lakes (wherever that is), Arizona, USA

text: Very dark black pour with an initial rich mocha head that leaves decent lacing. Aroma is rich roasted malts with a nutty coffee touch. Touch of milkyness. Flavor is milky chocolate with a strong roasted coffee bean flavor near the finish. Nice mouthfeel and good body.

Black body, nice cascading head of a couple fingers. Modest tan lacing with nice retention.

Extremely roasty, more coffee than chocolate.

Sweet chocolate in the front of the palate with a huge dose of roasted coffee in the back. Finish is dry with a roasty bitterness.

Carbonation is great, body is rich enough to support the big flavors. Easy to have several in a sitting.

Pours an ominous black color with light brown head. Head fades fairly quickly but leaves amazing amount of circular lacings. Big bold slightly bitter coffee flavor that smooths into dark chocolate. Bought some by mistake, there were two bottes in a different descutes six-pack. Stouts arenÂ’t really at the top of my favorites list but I enjoyed this one.
Recommended.
Bottled.  Pours like dark brown oil with a tan head including hints of red.  Aroma of dusty bittersweet chocolate.  Flavour was more chocolate, some hops and even a hint of smoke.  Nice, busy beer

Bottle. Pours almost black and totally opaque. The head is dark tan, short and sturdy. It holds up for a couple of minutes but eventually gives way to nice lacing. Aroma is very chocolaty with some coffee and dark fruit. Taste is solid roasted malts with quite a bit of sweetness balanced out by a higher than average hops load for the style. Palate is thick and firm with relatively low carbonation. This is a solid beer choice.

Opaque black with a light brown head. Medium intense malted chocolate - nutty smell. Medium bodied and softly carbonated with a smooth mouthfeel. Taste is a strong, nicely bittersweet chocolate malt flavor. Finishes with a tasty hop burp. My favorite everyday stout.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Very nice stout.  Fairly tight nose, but nice balanced between the malt and hop flavors.  A bit of molasses and a hint of baking cocoa.

On nitro. Black with a 1 inch velvet head. Aroma of sweet roasted malt and a touch of hop bitterness. Flavors of roasted malts and chocolate malt with secondary notes of maple and brown sugar. Creamy and smooth. A very nice stout.

Bottled.  Poured deep brown with a lovely cap of delightfully dark brown head.  The aroma picked up sweeter chocolates and milky notes on top of darker roasted chocolates and coffee.. very well-balanced between the sweeter notes and the roasty darker ones.  The flavor had sticky roasted coffee and dark chocolates at the core with mild earthy and coffee bitterness surrounding.. sweet chocolate and sour lactic notes laced throughout with grace.. caramel and molasses joined the coffee on the finish.. tasty!  Medium-bodied, and it gets to be a bit tacky at times on the palate.. nice roast and a sticky finish.  Overall a very good beer!

Bottle thanks to BuckeyeBoy.  Tastes like a big roasty chocolate covered cherry.  Chocolate and cherry are really what this is all about.  A bit sweet up front, but well balanced.  Not really bitter or hoppy at all.  Slight hints of licorice and molasses.  Wonderfully smooth and slick palate.  Kinda a poor manÂ’s Kalamazoo Stout, which is FAR from an insult.  Very well done beer.

Bottles from many over time. Black, with no head, oily. Plenty of chocolate up front fades to coffee. Flavor much the same. Coffee takes over through the middle and dominates from there out. Body thins out at times. Just not my thing.
Chocolatey and smooth. ItÂ’s like a Black Butte but with a bit more alcohol to it, and chewy feel in the mouth.  A very nice stout.

Pours an opaque black with a giant chocolate milk head that stays awhile and laces all over. This looks like a big bad stout. Smells of roated barley, caramel, expresso, fruits and some chocolate notes. Tastes silky smooth starting out with some sweet malt with a bitter bite and finishes with cocoa, roasted coffee, nuts and some hops. Feels creamy and smooth in the mouth with little carbonation feel. Alcohol is not detected at all in this. This is an awesome stout that is perfect for sessioning and a must try Oregon delight.
Black as night with burnt brown head.  Flavour raisiny yet dry.  Supersmooth.
Light head, brownish. Nice roasted, smokey aroma and flavor. Good Stout,Â although a bit thin for my liking.

(Draught) Sampled at Taphouse in Seattle. A rather expensive sampler at $9.95 for four 4-ounce samples. Great whipped brown head with an opaque body. Nose of creamy coffee. Flavour is fruity and bound with coffee. Strange.

Decent sized brown head of dense and creamy bubbles.  Light coffee, roasted grains, decaying grass and some lactose notes.  Color is a essentially black.  Sweet and roasty flavor.  Medium bodied with more milky notes, dark chocolate and a little bit of herbal hops presence.  Dry and pasty mouthfeel.  Finishes roasty with a lingering bitterness.  A decent stout.

Aroma rich, almost smoky. Color is about as black as it gets.  Head is brown but weak.  Flavor is strong, deep, rich malt and moderate bitter.  Creamy palate with a sparkle of citrus aftertaste.  Well worth many repeats.

Nitro pour in San Francisco - Black color with a medium but persistent head.  Aroma is a nice chocolate/roasty mix that gives the impression of dry and sweet together.  Flavor is very roasty, dry/sweet, chocolatey - lots of good stuff going on here, but the nitro detracted from the flavor in my opinion.  solid stout that I will have to re-rate with a bottle.

12-oz. Wow, didnÂ’t realize until last night that I hadnÂ’t rated this, and I had also forgotten just how good this one really is. Black with a thick, rocky burnt tan head of great depth and swiss-cheese-hole-having-ness. Settles quickly to awesome webby lace and a nice splatch of film across the top. Big peppery, herb-like hop nose. Delicious. No other beer smells quite like this. Thinking this must be a very fresh bottle. Medium, tingly-carbed body. Roasty, charry, peppery, spicy mid-palate. Dang, this is really, really good. Lingering pepper and pine finish.

Bottle.
Pours a thick, pitch black body with a medium-sized creamy tan-brown head. The aroma consists of quality bittersweet chocolate, some tobacco, toffee, and cookie dough.
This stuff is insanely silky and quite flavourful. Flavour has bitter roast, cocoa, and a fair amount of hop chewiness. Finishes with some light ashy oat and resin notes.
The parents picked this up sometime in the summer of 2007.
a fine looking stout that poured black with a small head.Roasted notes on the nose.The mouthfeel was creamy.Flavors of roasted coffee with a slight bitterness.

bottle.  I tried this beer in the middle of summer on a hot San Diego day so, my rating might be a bit skewed.  Black in color like motor oil.  A thin tan head with nice lacing was left on the glass.  Nose off freash coffee, cocoa, molasses, and dark fruits.  Thick and chewy.  IÂ’ll have to give this beer another go around one day soon.

One of the first Oregon beers I had the honor of tasting.  Poured a deep yet clean black-brown body with a medium tan-grey head.  Notes of coffee and chewy roasty malts.  Warm molasses finish with caramel and dry coffee flavor.  A Pacific Northwest classic!

12oz bottle: pitch black with a brown head, aroma of rosted malt flavor of mostly roasted malt. the flavor lacks a little for a stout and not a whole lot depth for taste, goes down smooth and easy to drink
Pours a nice dark with quickly diminishing head.  Reminds me immediately of BellÂ’s Kalamazoo Stout, only a little more watery.  Coffee and chocolate are there.  A pretty good brew.

Bottle at Stockholm Beer Festival 2007Black color; thin creamy head. Coffeish aroma. Silky mouthfeel, good body, good flavors (caramel, roasted malt, chocolate malt, sweet liquorice); quite sweet. Good.

Bottles from Dirty_Martini and BlackForestCO. Black body with a medium-sized, tan head that fades to a cover. The aroma is lightly sweet with a good dose of molasses and cola, some chocolate and roast in there as well. The flavor is just lightly sweet with dark chocolate, roasted malt, light coffee and a touch of dark fruits. Medium body is moderately carbonated and is a bit thin, especially in the finish. Finish is dry with a lingering presence of bakerÂ’s chocolate. Nice.
Pours very dark black.  Med. thin head with dark mocha foam.  Slight Dark Malt aroma.  Smokey taste, hops in the back.  Tongue tingler!
Deep brown pour with a medium head. Aroma of sweet, milky chocolate and roasted malt. Very sweet flavor; chocolate and lactic with some dark fruits and roasted malt. Medium to heavy body.
Pours dark brown with a thick dark caramel head. Aroma is rich and sweet. Flavor is sweet malty with chocolate, coffee, molasses notes. Good body, smooth finish.
A good stout with big body and matching hops.  Robust flavor.  A nice Deschutes product.
Black as night with a moderate tan head.  Very roasty flavor that leaves a bitter aftertaste.  Very drinkable.

This was very approachable, yet not boring stout.  I really enjoyed its moderate roastiness, and thought it very drinkable.

It pours a slightly viscous black, with a fluffy tan (nude pantyhose colored) head formation of tiny bubbles. Aroma was light roastiness.  Flavor was more roastiness with some good "burned pizza crust" character and some chocolate and coffee flavor notes.  Slightly creamy, but definitely not an extremely thick stout.  Highly drinkable.  

I had a roommate from OR who said that Deschutes was available in most gas stations & c-stores there...how wonderful that would be!  Far from the biggest and baddest in this style, but very nice.  Highly recommended.

I bought this at Liquor Mart in Boulder, CO during a visit to attend the GABF.

Bottle via trade with Jake65. Aroma of charred sweet caramel and toffee. Dark chocolate. Some fading hints of vanilla and alcohol. Pours dark, dark brown. Almost black with a thin khaki head. Flavor was quite dry with lots of roasted and charred malt. Come coffee and dry chocolate notes as well. Medium boded. Would have liked it to be richer and creamier on the palate. Thanks Jake!
UPDATED: APR 18, 2008 Pours a dark black with a thin tan head. Nutty with a hint of chocolate. Very smooth with only a little bit of a bitter finish. Overall a good beer.

Pours color of old motor oil with attractive parchment tan head.  This stout looks good and leaves a nice lace on the glass.  Scent of bread, chocolate, toffee and pine tar, maybe some figs.  Smooth mouthfeel w/ sharp bitterness.  Flavor of ethiopian coffee and caramel chocolates.  Big hop presence at the end but overall not overbearing and leaves you wanting more.
Tasted alongside Lion Stout.  Aroma of airy cocoa.  Brown head frothy.  Tastes of roast coffee, but not overpowering.  More crisp and lively than Lion.  Finishes slightly bitter

Bottle via jake65 - thanks, Jake!  Robust aroma has a coffee bean, roast, and chocolate profile similar to that of much bigger imperials.  Pitch pour with a rocky, bubbly, lacing light brown head.  Superbly balanced chocolate and roast taste, nothing really standing out or dominating, just smooth and tasty all the way through.  Somewhat dry with light hop funkiness (and just a super faint hint of grapefruit.  Picking up some mocha notes in the chocolaty aftertaste.  Thin body but very sessionable.  Only lightly bitter, and just as salty.  Not the obvious powerhouse - but luscious and pleasant.  ThereÂ’s a lot of joy to be had here.

pour is nearly coal-black with light brown head - bitter aroma with hints of chocolate, coffee, burnt wood - chocolatey/coffee/toffee taste with a slightly burnt taste (which is why I would rate it down slightly more than most seem to in this forum)

Very dark (opaque) brown.  Large thick foamy/creamy head. Aroma is slightly bitter with notes of dark chocolate.  Flavor hits you quickly big sweet with slight alcohal taste.  The usual suspects are here.  Charcoal, coffee, dark chocolate, yet they are weak and most definitley in the background. The sweet fruity flavors that come through in the nose is slightly overpowering.  A quality stout.

12oz Bottle
$1.55 Single
Liquid Solutions

Obsidian Stout pours the blackest of browns (if that makes any sense). Mahogany highlights only when held directly to the light and only creeping through the bottom of the glass. A strange looking big three finger tan head formed on the pour. I say strange because it was soapy looking and creamy at the same time. Very odd but definately a tasty looking stout. Leaves excellent lacing.

Unfortunately the nose seems to be lacking. Mild lightly roasted malts are there in the background but weak. Mild dark fruits, a lactic quality, and a pronounced metallic twang. If I smell deep I can pull out the aromas I like to expierence in a stout but theyÂ’re all just too weak and distant.

This is a quality stout. Roasted malts start things off with faint flavors of anise. Mild nuttiness mid-palate along with a creamy lactic quality. Nice balancing on the finish with bitter roasted malts and a touch of hop bitterness that make this smooth and exceptionally balanced.

Medium body with a slightly airy but creamy mouthfeel as it moves through the mouth. Nice lingering bitterness from a comonation of the hops and bitter malts.

This is a very good sessionable stout. Perfect beer to have on hand from Autumn through Winter if youÂ’re in the mood to sit down and have a few to warm up.

I believe this is only my second beer from Deschutes (the other being Black Butte Porter) and I wouldnÂ’t hesitate in buying either one of them again. Both very good examples in their respective styles.

10/1/07
Very tasty, nice dark tan full head, flavors of chocolate and coffee are present but not overpowering.  My favorite stout.
Bottle.  Pours thick with roasted coffee and chocolate aroma.  Flavor has espresso  and bitter chocolate notes.  This is a great stout.  Easily one of my favorite stouts!

Had this beer on 2/20/2006.  Aroma is a deep roasted malt scent.  Color is black with good carbonation and thick head.  Taste is full, roasted and toasted.  Starting with a full body it goes smooth with a bite on the end.  Finish enters with a roasted malt flavor and a faint hop flavor that is backed by a sharp toasted bitterness.  This is not the best Stout by any means but still good.

Wonderful chocolaty, roasty smell; slightly sweet aroma. Almost black with smallish head. Balanced taste with a lasting roasted/coffee-like taste. Hints of chocolate. Great medium-bodied but smooth mouthfeel. An excellent stout!

UPDATED: SEP 22, 2007 bottle 12 oz. This stout was better than I expected. well into med bodied, decent flavor with some spiciness, complexity, and dark roasted coffee. Plenty of malty creaminess with some pleasant hop flavors and bitterness. Available almost everywhere, I may even drink some again. A bit to the sweet for me, but not bad.
(3 days later) bought a 6er today for $6.99. IÂ’m upping this .2 to a 3.7, not bad at all for supermarket beer. IÂ’ll probably be looking at this brew every time I open the reefer door from now on. 9/22/07: There is a somewhat unpleasant bitterness from the bittering hops that lingers on the palate for many minutes with a bit of a menthol characteristic that I donÂ’t care for.

I am a stout fan, and this is a fine example of how a stout is supposed to be. Very dark color, really no ruby highlights on the edges. The taste is of roasted coffee beans and dark roasted chocolate...very good. This is an example of a Master Brewer showing his skill at the craft.
user_location: Why do you give a fuck?, Oregon, USA

text: 9/5/07 From the bottle.  Aroma is fruity esters and citrus blended with sweet roast malt and some light alcohol notes.  Appearance is dark brown with a persistent tan head.  Flavor is sweet, heavily roasted malt forward, full flavored with earthy/citrus hops across the palette, followed by some fruity esters and moderate bittering.  Mouthfeel is medium/full bodied, warm, with light astringency and a resiny finish.  Overall, this has great complexity and might be a little rich for some, but it goes down easy for such a big brew.

I picked his bottle up at a local store and decided it was time to try it. Here is my review:

Aroma: The aroma was of strong coffee and dark chocolate. No real hop aroma to be found.

Appearance: The brew poured into my glass a dark cola color. No ruby highlights could be seen on the sides. The head was a medium tan color and was about a finger width. Carbonation was very low to none.

Flavor: This brew tasted like coffee and roasted coffee beans. The taste has a bit of a "bite" to it, though after about two drinks, that goes away. The burnt coffee taste also shoots to the foreground and really sets this brews taste apart from others.

Mouthfeel: Not harsh nor bitter. No carbonation bite. Smooth and very very dark feeling.

Overall Impression: This is a damn fine example of a Master Brewer strutting his craft and knowing how to brew a craft beer. I really donÂ’t understand how some could give it such a low review as they have done...but to each his own...this is a dman fine brew.

Drink More Beer!!!

Bottle, pours a dark black with a one finger dark tan head that drifts to a whispy covering, good lacing.  Pleasing aroma of roasted/burnt malts, chocolate, and fresh ground coffee.  Flavor has a nice roast, and more chocolate; slightly lingering toastiness.  Palate is full and creamy, medium carbonation.  This is a nice stout!

UPDATED: JAN 16, 2008 Bottle.  Dark, rich brown with a rich and creamy tan head.  Roasted mocha aroma.  Has a nice little bite to it.  Great flavor with hints of roasted chocolate.  Smooth and creamy but not heavy.  Really enjoyable - I wish I had another one to drink today.

UPDATED: OCT 11, 2013 Black oily pour with a fluffy tan head.  Rich roasty and chocolate smell mostly, with some coffee, graham cracker, and tobacco and ash.  As one rater noted, it was nice and roasty without any burnt smells (or tastes).  Taste was beautiful on first sip.  Creamy, chocolately, perfectly bittersweet roasty goodness with a nice amount of hop bitterness.  Perfectly light to medium carbonation, and an solid slightly thick mouthfeel and flavor.  Goes down  easily and smooth, and leaves me wanting more.  Fantastic stout and very drinkable.
Near black with nice tan head.  Aroma is coffee and roasted malts.  Smooth and creamy with nice coffee and choclate flavour.  Nice rich malts throughout with a toasty presence.
Damn fine beer.  Perfect effort by Deschutes.  Smooth going down, not cloying on the tongue or leaving any nasty aftertaste.  Chocolate flavors, coffee smells, enjoy.

You can sample 50+ stouts from U.S. producers and not find a major contender like this one. Way to go Deschutes by not getting to big to make absolutely fabulous beers.
This beerÂ’s roast dominate character is so well integrated itÂ’s scarry. Big roast (not burnt charcoal) flavors dominate, but are balanced with serious carmel notes and a dollop of chocolate. Bitterness sits at medium grade and roughens the back palate. So, so nice. A must taste or hell drink a 6Â’er while youÂ’re at it.
A pretty decent stout.  I wasnÂ’t expecing much but it was a good surprise.  LOTS of flavor and DARK.  I will buy this one again.

Date: 10/13/1996
Mode: Draft
Source: corvalis pizza joint

black, whispy tan head, rich roasted chocolate aroma, rich roasted flavor followed by a strong chocolate finish, medium body 
-------- />
Date: 10/17/1998
Source: Brewfest
Score: ii+ to ii
Words: Bottle Conditioned
Words: Real Ale Festival

black, whispy tan head, rich roasted aroma, hint of chocolate, rich roasted flavor followed by a chocolate finish, medium body 

Aroma: 8/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 10/20
Rating: 2.9/5.0Score: *4

The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.
this stout has a harsh bitter character that overwhelms the taste buds... there is a late bite on the palate that is displeasing as well

black with medium size khaki head.
smell of roasted malt, cocoa, whiff of coffee.
nicely bitter, smooth, taste of dark cocoa, the cocoa taste hides the alcohol extremely well, you can just taste a little bit on the back-end.
very, very, nice stout, deschutes did well with this one.

Poured from a bottle.  Poured a deep brown, nearly black color with a nice tan head.  Initial smell is milk chocolate and roasted malts.  Taste matches the aroma with a nice milk chocolate start that leads into roasted malt flavor.  Little bitterness.  It is thick, and nice lacing is left throughout the glass.  Very nice stout.

Draft at Taphouse Grill in downtown Seattle. Pours midnight brown with a tan head and good lacing. Aroma of subtle dark roast, milk, and chocolate. Full bodied with a slight creaminess to the texture. Initial flavor of milk chocolate, hazlenut, and dark roasted grains that transitions to coffee and tamed bitterness mid palate. Moderate amount of residual sweetness. Finish is semi-dry and smooth. Very well done. Almost, I say almost, as good as Bells Kzoo Stout.

Pours a opaque black with thin, dark tan head that fades quickly into a thin layer of cloudy tan with a few patches of large bubbles. The head laces the glass heavily. The aroma is big and dark: dark fruit, sugar, coffee, malts, and alcohol. The flavor is quite nice - it starts bitter-sweet with loads of coffee, chocolate, and fruity hops. The middle of the tongue picks up more roasted grain flavors (burnt toast, coffee) combined with hop flavors and sweet malts with a hint of caramel. The beer finishes with a touch fruit, lots of dark, roasted, bittersweet malts, and a light dose of hops. The mouthfeel is pleasantly creamy with just a subtle impression of acidity from the carbonation, and it finishes full in body. Overall, an awesome stout.

The best stout I have had to date.  Very smooth body nice tan head that stays.  Wonderfully rich and malty flavor with a faint coffee essence.  My first Deschtes beer. For this beer alone I wish Deschutes was marketed in my state.

Thanks to hellbilly for the bottle! pours dark with thick creamy head, that slowly disapates to a killer film. lots of lacing.roasted malts, choolate, figs,  and coffee. finishÂ’s with a wonderful dry chocolate, vanilla, and hops. very complex with all types of nice this going wonderful balance as well. I wish i could get this on the reg. very rich beer!

UPDATED: JUN 11, 2008 Amazing full rich malty roasted grain aroma and flavor.  Jet black base, dense sandy head.  Bold, fierce taste that warms like a hug from yr grandmother.  Not too thick, not too thin with a bit of some alcohol bite.
Pours dark, small tan head. Very smooth and very flavorful, excellent beer from Deschutes

Nice rich coffee-chocolate aroma, toasted-burnt grain, and a smoky sweetness. Light milky sweetness. Dark brown-black clear with foamy-frothy tan head. Medium heavy body with medium carbonation. Great toasted-burnt malt sweetness with chocolate and light coffee bitterness. Tangy carbonic finish with nice dryness. Molasses and mild alcoholic after.
Draft. Black, black with a medium and lasting head. Nice aroma of roasted malts, grassy hops. Blend of coffee and molasses, slight bittering hops. Palate is smooth and medium-heavy bodied.
This beer is as dark as the night. A very dark stout that gives the taste of heavy malts and produces a dark tinted head and it lasts. The finish is extremely dry, but worth it. a good beer.

Bottle. Pours black with a large, persistent tan head. Aroma is roasted malt, with a bit of coffee and hint of chocolate. Flavor is bitter roasted malt with some earthiness; very dry. The aftertaste is actually a bit more interesting than the initial flavor, with bitter chocolate, vanilla, and of course more roast. A well-made dry stout.

Bottle: Pours black with a light tan head, nice lacing. Aroma, roasty, faint chocolate and coffee, with earthy quality. Flavor, roasted malts, some dry bitterness, and some coffee. Definitely on the dry side, not much sweetness at all. Palate is fizzy to start but smooths out as it goes down.

Bottle. [thanks to after4ever]. Pours a grand-looking black (only slightly brown edges on my (well-chosen) Guinness pint glass). Head is fizzy as I pour, but it settles as a thick, lacing brown whipped cream on top of the blackness. Aroma is mild and sweet - but certainly not weak. There is a clear definition of cocoa, a touch of vanilla and distant coffee. I sense a touch of yeastyness coming through as well. I was initially surprised by the mouthfeels fizzyness, entering my mouth and dancing a little around on my tongue. But it soon settles and a distinct creamyness comes through. Flavour is quite dry, almost like taking a piece of dark chocolate and letting it melt in your mouth. The vanilla comes through the cocoa, roasted and mild coffee tones to balance it out nicely. Only bad(ish) thing is that the initial flavour on drinking it is quite limited, only for the aftertaste to really come through.

pours obsidian with thin dark khaki head.  aroma smooth coffee and cocoa with a little toffee malt.  taste is coffee and cocoa with a slight sweetness peeking through.  finish dry bitter with some roasted malt astringence.  solid stuff (very very similar to a stout i just made at home).

pours obsidian with thin dark khaki head.  aroma smooth coffee and cocoa with a little toffee malt.  taste is coffee and cocoa with a slight sweetness peeking through.  finish dry bitter with some roasted malt astringence.  solid stuff (very very similar to a stout i just made at home).

This one poured quite black, I guess that name isnÂ’t an ironic one. Quite a sweet smelling aroma, with a bit of molasses, but on tasting it was dry. A bit of nuttiness in the aftertaste. A little lacking in body, but overall itÂ’s a decent drop.

Pours black with a thick tan head that reduces to a noticeable film.  A nicely pungent aroma composed mainly of hops with some roasted or earthy malt tones mixed in.  The more I smell, the more different aromas I find.  Initial flavor has the bite of the hops, but it gives way to the chocolate/burnt malt flavors that dominate the finish.  ItÂ’s a very noticeable and nice transition.  ItÂ’s not too heavy on the tongue - a nice medium bodied beer.  Great finish that leaves me wanting more.  I think IÂ’ll stock up on this one.

Nice subtle roasted malt aromas.  Creamy textures with a burnt coffee/french roast finish.  A little bit of sweetness in the taste along with some cocoa.  This one is medium bodied and well rounded for a stout.  Good and smooth.

Courtesy Quake. Black/brown. Small brown cap. Roasty, chocolatey malt in the nose, not much else. Flavor adds bittersweet chocolate and a bit of coffee. Simple but good. Medium body, balanced carbonation. Decent, very drinkable.

Bottle.  Aroma of roasted malt, caramel malt, chocolate, and coffee.  The flavor is mostly roasted malt and coffe, with a slightly creamy mouthfeel.  Nice aftertaste, maybe a little too much coffee for me.

Black with a big tan head. Smells and tastes sweet and a little roasty. Good stout but I think it really should be a sweet stout instead of just a stout. ItÂ’s a bit too sweet for my liking as an everyday stout. Still though itÂ’s solid.
Dark malt and yeast aroma. Pours black with a brown head that dimintshes quickly. Sweet malt taste. slightly creamy.
Bottle.  Roasted malts with chocolate aroma.  Fairly clean and dry finish - fairly bitter and very drinkable.  Not bad

Bottle... Poured a black tone with a fluffy, brown head.  Roasty, malt, and chocolates on the nose. Really enjoyable and smooth palate, flavors of chocalate, malt, hops, caramel, vanilla bean and a bit leafy.. very smooth finish.

Black with a thick dark tan soapy head.  Sweet aroma with some light roast notes, a bit of hops, too.  Lighter palate.  Light chocolate roast flavors over a slight hop middle and bitter finish.  Wish I could get enough to give it a proper session.
Nice dark color with toasty mild chocolate flavors. a little carbonated on the palate. a lighter taste with not too much depth. Could be a bit smoother.

canÂ’t see any light through the glass...nice! aroma is nutty with a lot of malt. flavors of darkened malt, bitter chocolate and scalded cream. nice rich beer. iÂ’ve always walked past it at the store... now itÂ’s a regular
Deep brown/Black in color with ruby highlights and a light tan colored head. Aroma/flavor is of roasted malts, slight chocolate with a touch of sweetness.
350 mL bottle.  Pours black with a fizzy tan head.  Aroma of chocolate and fruit.  Sweet dark malts come through in the taste, smooth palate, with a slightly bitter finish.  Decent.

Pours an attractive dark brown with a nice tan head (lasts longer in a narrow glass).  Aroma of some sort of raspberry-ish tang, dirt, caramel, chocolate (not too dark), and milk/creamer.  Dry roasty taste, with some milk chocolate and a tangy hop taste.  Finishes very earthy, dirtlike with some black coffee there.  Great mouthfeel (creamy, low-carbonation, not thin, but drinkable) and a good stout overall.  Tangy-qualities are out of place though.

Very dark in color,  I had this one on nitro so it drank smoothly.  Average head retention.  On the palate it was thick and rich.  I could taste roasted coffee and definitely chocolate notes.  There is a prevalence of hops in the finish; a little bit of a bite, but taste didnÂ’t linger in my mouth.

aroma of nougat (like the center of a 3 musketeers, w/ caramel & cocoa. opaque darkest brown w/ thick mocha foam. thick & smooth in the mouth, tongue feeling the dark & slightly sour. flavors of roasted & smoked malts, marshmallow, citrus underneath. complex finish, including darkest chocolate. I can see its base in Guinness, but the NW revolution, with more hops, body & alcohol.

12oz bottle Best by 04/13/07.  Pours black with a 1/2 finger tan head that dissipates to a ring and a thin film after a minute.  Aroma of roasted malts and coffee, grain, oats, light anise, tobacco, and maybe a bit of soy.  Flavor is somewhat bitter and roasty up front, with some salted nuts, grain,  some molasses sweetness, and a little earth.   Big roasty bitter finish---mmmm good!  Medium smooth body with some moderate carbonation.  Very good stout--I wouldnÂ’t mind having this more often at all.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Courtesy Quake1028.  Pours a pitch black with a light tan head.  Smells really nice, some coffee, lovely chocolate, dark malts, and a little roastiness as well.  Fairly light bodied, big chocolate and coffee, especially in the finish.  Very roasty as well, with a good bit of nuttiness.  Not a bad stout at all.
UPDATED: OCT 16, 2008 Bottle: Dark brown colour with a tan head. Aroma is roasted, hop, chocolate. Flavour is sweet, coffee, fruit, hop, chocolate, roasted. Nice  and harmonic beer.
Bottled. Dark, ruby red with a dense, tan head. Chocolate, mocha, smoke, some roast and even more chocolate in both aroma and flavor. Full body. A really nice one. (070413)

12 oz bottle.  Best by 12/06.  Dark brown with a thick cratered tan head.  Rings of lace.  Raisin, dusty oats and light molasses.  Bitter black licorice and cocoa with pithy tang.  Juicy lime leads to a dry, bittersweet chocolate finish.  Medium body but drinks lighter.
Has a very nice chocolate aroma.Pours black with a light tan head.Smooth chocolate with some big roasted malt in there as well in the flavor.Medium mouthfeel with a bitter/roasted finish.

Bottle from Iowaherkeye, thanks!  Nice roast chocolate scent.  Black with a tan head.  Medium palate at best.  Plenty of roasted malt, bitter chocolate and a tangy sort of finish.  Not as good as I had expected.

Bottle : Pours black and opaque with a thick brown creamy head. Tons or roasty coffee aroma and charcoal. Favor is rich with roasted barley. nice malt backbone but the burnt woody and dry coffee take over. Finishes semi dry and clean. Very nice house stout.

Dark ruby-brown with abundant, lasting light brown head. Aroma is roasty, malty, alcoholic, licorice. Full-bodied, foamy mouthfeel, roasty/hoppy flavor. Tasty, well-balanced, easy-to-drink. A finely-crafted stout.

(Bottle 35,5 cl) Pours completely black and opaque with a dense, creamy, light brown head leaving laces. Very burned aroma. Medium body with a very smooth mouthfeel, distinct flavours of burned malt and a high degree of sweetness - this really comes close to a Sweet Stout. Burned, bitter finish. 290307

bottle split with Muenster. The pour is pretty black here with a lasting dark tan head. The aroma is spiritous with just a touch of hops. Notes of coffee, bourbon, and even some fruits, maybe apples, are present.  The mouthfeel is just slightly viscous. Flavors of espresso are apparent along with that harsh, ashy, burnt oat taste IÂ’m so fond of in stouts. ItÂ’s not a very sweet beer, but there is a substantial amount of fruity character like banana or apple. Finish is a bit ashy. Well done.

Bottle split with NachlamSie. Pours black, with a nice tan head, and some mysterious sediment at the bottom. Aroma is strong roast, with coffee beans, dark, musty fruit, and some mild hops. Flavor is nice roasty malt goodness with some bourbon and strong oaky notes. Nice stout.

Medium statured tan head, good retention and a lovely stringy, coating lace that hangs. Black, opaque brew. Nose is grainy, roasty and fruity with light coffee notes too boot not to mention some tarry notes. Body is med/full, oily with a tangy touch. Nice roast flavors, coffee, citrus notes creeping threw, a hint of black patent and dark fruits. Finish is fairly dry and roasty. Another enjoyable Stout! Props to kenb for this one in a trade awhile ago.

Pours black with tan head. Aroma is toasty and light. The flavor is what you expect from a stout. Chocolate coffee and roasted malts. Nothing stand out but very solid. Plus the flavor isnÂ’t as strong as many stouts and I actually like that. It lets you appreciate the subtilties a bit more I think.

Served in my delirium tremens tulip.
Pours a very dark brown with a nice quarter inch head. Nice lacing and froth remains.
Smell is roasted malts and cocoa bean.  Taste is of bittering coffee bean. The mouthfeel is carbonated and medium in feel.  A decent stout from an above average brewery. A good session beer that I would like to have on hand at all times.

12 oz. bottle on 3/19/07 in Colorado. Pours black with a large deep tan head. Aroma is dark roasted and burnt coffee. Thick and full mouthfeel thatÂ’s smooth and satsfying. Dark caramel and molasses sweetness is balanced by a nice peppery bitterness. This a really nice everyday, easy drinking stout.

12 oz bottle.  Very dark.  Nice foamy head.  Lots of nutty roasty burnt aromas.  Very similar flavor.  Super nutty... roasted nuts.  Some coffee came through on the flavor as well.  Some alohol flavor on the finish.  Very yummy.

bottle; best by 5.26.07. obtained via trade with kenb. Opaque, with a moderate sized brown head. Fairly subdued aroma, with notes of chocolate and licorice. Roasted malt up front builts in intensity towards the finish. Hops most evident towards the end. Long lasting bitter finish. Thanks, Ken!

bottle from yonkers65: pours black with a large fluffy tan head. aroma of sweet chocolate and malts i dont know if a scent can be smooth, but this is a smooth aroma with some nuttiness.  flavour is smooth chocolate balanced well with the malt sweetness. a very well balanced stout that has a nice lingering bitterness to it, that finishes with some bitter coffee notes.

A dark brown pour with a tan head and more good lacing. An aroma of buttery chocolate cake. A rolling flavor of carbonated espresso. The flavor seems to transition from espresso to that chocolate then to a hard bitter that really makes this beer special. No bad tones on the bitter it just spreads across the palate. I hate to sound like a broken record but the palate is solid except for a touch overly carbonated a really good beer.

Thanks to awaisanen for the trade.  Pours a deep black with just hints of some amber coming through.  Large foamy/rocky deeper tan head that left nice spotty lacing.  Aroma of up front grainy maltiness, doughy, roasted malts, caramel, nuts and a very light hop presence.   Flavor of roasted/toasty malts, some dark chocolate, coffee with cream and sugar, nutty and just an overall very solid stout. One of the best I have had.

My bottle seems to have passed the "Fresh by" date, canÂ’t wait to try a fresh one.  Very roasted, sweet chocolate.  Mellow, calm and fulfilling.  Not overly dimensional, bold and delivering.  Creamy, slightly acidic in the finish.  Somewhat earthy.  Hint of alcohol.

Bottle. A tasty stout, but perhaps lacking the complexity of stout if a similiar ilk. Nice deep brown to black appearance. Aroma has the usual suspects of mocha, roast and chocolate. Palate is sweet, with light caramel notes, then a roasty malt character and then, as is the tradition in the NW US, lots of citric, piney hops in the finish. Lots of flavour, but the body was quite light.
Nice black pour with a slight smoke aroma and some malt as well. Tasted very smooth with nice chocolate and smoke flavors. Had a real subtle coffee feel to it also. Good stuff

I first had this beer on tap in Olympia WA and it was an experience that opened my eyes to good beers. Beautiful obsidian in the glass with a thick creamy head. Full bodied, smooth and hearty with subtle smoke and chocolate notes. A wonderful everyday stout.
Another jet black pour for the evening with a smoky chocolate aroma.  Similar chocolate body.

Pitch black with a light brown, huge and creamy head. The aroma has notes of roasted malt and chocolate. The mouthfeel is quite full. The flavour is surprisingly mild, but it has a nice body with notes of chocolate, cocoa, licorice and coffee. The balance and bitterness is nice, and it is a nice stout for beginners too. Thank you Tom/After4ever for this nice beer, that I had on my wishlist! 1911

Black, creamy tan head.  Nose held soft notes of dark roast coffee and black chocolate, and lighter wafts of citrus.  Flavor was a bit more intense then the nose with notes of lightly smoked coffee, roasty chocolate, a touch of vanilla, and some faint ashy earthy bitterness.  Light to medium bodied, medium carbonation, dry bittersweet finish.  Well made stout.  Thanks for sharing Schutzenliesel....

12oz bottle from Jake65 - thanks! Nice inky black stout with a sweet roasty aroma. Very drinkable, not excessive mouthfeel. The dominant presence is chocolate smoothness, but as it warms thereÂ’s a touch of bitter roastage. Very fine stout.

12oz bottle, courtesy of Schutzenliesel.  Thanks, Tom!  Pours a dark black center with a reddish tinge; light tan head.  Pleasant cocoa and milk chocolate aroma.  Full, chewy cocoa mouthfeel: dark chocolate, roasted malts, plenty of smoke; vanilla and light bitterness.  Medium, burnt malt and milk chocolate finish.
Pours brown with a thin tan head and great lacing.  Smells of roses, pepper, spices and earthy hops.  Tastes of sweet malt, chocolate and raisins.
This has a light coffee aroma.  Simple, straightforward malt flavor, only a little roasted taste and very light chocolate-coffee.

Pitch black color with a medium head.  A pretty strong roasted malt aroma with a little nuttiness.  Big, thick, roasted malt flavor.  Nothing crazy, nothing subtle.  Just a solidly bitter malt taste with a little chocolate on the end.  Nice.

Pours a jet black with a tiny tan head.  Nice smokey nutty aroma with hints of bittersweet chocolate.  Medium carbonation with a nice toasty smokiness.  Light chocolate flavor accented by a nice citrus hop touch that finishes unbelievably.
user_location: Farewell Minny; Hello Puyallup, Washington, USA

text: Thanks to BuckeyeBoy for trading this one to me. Black with a average tan head.  Big roasted nut, chocolate, and coffee aroma. Flavor is light smoke, huge roasted nutty, coffee, and chocolate. Has a mild dry finish.

UPDATED: FEB 13, 2007 Bottle.  Thick and dark with a small brown head with lots of lacing. Has no sweetness, some nuts and lots of roast and chocolate.  Has hints of smoke in it as well.  Big thick mouthfeel that goes down really smooth.  ItÂ’s hard to find anything I donÂ’t like about this beer.  Loads of flavor.  A quality stout if IÂ’ve ever had one.  Very satisfying.

Bottle and Tap - various locations in OR. 
POurs black with a brown espresso like head, itÂ’s opaque and oily looking. Delicious, rich, smoky/toasty flavors. Chocolate flavors follow and round out a superbly smooth brew.

Bottle (Sydney Summer Gathering 2007): A solid performer. Thick opaque black with a menacing tan head. THereÂ’s no mistaking where this is headed, or is there? In the nose, slightly salty, roasty aromas over a base of chalk. Possibly a touch thin. Thankfully, it was just a case of the liquid not wanting to give up its essence. In the mouth lots of roasted grains swirl around creamy chocolate. ThereÂ’s not really a lot of complexity here, but thereÂ’s a hell of a lot of flavour. Tasty.
Pours black, thin tan head.  Flavor is dark chocolate and roasts.  Finish is more roastiness and dry.  Might be a little too much roasts for my taste, but still a nice beverage.

Another star performer at an Australian group tasting of absurd extravagance. I might rate this even higher had it not been sandwiched by a couple of stunning Mikkellers and succeeded by a pair of Pannepots, Westveleterens and a Belle Vue Selection Lambic. Oh, that every day could be like that Sunday. Obsidian Stout was an impenetrable black capped by a lavish layer of coffee cream. The aroma was rich with molasses, cocoa powder and sump oil - a feast of roasted grains. Medium bodied but quite lactic. Good bitterness. ItÂ’s sweet but very balanced, with a late sourness in a dry finale. A fine balancing act. (Bottle courtesy of Linc at the Sydney Jan 2007 RateBeer gathering)

Bottle.  Black color, fluffy brown head with some nice lacing.  Roasty aroma with a hint of imperial stout-ish hops, taste is pretty simple with some dirt, coffee, chocolate.  Medium bodied, dry finish.

Bottle. Pours a pitch black color with a medium tan head. Aroma of dark chocolate and roasted coffee beans. Taste is of dark chocolate earthy and bitter. Finishes very dry. Not a very complex stout but still manages to keep your interest.

ItÂ’s a pretty average black with some espresso head.  Malted milk balls, grocery store coffee and a little soy sauce in the aroma.
