Very enojoyable imp. stout.  Dark , bu tnot opaque.  Very dark head and good carbonation.  Chocolately and roasty with a heavy caramel backbone. Tasty use of hops in moderation leaving a very chewy stout.  Thanks Santa.

Nitro at brewery: Very black with a typical nitro head. Mind-blowing aroma in this beer! Before taking my first sip, I just sat there smelling it for many minutes. Very roasted, burnt, bitter, coffeeish and chocolatey. Sweet malt base provided a nice platform. Chewy texture gave the beer purpose. Great beer ... and probably the best nitro I've ever had (it didn't seem to dumb the beer down or rob any of its aromas).
Nice deep dark with espresso head.  Aroma of fresh roast.  Nice sweet flavor with all the malt in the world and just a touch of hops to say thanks from Bend, OR.  Good solid stuff.
oh my god last time i had his i bought a 6 pack and slammed all of'em and damn near fainted this is some serous quality brew great hop taste and a slight hint of roasted malt..killer suff A+

dark and dense, super thin head, aroma of chocolate, coffee and roasted malts, flavor is rich with hints of roasted malts, nuts and mocha, finish has a little bit of a hop bite, but the body is a little thin. If I were a rapper i might say something like: "i'd rather have this stout than have the gout... werd"

Bought in the 12oz brown bottle..nice simple label .
Appearance what can i say but its BLACK pitch black no light permeates this beer very small head even when poured roughly..soon fades to a ring around the glass.
Nice stout smell but there is something different here..among the usual toasted oats i smell a double clotted cream aroma.. strange but welcoming.
The tatse of this beer is pure pleasure..creamy yet rough..slight yet massive..so much taste sensation..massive variety. black coffee and fudge clash..nice hoip bitterness to end..i even taste cream cheese..man so complex.
Feels magic on the tongue leaves the back of my mouth tingling with anticipation.
Good drinkability if its cold outside a massive brew..very good stuff.

UPDATED: OCT 25, 2008 Bottle (BB Jan/09).

Head is initially average sized, frothy, brown, mostly lasting.
Body is dark brown to black.

Aroma is moderately malty (roasted grain, dark chocolate, coffee), with notes of bile and chalk.

Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is lightly sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, moderately bitter, slightly husky.

Medium to full body, velvety texture, lively carbonation.

Both this and the Black Butte I just sampled are three months before their BB date, yet both have off-notes of sour stomach acid reflux, somewhat vegetal.  Weird and unpleasant.
Nice dark color.  pretty light for a stout.  However it's still full of flavor.  Toasted malt, chocolate and coffee are the well balanced flavors.  Lovely.
UPDATED: OCT 12, 2003 Another great one from Deschutes, pours black with a fairly large brown head.  Thick, roasted, and delicious.

Sampled on Nitro.

Out-fricking-standing.

I went to a bar tonight, which I rarely do, and I noticed some writing on the Obsidian Stout handle that the bottles didn't have. I looked closer and noticed that it had "NITRO" in big red letters across the handle. Deschutes is my favorite brewery anyway, so I had to give it a shot. I couldn't be more glad that I did. 

Please note that this review is primarily comparing this version to the bottled version, so if you want to read my full review, scroll down a bit. This is everything the bottle gives and more.

Deep black pour with an incredibly fine and thick head. It didn't leave lace, it left a sheet behind on the glass. The scent was a bit more subdued than the bottled version but it was still excellent. Tasted heavenly, of course, since I don't think Deschutes could make a bad beer if they tried.

The mouthfeel is where the difference *really* kicks in. Guiness only *wishes* it could be this creamy and still maintain this kind of flavor.

Pours like it's name, with a dark tan head and good lacing. Roasted malt 
nose with some fruit. Pleasing roasted coffee flavors, with a very creamy palate.
A very good stout, with a pleasant and complex roasty nose, backed up with an initially smooth malt body that finishes with a nice, dry roast.  An excellent and highly drinkable stout.

Loads of chocolate in the aroma, with a mild pine presence and some burnt/roast barley on the finish. Not really dark but holds a head nicely and then you taste it... it's all disappointment from here on in, mainly tastes of burnt barley, that chocolate aroma has almost entirely disappeared, you get some slight notes of caramel but any flavours are swept away by the anorexic body.

Black with thick brown head. Heavy malty aromas, roasted grain, coffee, chocolate and somewhat nutty. Very malty flavors, sweet and nutty. Hops noticeable on the finish. Body is only medium with a dry texture.

(draft) Black body with brown head.  Aroma is medium sweet, chococoffee, roasty.  Taste is sweet, chococoffee, light roasty, finishing with medium bitter coffee with hint of herbal.  Full body.  As sweet as the Black Butte, but slightly fuller body handles it better.

Super dark brown with a brown/red foam that settled into a nice 1/2-inch thick tan head.  The aroma is a nice combination of roasted malt, chocolate, burnt toast, and only a hint of coffee.  The hops are quite subtle in the nose.  Smooth, velvety body.  The flavor is rather bitter.  Strong, bitter coffee and bitter hops seem to dominate.  Chocolate, caramel and raisins all raise their heads from the pitch at random intervals.  Flavorful and full bodied, a little more bitter than I would have liked.   A decent mid-summer stout.

Tan/reddish head;opaque OBSIDIAN color, with a sourish nose of roasted malt with a slight minty hop aroma. nice middleweight stout, not imperial, not wimpy Irish dry, sorta "foreign extra" in style, with definite northwest traits...makes a good black n' tan, but don't expect it to "float".

A very dark beer with red edges like a coca cola.  Head was kinda weak.  A decent stout, probably a bit too sweet for my liking though.  Mouthfeel was crisp and thin.  I noticed lots of yeasties towards the bottom of the glass...very intersting, I wasnt expecting that from this beer for some reason.  Ive had many better stouts, but it put up a showing.

Pitch-black, small head.  Okay, this bottle was bought about four months ago, so this *MIGHT* be a distorted rating, but it seemed a little off.  It was an okay stout with the standard roasted coffee flavor, but there was definitely some sourness to it that didn't fit in and lingered in the finish.  Or maybe the bar was set too high by last night's Siberian Night Imperial...
Good roasted barley presence.  Dry, bitter finish with notes of chocolate, slight soy in the nose.  Bit nutty.
Tan, frothy head.  Sticks around for a while.  The aroma is fairly bland, a little bit of malt.  Sweet malty flavor.  Soft mouthfeel.  Not bad.
A deep brown/black with a off white head. The aroma is of roasted malts with a hint of chocolate and nuts. The flavor is of roasted malts, coffee, chocolate and nuts. A very nice stout.
Thanks to Gregory for this bottle. Very good stout. Nice robust roasted flavor. Poured jet black. This is a keeper!!!
UPDATED: APR 22, 2003 One of my favorites, although I haven't had it since leaving Seattle. Smooth creamy texture with a dry, strong crisp flavor. Enjoyed right out of fridge and closer to room temp.

Jet black colour with a small & creamy mocha head. Aroma of burnt coffee, bitter chocolate and warm alcohol. Nice, smooth body with a pleasant creaminess. More bitter coffee & chocolate in the flavour. A very good quality stout.

(8Mar2003--draft)
What the hell is wrong with this stuff?  Almost a pour, but alas, I had no sink handy.
Nitro-priming was the first sign of trouble.
Pours with a thick, synthetic head.  Opaque.
Roasty, oddly alcoholic aroma.
The same roasty, oddly alcoholic notes dominated the flavor.
The best analogy I can concoct is chocolate liqueur.  I think there
is a definite problem here with fusel alcohols.
Alot of roasted malt comes through on this one.  Has a coffee taste and an aroma of roasted malt.  Very good stout.
Extremely creamy head.  Nice average stout with hint of roasted malts and a hint of hops.  Not an overpowering stout, and surprisingly easy to drink.

Years ago before I had really started drinking beer, and way before I developed a taste for it, I asked a 21 year old friend to go to the store and grab my friends and I some "good" beer. By "good" I meant easy to drink, in hindsight what we really wanted was something like Mike's or Hornsby, but what we got was this. At first sip I wanted my money back from the asshole who we thought intentionally purchased us the worst beer at the store. Years later, I can say that this is really not a bad beer. What freaked me out so much was the flavor: strong roasted malt and cloying richness - but that's what I dig now. Very well balanced and very solid, like the Black Butte is to porters.
Roasty chocolate aroma, brown creamy head but a little thin.  Black, opaque in color.  This is a well built, hardy beer.  The chocolate really stands out.  Medium carbonation.

True to the nature of the name.  Great head retention as well.  Milk chocolatey malts with roasted hints, maybe some caramel as well.  Fairly dry and bitter, loaded with hops.  To me the hop character is awful prevailing, more-so than I'd like, but it is good stuff for sure!

UPDATED: DEC 11, 2003 Pours a dark brown with a khaki head of rather large bubbles that collapses to a ring of bubbles. Pretty average looking for a stout. Sweet-roasty aroma of caramel, chocolate, smoke, and coffee with touches of dried bananas and twang of hops. Somewhat sweet flavor with a light roasty finish. Very drinkable for a stout. Solid stuff.
Awesome dark flavor...one of the best smoky flavors I've ever had. It also has some fruity flavor behind the dark flavors.
A burnt malt flavor that is a little to dominant. A rich malty beer with a lighter than typical hop presence. For those that want to push the brunt grain envelope this is your beer. But its not mine

I was turned onto this a few weeks ago, and enjoyed it very much.  Very rich and dark, a lightly burnt but not too bitter, a bit of a coffee aftertaste.  Extremely drinkable even if you are not a big fan of stouts you will love this beer.
Nasty
UPDATED: JUN 21, 2013 [rerate needed] Extremely rich, very dark.  Wonderful sweet aroma, with a roasted taste.  A staple of my beer fridge.
This is definitely a worthy example of a stout.  Very dark color, very roasty and coffee colored hues shine through indefinitely. This is very easy to drink and always a dependable choice.

UPDATED: JUL 7, 2003 Stout is my favorite style. This one pays a great hommage to the style. Pitch black color, sweet and stout smell. Chocolate and slight coffee taste. Very smooth aftertaste, not too bitter like some stouts. Very drinkable. I like this beer especially because it is readily available in my area and not too expensive.
UPDATED: JUL 9, 2006 Black, small lasting brown head. Great roasty nose and flavor with a bitter burnt  but dry malt end. Good body

Ink black with a tall and void filled tan head. Aromas of sweet dark chocolate and raisins. Flavor of powdered hot chocolate mixwith a somewhat grainy mouthfeel and a pronounced initial sharpness that settles and smooths as it passes down the throat.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2003 black black! double dose of fricken' black!...tan head subsided and left a ring around the collar...aroma shouted BURNT!, ROASTED!, subtle coffee bean & fudge brownie...blackened coffee bean 'special' brownie, especially baked for your pleasure...roasted coffee bean was such a pleasing 'hello' that I double-taked it's presence...Damn fine..Coffee lovers unite...this is the beer for you, as long as you like it black, as I do, and not with all that cream and sugar panzy style!
Black color, silky foamy head, sweet malty aroma, coffee sweet chocolate flavors, some hop biternes, finishes sweet.

This beer rocks.
The aroma is of heavily roasted malt, roasted nuts and very dark chocolate. There are also a few floral notes in the nose which provide a hint of the flavor that is still yet to come.
The color is black. Total and complete black. I held the pint glass up to a very strong halogen lamp and still nothing but black. Actually, I thought I saw yeast particles floating in there, but it may have simply been the slow rising light brown bubbles which eventually form the beerÂ’s medium-sized, creamy head. Excellent lacing.
Up front, the flavor is of heavily roasted malt, roasted coffee and obscenely dark chocolate. Moderately bitter and pungent on the backside. Blasts of espresso and alcohol.
Full-bodied with very lively carbonation and a creamy/fizzy mouthfeel. A long, bitter, crazy-dry finish. There wasnÂ’t a sweet note found in my bottle. A stout manÂ’s stout.

porter and stout tasting Â’02:  pours black, off white head.  fruity, roasty, nutty aroma.  low carbo gives a nice mellow mouthfeel.  malty dark chocolate flavours up front, some sligtht smoky nuttiness in the background.  finish was more sweet and less hoppy than I expected.

What a great beer. Thick and oily in the mouth, just what youÂ’d expect and hope for after looking at the deep blackness and thick foam in your glass. Malty with a decisive hop bite. Bitter chocolate and fruity. Very drinkable.

Black, opaque, impressive chocolate mousse foam. Nose is roasty but with some fruitiness for the style. Definitive dark chocolate and roastiness on the palate followed by mild hop bitterness and fruit in the second half. Pretty easy drinking for its style. Typical of several west coast stouts but not particularly complex.
Bottle.  Black with a coffee brown head and a dark chocolate aroma.  A thick rich body that screams roasted coffee.  It leaves a long and sweet aftertaste.  This is how I like my stouts.
One of the finer stouts with a simple formula: Black as coal with a huge body to match, a very malty flavor with a nice strong after-taste
Extreme smokey, semisweet chocolate aroma. Great flavors...smokey, sweet, bitter, chocolate, nutty. Dark brown/black color. Slightly thick feel. Nice malty aftertaste.
Sweet chocolate-covered nut aroma, opaque obsidian color (go figure), very slight malty taste, with chocolate and hops. Very full, complex flavor.

Dark Black color, medium creamy head. Nice pour. Deeply roasted malts, slightly hoppy. Full flavored and full bodied stout. Very smooth taste, pronounced chocolate flavor. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.

It certainly is the color of black obsidian! Tan head not very substantial, but leaves more-than-adequate lace. Aroma nice balance of sweet and roasted malt...some vanilla highlights. Taste commences with hint of sweetness, quickly overwhelmed by strong doses of coffee, cocoa, perhaps a little charcoal too...Softer, sweeter tones emerge again toward the very smooth finish. Just enough carbonation to lighten the substantial character of this stuff. The "chewy" description is very accurate. This is an excellent stout: complex, intense, substantial...Well done, Deschutes!
opaque black color.  firm tan head.  slight oakiness, vanilla in the nose.  creamy, with strong coffee flavors.
Screw Guinness, this beer redefines stout. Great depth of flavor, awesome mouthfeel. Grab one today! 07/30/02 One, no way. I did however do a 6er of these recently. Just as good as ever!
Sweet, very malty and sort of roasty.  I really like this one.
I was quite disappointed by this stout.  Very smooth but appeared to fall flat as it went down.
very good beer. not even translucent. good taste, even if very alcoholic.
Pretty good stout.  Wonderfully smooth, dark rich flavors, lightyl roasted malt on the palate, medium body, nicely balanced.

One of the smoothest stouts IÂ’ve ever had.  Appropriately named, a beer to stare into.  Way too coffee for my taste buds, I am not a coffee person.  Chocolate notes helped balance that though.  Not for me but I would recomend trying it.
Excellent hop bitterness/roasted chocolate malt balanceâ€¦Smelling your coffee in the proximity of a yoga master burning his feet on hot coalâ€¦Ample, delicious stoutâ€¦
Chocolate and coffee flavors prodominate. A bit overpowering but grows on you.

I can tell that Oregonians are out of step with the usual beer drinkers by seeing the average rating here--3.81.  I think in Oregon it would be closer to 4.8.  We love  stouts, and this one is loved more than the rest.  But to me itÂ’s got too much dark malt and is cloying and syrupy.  IÂ’d take a Shakespeare instead, thank you.

super roasted, jet black, definitely can taste the alchohol.  

very strong - but not quite overwhelming.  moderately hopped.  

almost qualifies as an imperial stout.  very nice.
Nice rich flavor, smooth drinking with a chewy finish,dark and overpowering
I had this for the first time this weekend. ItÂ’s great, and I recommend it to anyone who likes a chocolatey brew. Has a great aftertaste too.

UPDATED: MAR 6, 2004 When I first had this beer in high school, I didn't understand how people could drink it. I have now come to understand why as I have matured- this stuff is great. ReRate 2004. Aged one year. This mellowed out considerably, still has a great roasty taste, full body, all that.

UPDATED: JUL 7, 2009 A beautiful stout that is rich in taste.  Just the right balance of everything.  Probably the best american stout IÂ’ve tried in my few short months since becoming legal to drink.
A solid offering from a great brewery
That was a nice ride, whoah, glad itÂ’s over.  This is pretty strong with a definate coffee taste.
Too strong for my taste buds.  Deschutes makes such better tasting brewa.
coffee and rye aroma.  dark black, head was chocolate milkshake color.  chocolate, coffee, roasted oats, god this beer is complex.  incredibly good
A great stout.  Dark, heavy.  Good malty flavor, light hops.  Roasted flavor is distinguished.
Overall good beer. Beige head leaves nice lacing. Roasted aroma and bitter. Good job on this Deschutes!
UPDATED: JAN 28, 2003 Maybe if I drank it during the cold winter months my rating would be higher, but a stout in mid August just doesn't hit the spot.
Chocolatey and smooth.  ItÂ’s like a Black Butte kicked up a few notches.
An easy-going stout. I would have liked to have seen it more assertive and flavor-packed.  Certainly not bad, but IÂ’d say this in the bottom half of this breweryÂ’s line of beer.
Thick dark black brew with mild roastiness but good dark malt bite.  A semi-sweet stout with noticeable PNW hopping.  Excellent on tap ....in a bottle it loses a lot of itÂ’s luster.
Surprisingly nutty, and with a hint of chocolate.  Drinks mild.

IÂ’ve only had one of these (brought back to me from a friend on vacation), so I am prbably not qualified to comment.  It was a nice, stout-esque beer.  A little too watery for my taste.  A bit like Sam Adams, but with a little more flavor.  If you live where you can get it, give it a whirl!

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2003 The most beauteous thing in the world is a Â“StoutÂ” setting in its Â“ChaliceÂ”, that magnificent ebony color crowned by a thick head all chocolate brown, frothy and the left over lace a nice sealing sheet upon the glass. Toasted grains, Starbucks coffee, bittersweet chocolate, sweet and inviting, as is the malt-laden start and the top thick and chewy. Finish has a spicy hop bite, moderately acidic, bittersweet chocolate dry and a real treat to the palate and a top notch Â“StoutÂ” in my book.

This is one of my favorite stouts.  ItÂ’s fairly strong as far as alcohol percentage goes.  ItÂ’s got everything I look for in a stout...itÂ’s roasty, chewy, and got some sweetness to boot.  A great beer for sure!  Black as night.
